There is emerging evidence that changes in vision may involve alterations in ocular structure and function. To investigate possible mechanisms, changes in protein expression profiles and oxidative stress-associated apoptosis were examined in mouse ocular tissue after spaceflight. Nine-week-old male C57BL/6 mice (n = 12) were launched from the Kennedy Space Center on a SpaceX rocket to the ISS for a 35-day mission. The animals were housed in the mouse Habitat Cage Unit (HCU) in the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) “Kibo” facility on the ISS. The flight mice lived either under an ambient microgravity condition (µg) or in a centrifugal habitat unit that produced 1 g artificial gravity (µg + 1 g). Habitat control (HC) and vivarium control mice lived on Earth in HCUs or normal vivarium cages, respectively. Quantitative assessment of ocular tissue demonstrated that the µg group induced significant apoptosis in the retina vascular endothelial cells compared to all other groups (p < 0.05) that was 64% greater than that in the HC group. Proteomic analysis showed that many key pathways responsible for cell death, cell repair, inflammation, and metabolic stress were significantly altered in µg mice compared to HC animals. Additionally, there were more significant changes in regulated protein expression in the µg group relative to that in the µg + 1 g group. These data provide evidence that spaceflight induces retinal apoptosis of vascular endothelial cells and changes in retinal protein expression related to cellular structure, immune response and metabolic function, and that artificial gravity (AG) provides some protection against these changes. These retinal cellular responses may affect blood–retinal barrier (BRB) integrity, visual acuity, and impact the potential risk of developing late retinal degeneration.
headings: 2.1. Apoptosis in Retinal Endothelial Cells Following Spaceflight
4.2. Dissecting and Preservation of Mouse Eyes after Spaceflight
summary: This study investigated the impact of spaceflight on mouse ocular tissue, aiming to understand mechanisms behind astronaut visual impairment. It found that microgravity induced significant apoptosis in retina vascular endothelial cells, which was 64% greater than the habitat control group (p < 0.05). Proteomic analysis revealed significant alterations in pathways related to cell death, repair, inflammation, and metabolic stress, with artificial gravity providing some protection against these changes. These findings suggest spaceflight can affect blood-retinal barrier integrity and increase the risk of retinal degeneration.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of spaceflight's detrimental effects on ocular health by pinpointing retinal vascular endothelial cell apoptosis and specific proteomic alterations. The demonstration that artificial gravity offers protection against these changes provides a critical direction for developing countermeasures for astronaut visual impairment and the potential risk of late retinal degeneration during long-duration missions. This work directly informs strategies for maintaining astronaut health and mitigating risks associated with space environments.
theme: Microgravity Effects on Ocular Health and Countermeasures
original_title: Impact of Spaceflight and Artificial Gravity on the Mouse Retina: Biochemical and Proteomic Analysis.

title: Simulated Microgravity Induces Regionally Distinct Neurovascular and Structural Remodeling of Skeletal Muscle and Cutaneous Arteries in the Rat
abstract:
Introduction: Mechanical forces and sympathetic influences are key determinants of vascular structure and function. This study tested the hypothesis that hindlimb unloading (HU) exerts diverse effects on forelimb and hindlimb small arteries of rats in functionally different regions of the skeletal muscle and skin.

Methods: Male Wistar rats were subjected to HU for 2 weeks, then skeletal muscle arteries (deep brachial and sural) and skin arteries (median and saphenous) were examined in vitro using wire myography or isobaric perfusion and glyoxylic acid staining.

Results: HU increased lumen diameter of both forelimb arteries but decreased diameter of the sural artery; the saphenous artery diameter was not affected. Following HU, maximal contractile responses to noradrenaline and serotonin increased in the forelimb but decreased in the hindlimb skeletal muscle feed arteries with no change in skin arteries; all region-specific alterations persisted after endothelium removal. HU increased the sensitivity to vasoconstrictors in the saphenous artery but not in the sural artery. In the saphenous artery, initially high sympathetic innervation density was reduced by HU, sparse innervation in the sural artery was not affected. Electrical stimulation of periarterial sympathetic nerves in isobarically perfused segments of the saphenous artery demonstrated a two-fold decrease of the contractile responses in HU rats compared to that of controls.

Conclusion: HU induces contrasting structural and functional adaptations in forelimb and hindlimb skeletal muscle arteries. Additionally, HU had diverse effects in two hindlimb vascular regions. Hyper-sensitivity of the saphenous artery to vasoconstrictors appears to result from the shortage of trophic sympathetic influence. Importantly, HU impaired sympathetically induced arterial vasoconstriction, consistent with the decreased sympathetic constrictor response in humans following space flight.
summary: This study investigated how simulated microgravity (hindlimb unloading, HU) differentially affects small arteries in forelimb and hindlimb skeletal muscle and skin of rats. Key findings showed HU induced contrasting structural and functional adaptations, with forelimb arteries increasing in diameter and contractile responses, while the sural artery diameter decreased and hindlimb skeletal muscle feed artery contractile responses reduced. Notably, the saphenous artery's initially high sympathetic innervation density was reduced by HU, leading to a two-fold decrease in sympathetically-induced contractile responses, consistent with observations in astronauts post-space flight.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of region-specific neurovascular remodeling in response to simulated microgravity, elucidating how mechanical forces and sympathetic innervation influence arterial structure and function. The finding of impaired sympathetically-induced arterial vasoconstriction directly supports cardiovascular health considerations for astronauts, potentially informing the development of targeted countermeasures for long-duration space missions. Furthermore, it provides a foundational basis for future research into vascular adaptations in altered gravity and related terrestrial conditions.
theme: Microgravity Effects on the Cardiovascular System
original_title: Simulated microgravity induces regionally distinct neurovascular and structural remodeling of skeletal muscle and cutaneous arteries in the rat

title: Spaceflight decelerates the epigenetic clock orchestrated with a global alteration in DNA methylome and transcriptome in the mouse retina
abstract: Astronauts exhibit an assortment of clinical abnormalities in their eyes during long-duration spaceflight. The purpose of this study was to determine whether spaceflight induces epigenomic and transcriptomic reprogramming in the retina or alters the epigenetic clock. The mice were flown for 37 days in animal enclosure modules on the International Space Station; ground-based control animals were maintained under similar housing conditions. Mouse retinas were isolated and both DNA methylome and transcriptome were determined by deep sequencing. We found that a large number of genes were differentially methylated with spaceflight, whereas there were fewer differentially expressed genes at the transcriptome level. Several biological pathways involved in retinal diseases such as macular degeneration were significantly altered. Our results indicated that spaceflight decelerated the retinal epigenetic clock. This study demonstrates that spaceflight impacts the retina at the epigenomic and transcriptomic levels, and such changes could be involved in the etiology of eye-related disorders among astronauts.
summary: This study investigated whether 37 days of spaceflight on the International Space Station induced epigenomic and transcriptomic reprogramming in the mouse retina or altered its epigenetic clock. Researchers found a large number of genes were differentially methylated, with fewer differentially expressed genes, and several biological pathways linked to retinal diseases like macular degeneration were significantly altered. Importantly, the study concluded that spaceflight decelerated the retinal epigenetic clock, suggesting these changes could be involved in the etiology of eye-related disorders among astronauts.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of spaceflight's impact on the ocular system at molecular and epigenetic levels, linking microgravity exposure to specific changes in DNA methylation, gene expression, and epigenetic clock deceleration. Practically, these findings are crucial for developing targeted countermeasures and enhancing health monitoring protocols for astronaut eye health during long-duration missions. Broader implications extend to understanding age-related retinal diseases and the general effects of extreme environments on biological aging processes.
theme: Microgravity Effects on Retinal Genetics & Genomics
original_title: Spaceflight decelerates the epigenetic clock orchestrated with a global alteration in DNA methylome and transcriptome in the mouse retina

title: DEVELOPMENT OF OTOLITH RECEPTORS IN JAPANESE QUAIL
abstract: The present study examined the morphological development of the otolith vestibular receptors in quail. Here we describe epithelial growth, hair cell density, stereocilia polarization, and afferent nerve innervation during development. The otolith maculae epithelial areas increased exponentially throughout embryonic development reaching asymptotic values near post-hatch day P7. Increases in hair cell density were dependent upon macular location; striolar hair cells developed first followed by hair cells in extrastriola regions. Stereocilia polarization was initiated early, with defining reversal zones forming at E8. Less than half of all immature hair cells observed had non-polarized internal kinocilia with the remaining exhibiting planar polarity. Immunohistochemistry and neural tracing techniques were employed to examine the shape and location of the striolar regions. Initial innervation of the maculae was by small fibers with terminal growth cones at E6, followed by collateral branches with apparent bouton terminals at E8. Calyceal terminal formation began at E10, however no mature calyces were observed until E12, when all fibers appeared to be dimorphs. Calyx afferents innervating only type I hair cells did not develop until E14. Finally, the topographic organization of afferent macular innervation in the adult quail utricle was quantified. Calyx and dimorph afferents were primarily confined to the striolar regions, while bouton fibers were located in the extrastriola and type II band. Calyx fibers were the least complex, followed by dimorph units. Bouton fibers had large innervation fields, with arborous branches and many terminal boutons.
headings: Hair cell planar polarity and density
Type I hair cell and striolar localization in adult maculae
Afferent innervation patterns in adult maculae
Macular growth and hair cell development
summary: This study investigated the morphological development of otolith vestibular receptors in Japanese quail, describing epithelial growth, hair cell density, stereocilia polarization, and afferent nerve innervation. Key findings include exponential increases in macular epithelial areas reaching asymptotic values near post-hatch day P7, and location-dependent hair cell density increases with striolar hair cells developing first. Stereocilia polarization began at E8, with less than half of immature hair cells exhibiting non-polarized kinocilia, while innervation progressed from small fibers at E6 to mature calyx afferents for type I hair cells by E14.
impact: This research significantly advances fundamental understanding of vestibular system development, providing a detailed chronological and morphological baseline for gravity-sensing otolith organs in quail. The findings are crucial for space biology by establishing normal developmental parameters, which are essential for understanding how altered gravity environments, such as microgravity, might impact the development and function of astronauts' spatial orientation and balance systems. This foundational knowledge also has broader implications for understanding and treating terrestrial balance disorders and inner ear development.
theme: Cell Biology of Vestibular Development and Gravity Perception
original_title: Development of otolith receptors in Japanese quail.

title: Spatial and temporal characteristics of vestibular convergence
abstract: In all species studied, afferents from semicircular canals and otolith organs converge on central neurons in the brainstem. However, the spatial and temporal relationships between converging inputs and how these contribute to vestibular behaviors is not well understood. In the current study, we used discrete rotational and translational motion stimuli to characterize canal- and otolith-driven response components of convergent non-eye movement (NEM) neurons in the vestibular nuclear complex of alert pigeons. When compared to afferent responses, convergent canal signals had similar gain and phase ranges but exhibited greater spatial variability in their axes of preferred rotation. Convergent otolith signals also had similar mean gain and phase values to the afferent population but were spatially well-matched with the corresponding canal signals, cell-by-cell. However, neither response component alone nor a simple linear combination of these components was sufficient to predict actual net responses during combined canal-otolith stimulation. We discuss these findings in the context of previous studies of pigeon vestibular behaviors, and we compare our findings to similar studies in other species.
summary: This study characterized the spatial and temporal relationships of converging semicircular canal and otolith organ inputs on non-eye movement (NEM) neurons in the vestibular nuclear complex of alert pigeons. It found that while convergent canal and otolith signals had similar gain and phase ranges to afferent responses, their integration was complex: neither component alone nor a simple linear combination could predict actual net responses during combined stimulation. These findings reveal fundamental aspects of how the brainstem integrates multi-sensory vestibular information, contributing to our understanding of vestibular behaviors.
impact: Scientifically, this research significantly advances the understanding of central vestibular sensory integration, demonstrating a complex, non-linear processing of inputs from different gravito-inertial sensors. This foundational neurophysiological knowledge is critical for NASA Space Biology, as a detailed understanding of vestibular system function is essential for predicting and mitigating space motion sickness, spatial disorientation, and balance impairments experienced by astronauts. Broader implications include informing the development of clinical treatments for vestibular disorders on Earth and enhancing our general understanding of sensory processing in the central nervous system.
original_title: Spatial and temporal characteristics of vestibular convergence

title: The CaV1.2 L-type calcium channel regulates bone homeostasis in the middle and inner ear
abstract: Bone remodeling of the auditory ossicles and the otic capsule is highly restricted and tightly controlled by the osteoprotegerin (OPG) / receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-B ligand (RANKL) / receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-B (RANK) system. In these bony structures, a pathological decrease in OPG expression stimulates osteoclast differentiation and excessive resorption followed by accrual of sclerotic bone, ultimately resulting in the development of otosclerosis, a leading cause of deafness in adults. Understanding the signaling pathways involved in maintaining OPG expression in the ear would shed light on the pathophysiology of otosclerosis and other ear bone-related diseases. We and others previously demonstrated that Ca2+ signaling through the L-type CaV1.2 Ca2+ channel positively regulates OPG expression and secretion in long bone osteoblasts and their precursor cells in vitro and in vivo. Whether CaV1.2 regulates OPG expression in ear bones has not been investigated. We drove expression of a gain-of-function CaV1.2 mutant channel (CaV1.2TS) using Col2a1-Cre, which we found to target osteochondral/osteoblast progenitors in the auditory ossicles and the otic capsule. Col2a1-Cre;CaV1.2TS mice displayed osteopetrosis of these bones shown by μCT 3D reconstruction, histological analysis, and lack of bone sculpting, findings similar to phenotypes seen in mice with an osteoclast defect. Consistent with those observations, we found that Col2a1-Cre;CaV1.2TS mutant mice showed reduced osteoclasts in the otic capsule, upregulated mRNA expression of Opg and Opg/Rankl ratio, and increased mRNA expression of osteoblast differentiation marker genes in the otic capsule, suggesting both an anti-catabolic and anabolic effect of CaV1.2TS mutant channel contributed to the observed morphological changes of the ear bones. Further, we found that Col2a1-Cre;CaV1.2TS mice experienced hearing loss and displayed defects of body balance in behavior tests, confirming that the CaV1.2-dependent Ca2+ influx affects bone structure in the ear and consequent hearing and vestibular functions. Together, these data support our hypothesis that Ca2+ influx through CaV1.2TS promotes OPG expression from osteoblasts, thereby affecting bone modeling/remodeling in the auditory ossicles and the otic capsule. These data provide insight into potential pathological mechanisms underlying perturbed OPG expression and otosclerosis.
summary: This study investigated whether the CaV1.2 L-type calcium channel regulates osteoprotegerin (OPG) expression and bone homeostasis in the auditory ossicles and otic capsule, highly relevant to otosclerosis. Using gain-of-function CaV1.2TS mutant mice, researchers found osteopetrosis of these ear bones, reduced osteoclasts, upregulated mRNA expression of Opg and Opg/Rankl ratio, and increased osteoblast differentiation markers, leading to hearing loss and body balance defects. These findings support that Ca2+ influx through CaV1.2TS promotes OPG expression, affecting ear bone remodeling and providing insight into otosclerosis pathophysiology.
impact: This publication significantly advances the scientific understanding of CaV1.2's role in regulating bone homeostasis and OPG expression in specialized ear bones, offering mechanistic insights into otosclerosis, a leading cause of deafness. While not directly focused on space applications, the research contributes fundamental knowledge of bone remodeling and calcium signaling pathways, which are highly relevant to maintaining astronaut bone health in microgravity. Future research could explore the susceptibility of these specific pathways to spaceflight conditions and inform the development of targeted countermeasures for bone health.
original_title: Bone remodeling is regulated by inner ear vestibular signals

title: SIMULATED MICROGRAVITY ENHANCES OLIGODENDROCYTE MITOCHONDRIAL FUNCTION AND LIPID METABOLISM
abstract: The primary energy sources of mammalian cells are proteins, fats and sugars that are processed by well-known biochemical mechanisms that have been discovered and studied in 1G (terrestrial gravity). Here we sought to determine how simulated microgravity (sim-μG) impacts both energy and lipid metabolism in oligodendrocytes (OLs), the myelin forming cells in the central nervous system. We report increased mitochondrial respiration and increased glycolysis 24 hours after exposure to sim-μG. Moreover, examination of the secretome after three days exposure of OLs to sim-μG confirmed increased the Krebs cycle (Krebs & Weitzman et al., 1987), flux in sim-μG. The secretome study also revealed a significant increase in the synthesis of fatty acids and complex lipids such as, 1,2-dipalmitoyl-GPC (5.67), lysolipids like 1-oleoyl-GPE (4.48) were also increased by microgravity. Although longer chain lipids were not observed in this study, it is possible that at longer time points OLs would have continued moving forward toward the synthesis of lipids that constitute myelin. For centuries, basic developmental biology research has been the pillar to an array of discoveries that have led to clinical applications; we believe that studies using microgravity will open new avenues to our understanding of the brain in health and disease, in particular, to the discovery of new molecules and mechanisms impossible to unveil while in 1G.
summary: This study investigated how simulated microgravity (sim-μG) impacts energy and lipid metabolism in oligodendrocytes (OLs), the central nervous system's myelin-forming cells. Key findings include increased mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis within 24 hours, and after three days, increased Krebs cycle flux and significant synthesis of fatty acids and complex lipids, such as 1,2-dipalmitoyl-GPC (5.67) and lysolipids like 1-oleoyl-GPE (4.48). This research suggests that microgravity studies can unveil novel molecular mechanisms relevant to brain health and disease not discoverable in 1G.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of cellular metabolism under altered gravity by revealing specific enhancements in oligodendrocyte mitochondrial function and lipid synthesis. These findings are crucial for understanding the neurological implications for astronaut health during space missions and could inform countermeasure development. Furthermore, this approach offers a novel paradigm for terrestrial discovery, potentially unveiling new molecules and mechanisms relevant to neurological health and disease.
original_title: Simulated Microgravity Enhances Oligodendrocyte Mitochondrial Function and Lipid Metabolism

title: Human Neural Stem Cells Flown into Space Proliferate and Generate Young Neurons
abstract: Here we demonstrate that human neural stem cells (NSCs) proliferate while in space and they express specific NSC markers after being in space. NSCs displayed both higher oxygen consumption and glycolysis than ground controls. These cells also kept their ability to become young neurons. Electrophysiological recordings of space NSC-derived neurons showed immature cell membrane properties characterized by small capacitance and very high input resistance. Current injections elicited only an incipient action potential. No spontaneous synaptic events could be detected, suggesting their immature status even though most recorded cells displayed complex morphology and numerous cell processes. Ascertaining the origin of the NSCs′ increased energy requirement is of the essence in order to design effective measures to minimize health risks associated with long-duration human spaceflight missions.
summary: This study investigated human neural stem cells (NSCs) in space, demonstrating their proliferation and expression of specific NSC markers, while retaining the ability to differentiate into young neurons. Space-flown NSCs exhibited higher oxygen consumption and glycolysis compared to ground controls, and their derived neurons showed immature electrophysiological properties including small capacitance, very high input resistance, and only incipient action potentials without spontaneous synaptic events. The research highlights the critical need to understand the increased energy requirements of these cells to minimize health risks for astronauts during long-duration space missions.
impact: Scientifically, this publication significantly advances the understanding of microgravity's effects on human neural stem cell biology, specifically their proliferation, differentiation, and metabolic changes. Practically, these findings are crucial for assessing astronaut neurocognitive health and for developing targeted countermeasures to address the observed increased cellular energy demands during long-duration spaceflight. Broader implications include potential insights into terrestrial neurological conditions and regenerative medicine strategies, particularly concerning how environmental stressors impact stem cell function and neuronal maturation.
theme: Microgravity Effects on Neural Stem Cells
original_title: Human Neural Stem Cells Flown into Space Proliferate and Generate Young Neurons

title: Delayed Maturation of Oligodendrocyte Progenitors by Microgravity: Implications for Multiple Sclerosis and Space Flight
summary: This study investigates the impact of microgravity on the maturation of oligodendrocyte progenitors, which are crucial for central nervous system function. The key finding indicates that microgravity causes a delayed maturation of these cells. This research holds significant implications for understanding neurological changes during space flight and for terrestrial diseases such as Multiple Sclerosis.
impact: This publication significantly advances the scientific understanding of how microgravity affects central nervous system development, particularly the cellular processes of oligodendrocyte maturation. Its practical applications are critical for informing astronaut health strategies, identifying potential neurological risks during space missions, and developing countermeasures. Furthermore, these findings have broader implications for understanding and potentially addressing demyelinating diseases like Multiple Sclerosis on Earth.
original_title: Delayed Maturation of Oligodendrocyte Progenitors by Microgravity: Implications for Multiple Sclerosis and Space Flight

title: Space Microgravity Alters Neural Stem Cell Division: Implications for Brain Cancer Research on Earth and in Space
abstract: Considering the imminence of long-term space travel, it is necessary to investigate the impact of space microgravity (SPC-µG) in order to determine if this environment has consequences on the astronauts’ health, in particular, neural and cognitive functions. Neural stem cells (NSCs) are the basis for the regeneration of the central nervous system (CNS) cell populations and learning how weightlessness impacts NSCs in health and disease provides a critical tool for the potential mitigation of specific mechanisms leading to neurological disorders. In previous studies, we found that exposure to SPC-µG resulted in enhanced proliferation, a shortened cell cycle, and a larger cell diameter of NSCs compared to control cells. Here, we report the frequent occurrence of abnormal cell division (ACD) including incomplete cell division (ICD), where cytokinesis is not successfully completed, and multi-daughter cell division (MDCD) of NSCs following SPC-µG as well as secretome exposure compared to ground control (1G) NSCs. These findings provide new insights into the potential health implications of space travel and have far-reaching implications for understanding the mechanisms leading to the deleterious effects of long-term space travel as well as potential carcinogenic susceptibility. Knowledge of these mechanisms could help to develop preventive or corrective measures for successful long-term SPC-µG exposure.
summary: This study investigated the impact of space microgravity (SPC-µG) on neural stem cell (NSC) division, aiming to understand consequences for astronaut neurological and cognitive health. The research found that SPC-µG exposure, and even secretome exposure, led to the frequent occurrence of abnormal cell division (ACD), including incomplete cell division (ICD) and multi-daughter cell division (MDCD) of NSCs, compared to ground control cells. These findings offer critical insights into potential health implications of long-term space travel, specifically concerning mechanisms leading to neurological disorders and carcinogenic susceptibility, which could inform preventive measures.
impact: Scientifically, this publication significantly advances our understanding of how microgravity profoundly alters fundamental cellular processes, specifically neural stem cell division, by identifying precise abnormalities like incomplete cytokinesis. Practically, these findings are crucial for assessing and mitigating health risks for astronauts on long-duration space missions, particularly regarding neurological health and potential cancer development, and could lead to the development of specific countermeasures. Broader implications include new perspectives for terrestrial research into brain cancer and cell regeneration, leveraging microgravity as a unique experimental condition to uncover underlying cellular mechanisms.
original_title: Space Microgravity Alters Neural Stem Cell Division: Implications for Brain Cancer Research on Earth and in Space

title: Oligodendrocyte Progenitors Display Enhanced Proliferation and Autophagy after Space Flight
abstract: Intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visual impairment intracranial pressure (VIIP) are some of the consequences of long-term space missions. Here we examined the behavior of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs) after space flight using time-lapse microscopy. We show that most OLPs divided more than ground control (GC) counterparts did. Nonetheless, a subpopulation of OLPs flown to space presented a significant increase in autophagic cell death. Examination of the proteomic profile of the secretome of space flown OLPs (SPC-OLPs) revealed that the stress protein heat shock protein-90 beta “HSP-90β” was the 5th most enriched (6.8 times) and the secreted protein acidic and rich in cysteine “SPARC” was the 7th most enriched (5.2 times), with respect to ground control cells. SPARC induces endoplasmic reticulum stress, which leads to autophagy. Given the roles and importance of these two proteins in mammalian cells’ metabolism, their upregulation may hold the key to modulating cell proliferation and autophagy, in order to mitigate ICP and VIIP during and after space missions.
summary: This study investigated the behavior of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs) after space flight, revealing that most OLPs exhibited enhanced proliferation compared to ground controls, while a subpopulation showed a significant increase in autophagic cell death. Proteomic analysis of space-flown OLP secretome identified heat shock protein-90 beta (HSP-90β) as 6.8 times enriched (5th) and secreted protein acidic and rich in cysteine (SPARC) as 5.2 times enriched (7th). These findings suggest that modulating the upregulation of HSP-90β and SPARC could be crucial for mitigating intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visual impairment intracranial pressure (VIIP) during long-duration space missions.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of how specific brain cell progenitors respond to the space environment, particularly concerning proliferation and autophagy, and links these responses to critical astronaut health issues like ICP and VIIP. The identification of key proteins like HSP-90β and SPARC provides potential targets for developing countermeasures to mitigate these neurological complications, directly benefiting the health and safety of astronauts on long-term missions. Furthermore, these insights into cellular stress responses in extreme environments could have broader implications for understanding neurological disorders or stress-induced cellular changes in terrestrial contexts.
theme: Microgravity Effects on Neurological Cell Biology
original_title: Oligodendrocyte Progenitors Display Enhanced Proliferation and Autophagy after Space Flight

title: Metabolomics Profile of the Secretome of Space-Flown Oligodendrocytes
abstract: Intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visual impairment intracranial pressure (VIIP) are some of the sequels of long-term space missions. Here we sought to determine how space microgravity (µG) impacts the metabolomics profile of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs), the myelin-forming cells in the central nervous system. We report increased glutamate and energy metabolism while the OLPs were in space for 26 days. We also show that after space flight, OLPs (SPC OLPs) display significantly increased mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis. These data are in agreement with our previous work using simulated microgravity. In addition, our global metabolomics approach allowed for the discovery of endogenous metabolites secreted by OLPs while in space that are significantly modulated by microgravity. Our results provide, for the first time, relevant information about the energetic state of OLPs while in space and after space flight. The functional and molecular relevance of these specific pathways are promising targets for therapeutic intervention for humans in long-term space missions to the moon, Mars and beyond.
summary: This study investigated how space microgravity (µG) impacts the metabolomics profile of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs), the myelin-forming cells linked to intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visual impairment intracranial pressure (VIIP) in long-term space missions. Key findings revealed increased glutamate and energy metabolism in OLPs during 26 days in space, with significantly enhanced mitochondrial respiration and glycolysis post-flight, along with the discovery of microgravity-modulated endogenous secreted metabolites. These results provide novel insights into OLP energetic states in space and suggest promising therapeutic targets for humans undertaking long-duration missions to the Moon, Mars, and beyond.
impact: Scientifically, this publication significantly advances our understanding of microgravity's effects on the cellular energetics of myelin-forming oligodendrocyte progenitors, validating previous simulated microgravity findings with actual spaceflight data through a global metabolomics approach. Practically, it identifies promising metabolic pathways and targets for developing countermeasures against conditions like ICP and VIIP, directly benefiting astronaut health during long-term missions. Broader implications include informing future research into neurological health in space and potentially offering insights into oligodendrocyte function for terrestrial applications.
original_title: Metabolomics profile of the secretome of space-flown oligodendrocytes.

title: Metabolomic Profiling of the Secretome from Human Neural Stem Cells Flown into Space
abstract: The change in gravitational force has a significant effect on biological tissues and the entire organism. As with any alteration in the environment, microgravity (µG) produces modifications in the system inducing adaptation to the new condition. In this study, we analyzed the effect of µG on neural stem cells (NSCs) following a space flight to the International Space Station (ISS). After 3 days in space, analysis of the metabolome in culture medium revealed increased glycolysis with augmented pyruvate and glycerate levels, and activated catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) and glutamine. NSCs flown into space (SPC-NSCs) also showed increased synthesis of NADH and formation of polyamine spermidine when compared to ground controls (GC-NSCs). Overall, the space environment appears to increase energy demands in response to the µG setting.
summary: This study investigated the metabolomic changes in the secretome of human neural stem cells (NSCs) after 3 days of spaceflight on the International Space Station (ISS) to understand microgravity's effects. Key findings revealed increased glycolysis with augmented pyruvate and glycerate levels, activated catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) and glutamine, and increased NADH synthesis and polyamine spermidine formation in space-flown NSCs compared to ground controls. These metabolic alterations suggest that the microgravity environment significantly elevates the energy demands of neural stem cells.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of how human neural stem cells metabolically adapt to microgravity, providing crucial insights into cellular stress responses in space. The findings on increased energy demands and specific metabolic pathway alterations have practical implications for assessing astronaut health, potentially informing the development of targeted countermeasures for neurological well-being during long-duration space missions. This work contributes to the broader field of space medicine by identifying key biological responses to the space environment, guiding future research into specific metabolic pathways under microgravity conditions.
theme: Microgravity Effects on Neural Stem Cell Metabolism
original_title: Metabolomic profiling of the secretome from human neural stem cells flown into space.

title: Paving the way to better understand the effects of prolonged spaceflight on operational performance and its neural bases
abstract: Space exploration objectives will soon move from low Earth orbit to distant destinations like Moon and Mars. The present work provides an up-to-date roadmap that identifies critical research gaps related to human behavior and performance in altered gravity and space. The roadmap summarizes (1) key neurobehavioral challenges associated with spaceflight, (2) the need to consider sex as a biological variable, (3) the use of integrative omics technologies to elucidate mechanisms underlying changes in the brain and behavior, and (4) the importance of understanding the neural representation of gravity throughout the brain and its multisensory processing. We then highlight the need for a variety of target-specific countermeasures, and a personalized administration schedule as two critical strategies for mitigating potentially adverse effects of spaceflight on the central nervous system and performance. We conclude with a summary of key priorities for the roadmaps of current and future space programs and stress the importance of new collaborative strategies across agencies and researchers for fostering an integrative cross- and transdisciplinary approach from cells, molecules to neural circuits and cognitive performance. Finally, we highlight that space research in neurocognitive science goes beyond monitoring and mitigating risks in astronauts but could also have significant benefits for the population on Earth.
headings: Priorities for the space program (microgravity and/or exploration relevance)
summary: This roadmap identifies critical research gaps concerning human behavior and operational performance during prolonged spaceflight and in altered gravity, emphasizing key neurobehavioral challenges, the need to consider sex as a biological variable, integrative omics technologies, and the neural representation of gravity. It highlights the importance of target-specific and personalized countermeasures to mitigate adverse effects on the central nervous system and performance. The work concludes with key priorities for future space programs, stressing collaborative, transdisciplinary approaches and noting potential benefits for the population on Earth.
impact: This publication provides a scientifically significant roadmap, advancing the understanding of neurobehavioral challenges in space by identifying critical research gaps and proposing integrated approaches, including omics technologies and considering sex as a biological variable. Practically, it guides future space missions by informing the development of personalized countermeasures crucial for astronaut health and operational performance during deep-space exploration. Broader implications include potential terrestrial benefits and a strong call for new collaborative strategies across agencies and researchers to foster a transdisciplinary approach in neurocognitive science.
original_title: Strategies, research priorities, and challenges for the exploration of space beyond low-Earth orbit

title: Spaceflight Induces Specific Alterations in the Proteomes of Arabidopsis
abstract: Life in spaceflight demonstrates remarkable acclimation processes within the specialized habitats of vehicles subjected to the myriad of unique environmental issues associated with orbital trajectories. To examine the response processes that occur in plants in space, leaves and roots from Arabidopsis (Arabidopsis thaliana) seedlings from three GFP reporter lines that were grown from seed for 12 days on the International Space Station and preserved on orbit in RNAlater were returned to Earth and analyzed by using iTRAQ broad-scale proteomics procedures. Using stringent criteria, we identified over 1500 proteins, which included 1167 leaf proteins and 1150 root proteins we were able to accurately quantify. Quantification revealed 256 leaf proteins and 358 root proteins that showed statistically significant differential abundance in the spaceflight samples compared to ground controls, with few proteins differentially regulated in common between leaves and roots. This indicates that there are measurable proteomics responses to spaceflight and that the responses are organ-specific. These proteomics data were compared with transcriptome data from similar spaceflight samples, showing that there is a positive but limited relationship between transcriptome and proteome regulation of the overall spaceflight responses of plants. These results are discussed in terms of emergence understanding of plant responses to spaceflight particularly with regard to cell wall remodeling, as well as in the context of deriving multiple omics data sets from a single on-orbit preservation and operations approach.
summary: This study investigated the proteomic responses of *Arabidopsis* seedlings grown for 12 days on the International Space Station to understand plant acclimation to spaceflight. Using iTRAQ proteomics, researchers identified over 1500 proteins, finding that 256 leaf proteins and 358 root proteins exhibited statistically significant differential abundance compared to ground controls, with responses being organ-specific. The findings contribute to understanding plant responses to spaceflight, particularly cell wall remodeling, and highlighted a positive but limited relationship between transcriptome and proteome regulation.
impact: This publication significantly advances scientific understanding of plant biology in space by detailing organ-specific proteomic responses to spaceflight, showing that 256 leaf and 358 root proteins were differentially regulated. This knowledge is critical for designing future long-duration space missions, improving plant-based life support systems, and potentially developing strategies to enhance plant resilience in extraterrestrial environments. Furthermore, the methodology for integrated multi-omics data collection from a single preservation approach offers valuable insights for future space biology research.
original_title: Spaceflight Induces Specific Alterations in the Proteomes of Arabidopsis

title: The effect of spaceflight on the gravity-sensing auxin gradient of roots: GFP reporter gene microscopy on orbit
abstract: Our primary aim was to determine whether gravity has a direct role in establishing the auxin-mediated gravity-sensing system in primary roots. Major plant architectures have long been thought to be guided by gravity, including the directional growth of the primary root via auxin gradients that are then disturbed when roots deviate from the vertical as a gravity sensor. However, experiments on the International Space Station (ISS) now allow physical clarity with regard to any assumptions regarding the role of gravity in establishing fundamental root auxin distributions. We examined the spaceflight green fluorescent protein (GFP)-reporter gene expression in roots of transgenic lines of Arabidopsis thaliana: pDR5r::GFP, pTAA1::TAA1–GFP, pSCR::SCR–GFP to monitor auxin and pARR5::GFP to monitor cytokinin. Plants on the ISS were imaged live with the Light Microscopy Module (LMM), and compared with control plants imaged on the ground. Preserved spaceflight and ground control plants were examined post flight with confocal microscopy. Plants on orbit, growing in the absence of any physical reference to the terrestrial gravity vector, displayed typically “vertical” distribution of auxin in the primary root. This confirms that the establishment of the auxin-gradient system, the primary guide for gravity signaling in the root, is gravity independent. The cytokinin distribution in the root tip differs between spaceflight and the ground controls, suggesting spaceflight-induced features of root growth may be cytokinin related. The distribution of auxin in the gravity-sensing portion of the root is not dependent on gravity. Spaceflight appears benign to auxin and its role in the development of the primary root tip, whereas spaceflight may influence cytokinin-associated processes.
summary: This study investigated whether gravity directly establishes the auxin-mediated gravity-sensing system in plant primary roots. Utilizing GFP reporter genes in *Arabidopsis thaliana* on the International Space Station and ground controls, the researchers discovered that plants in space displayed a typical "vertical" auxin distribution in their primary roots, confirming the gravity-independence of the auxin-gradient system. Conversely, the distribution of cytokinin in the root tip varied significantly between spaceflight and ground controls, suggesting that spaceflight may influence cytokinin-associated processes.
impact: This research provides a fundamental scientific advance by definitively demonstrating that the establishment of the critical auxin gradient in plant roots, essential for gravity sensing, is independent of gravity. The use of live GFP reporter imaging on the ISS represents a robust methodological contribution to space biology, offering crucial insights for designing effective plant growth systems and understanding crop development for future long-duration space missions. Furthermore, the observed differences in cytokinin distribution highlight new areas for investigating plant physiological responses to microgravity, potentially impacting terrestrial agricultural strategies under stressful conditions.
original_title: The effect of spaceflight on the gravity-sensing auxin gradient of roots: GFP reporter gene microscopy on orbit.

title: Skewing in Arabidopsis roots involves disparate environmental signaling pathways
abstract:
Background
Skewing root patterns provide key insights into root growth strategies and mechanisms that produce root architectures. Roots exhibit skewing and waving when grown on a tilted, impenetrable surface. The genetics guiding these morphologies have been examined, revealing that some Arabidopsis ecotypes skew and wave (e.g. WS), while others skew insignificantly but still wave (e.g. Col-0). The underlying molecular mechanisms of skewing and waving remain unclear. In this study, transcriptome data were derived from two Arabidopsis ecotypes, WS and Col-0, under three tilted growth conditions in order to identify candidate genes involved in skewing.
Results
This work identifies a number of genes that are likely involved in skewing, using growth conditions that differentially affect skewing and waving. Comparing the gene expression profiles of WS and Col-0 in different tilted growth conditions identified 11 candidate genes as potentially involved in the control of skewing. These 11 genes are involved in several different cellular processes, including sugar transport, salt signaling, cell wall organization, and hormone signaling.
Conclusions
This study identified 11 genes whose change in expression level is associated with root skewing behavior. These genes are involved in signaling and perception, rather than the physical restructuring of root. Future work is needed to elucidate the potential role of these candidate genes during root skewing.
summary: This study aimed to identify candidate genes involved in root skewing by analyzing transcriptome data from two Arabidopsis ecotypes (WS and Col-0) under three tilted growth conditions. It successfully identified 11 candidate genes associated with root skewing, which are involved in various cellular processes including sugar transport, salt signaling, cell wall organization, and hormone signaling. The findings suggest that these genes contribute to signaling and perception mechanisms underlying root skewing, rather than just physical restructuring, warranting further investigation into their specific roles.
impact: This research significantly advances the scientific understanding of molecular mechanisms governing root architecture and mechanosensing, particularly root skewing and waving, in a key model plant. For space biology, this fundamental plant physiology work is crucial for optimizing plant growth and resilience in controlled environments, such as those on the International Space Station or future planetary habitats. Beyond space applications, these insights contribute to broader agricultural and ecological understanding of root development and adaptation to diverse soil conditions.
original_title: Skewing in Arabidopsis roots involves disparate environmental signaling pathways.

title: Data for characterization of SALK_084889, a T-DNA insertion line of Arabidopsis thaliana
abstract: In this article we report the identification of T-DNA (transfer DNA) insertion sites within two different gene regions in the genome of an Arabidopsis mutant line, SALK_084889. The T-DNA positions are in the 3′ UTR (untranslated region) of DREB2A (Dehydration-responsive element-binding protein 2A) (AT5G05410) and promoter of LOX1 (Lipoxygenase 1) (AT1G55020) as determined by DNA-PCR and sanger sequencing. The expression levels of DREB2A and LOX1 were also analyzed using quantitative realtime PCR (qPCR) in SALK_084889 and wild type Arabidopsis (Col, Columbia). Further, the comparison of drought and heat tolerance between Col and SALK_084889 were conducted by stress treatments. The present data indicate that in SALK_084889, the expression of DREB2A is not downregulated under normal growth conditions but can be affected only in roots under drought treatment, while LOX1 is significantly downregulated in both roots and shoots under all tested conditions. These data are original and have not been published elsewhere.
summary: This study characterized the *Arabidopsis thaliana* T-DNA insertion line SALK_084889, identifying insertions in the 3′ UTR of DREB2A (AT5G05410) and the promoter of LOX1 (AT1G55020). Key findings indicate DREB2A expression was not downregulated under normal conditions but was affected in roots under drought treatment, while LOX1 was significantly downregulated in both roots and shoots under all tested conditions. This data provides foundational insights into gene regulation and stress tolerance mechanisms in this specific *Arabidopsis* mutant.
impact: Scientifically, this publication contributes foundational data to plant functional genomics, detailing how specific T-DNA insertions affect gene expression and stress responses in *Arabidopsis*. For space biology, understanding plant resilience to environmental stressors like drought and heat is crucial for developing robust plant systems for life support and food production in extreme conditions of long-duration space missions. The findings also have broader implications for enhancing crop resilience in terrestrial agriculture and guiding future research into plant adaptation and genetic engineering for both Earth and space environments.
theme: Plant Biology: Genetic Characterization and Stress Response
original_title: Data for characterization of SALK_084889, a T-DNA insertion line of Arabidopsis thaliana

title: Genetic dissection of the Arabidopsis spaceflight transcriptome: Are some responses dispensable for the physiological adaptation of plants to spaceflight?
abstract: Experimentation on the International Space Station has reached the stage where repeated and nuanced transcriptome studies are beginning to illuminate the structural and metabolic differences between plants grown in space compared to plants on the Earth. Genes that are important in establishing the spaceflight responses are being identified, their roles in spaceflight physiological adaptation are increasingly understood, and the fact that different genotypes adapt differently is recognized. However, the basic question of whether these spaceflight responses are actually required for survival has yet to be posed, and the fundamental notion that spaceflight responses may be non-adaptive has yet to be explored. Therefore the experiments presented here were designed to ask if portions of the plant spaceflight response can be genetically removed without causing loss of spaceflight survival and without causing increased stress responses. The CARA experiment compared the spaceflight transcriptome responses in the root tips of two Arabidopsis ecotypes, Col-0 and WS, as well as that of a PhyD mutant of Col-0. When grown with the ambient light of the ISS, phyD plants displayed a significantly reduced spaceflight transcriptome response compared to Col-0, suggesting that altering the activity of a single gene can actually improve spaceflight adaptation by reducing the transcriptome cost of physiological adaptation. The WS genotype showed an even simpler spaceflight transcriptome response in the ambient light of the ISS, more broadly indicating that the plant genotype can be manipulated to reduce the cost of spaceflight adaptation, as measured by transcriptional response. These differential genotypic responses suggest that genetic manipulation could further reduce, or perhaps eliminate the metabolic cost of spaceflight adaptation. When plants were germinated and then left in the dark on the ISS, the WS genotype actually mounted a larger transcriptome response than Col-0, suggesting that the in-space light environment affects physiological adaptation, which implies that manipulating the local habitat can also substantially impact the metabolic cost of spaceflight adaptation.
summary: This study investigated whether specific plant spaceflight responses are essential for survival or are non-adaptive, genetically dissecting the Arabidopsis spaceflight transcriptome. Key findings revealed that altering a single gene (phyD mutant) significantly reduced the spaceflight transcriptome response in Col-0, and the WS genotype showed an even simpler response in ambient ISS light, suggesting genetic manipulation can reduce adaptation costs. Conversely, WS exhibited a larger transcriptome response in the dark, indicating the light environment also impacts metabolic cost.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of plant physiological adaptation to spaceflight by demonstrating that not all transcriptional responses may be necessary for survival, opening new avenues for optimizing plant growth in extraterrestrial environments. The findings suggest practical applications for future space missions, enabling the genetic engineering of plants for more efficient resource utilization and reduced stress responses, which could improve in-situ resource production. Broader implications include informing plant breeding strategies for enhanced resilience and resource efficiency in various terrestrial stress conditions.
original_title: Genetic dissection of the Arabidopsis spaceflight transcriptome: Are some responses dispensable for the physiological adaptation of plants to spaceflight?

title: Phenotypic characterization of an Arabidopsis T-DNA insertion line SALK_063500
abstract: In this article we report the identification of a homozygous lethal T-DNA (transfer DNA) line within the coding region of the At1G05290 gene in the genome of Arabidopsis thaliana (Arabidopsis) line, SALK_063500. The T-DNA insertion is found within exon one of the AT1G05290 gene, however a homozygous T-DNA allele is unattainable. In the heterozygous T-DNA allele the expression levels of AT1G05290 were compared to wild type Arabidopsis (Col-0, Columbia). Further analyses revealed an aberrant silique phenotype found in the heterozygous SALK_063500 plants that is attributed to the reduced rate of pollen tube germination. These data are original and have not been published elsewhere.
summary: This study identified a homozygous lethal T-DNA insertion within exon one of the AT1G05290 gene in the Arabidopsis line SALK_063500, making homozygous T-DNA alleles unattainable. Heterozygous SALK_063500 plants exhibited reduced AT1G05290 expression compared to wild type (Col-0) and displayed an aberrant silique phenotype. This abnormal silique development was attributed to a reduced rate of pollen tube germination, providing original data on the gene's role in plant development.
impact: Scientifically, this research advances our understanding of plant gene function and development, specifically highlighting the critical role of AT1G05290 in pollen tube germination and subsequent silique formation in *Arabidopsis*. While a fundamental plant biology study, insights into plant genetic lethalities and reproductive biology are valuable for model plant systems like *Arabidopsis*, which are often used in NASA's space biology research to understand plant growth and reproduction in altered gravity environments. This knowledge could indirectly inform strategies for plant cultivation in controlled ecological life support systems during long-duration space missions or contribute to agricultural advancements on Earth.
original_title: Phenotypic characterization of an Arabidopsis T- DNA insertion line SALK_063500

title: Utilization of single‐image normalized difference vegetation index (SI‐NDVI) for early plant stress detection
abstract:
Premise of the Study

An imaging system was refined to monitor the health of vegetation grown in controlled conditions using spectral reflectance patterns. To measure plant health, the single‐image normalized difference vegetation index (SI‐NDVI) compares leaf reflectance in visible and near‐infrared light spectrums.

Methods and Results

The SI‐NDVI imaging system was characterized to assess plant responses to stress before visual detection during controlled stress assays. Images were analyzed using Fiji image processing software and Microsoft Excel to create qualitative false color images and quantitative graphs to detect plant stress.

Conclusions

Stress was detected in Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings within 15 min of salinity application using SI‐NDVI analysis, before stress was visible. Stress was also observed during ammonium nitrate treatment of Eruca sativa plants before visual detection. Early detection of plant stress is possible using SI‐NDVI imaging, which is both simpler to use and more cost efficient than traditional dual‐image NDVI or hyper‐spectral imaging.
headings: Appendix 1. Benchside protocol for development and use of the single‐image normalized difference vegetation index (SI‐NDVI) imager in controlled plant stress assays.
summary: This study refined an imaging system utilizing single-image normalized difference vegetation index (SI-NDVI) to monitor plant health in controlled conditions by analyzing spectral reflectance patterns for early stress detection. The SI-NDVI system successfully detected stress in Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings within 15 minutes of salinity application and in Eruca sativa plants during ammonium nitrate treatment, both before visual detection. This method offers a simpler and more cost-efficient approach for early plant stress detection compared to traditional dual-image NDVI or hyper-spectral imaging.
impact: Scientifically, this work significantly advances the methodology for non-invasive, early plant stress detection, providing a more accessible and cost-effective tool for plant health assessment in controlled environments. Its practical application for NASA Space Biology is substantial, enabling timely intervention to maintain plant-based life support systems and food production on missions like the ISS or future lunar/Martian habitats. Terrestrially, it has broad implications for optimizing crop management in greenhouses and controlled agriculture, potentially improving resource efficiency and yields.
original_title: Utilization of single‚Äêimage normalized difference vegetation index (SI‚ÄêNDVI) for early plant stress detection

title: Comparing RNA‐Seq and microarray gene expression data in two zones of the Arabidopsis root apex relevant to spaceflight
abstract:
Premise of the Study

The root apex is an important region involved in environmental sensing, but comprises a very small part of the root. Obtaining root apex transcriptomes is therefore challenging when the samples are limited. The feasibility of using tiny root sections for transcriptome analysis was examined, comparing RNA sequencing (RNA‐Seq) to microarrays in characterizing genes that are relevant to spaceflight.

Methods

Arabidopsis thaliana Columbia ecotype (Col‐0) roots were sectioned into Zone 1 (0.5 mm; root cap and meristematic zone) and Zone 2 (1.5 mm; transition, elongation, and growth‐terminating zone). Differential gene expression in each was compared.

Results

Both microarrays and RNA‐Seq proved applicable to the small samples. A total of 4180 genes were differentially expressed (with fold changes of 2 or greater) between Zone 1 and Zone 2. In addition, 771 unique genes and 19 novel transcriptionally active regions were identified by RNA‐Seq that were not detected in microarrays. However, microarrays detected spaceflight‐relevant genes that were missed in RNA‐Seq.

Discussion

Single root tip subsections can be used for transcriptome analysis using either RNA‐Seq or microarrays. Both RNA‐Seq and microarrays provided novel information. These data suggest that techniques for dealing with small, rare samples from spaceflight can be further enhanced, and that RNA‐Seq may miss some spaceflight‐relevant changes in gene expression.
summary: This study compared RNA-Seq and microarrays for transcriptome analysis of tiny Arabidopsis root apex sections, seeking genes relevant to spaceflight. Both techniques were applicable, identifying 4180 differentially expressed genes between root zones. RNA-Seq uniquely identified 771 genes and 19 novel transcriptionally active regions, yet microarrays detected some spaceflight-relevant genes missed by RNA-Seq, suggesting complementary utility for limited spaceflight samples.
impact: This research significantly advances methodology for transcriptome analysis of limited biological samples, crucial for spaceflight experiments on plants. The finding that microarrays uniquely detect some spaceflight-relevant genes is critical for designing future space biology studies and ensuring comprehensive data collection in microgravity. The work has direct implications for optimizing genetic studies in space and could inform similar analyses of rare or tiny samples in terrestrial plant research.
original_title: Comparing RNA-Seq and microarray gene expression data in two zones of the Arabidopsis root apex relevant to spaceflight.

title: Spaceflight-induced alternative splicing during seedling development in Arabidopsis thaliana
abstract: Plants grown in spaceflight experience novel environmental signals, including those associated with microgravity and ionizing radiation. Spaceflight triggers a response involving transcriptional re-programming and altered cell morphology, though many aspects of this response remain uncharacterized. We analyzed the spaceflight-induced transcriptome with a focus on genes that undergo alternative splicing to examine differential splicing associated with spaceflight—an unstudied characteristic of the molecular response to spaceflight exposure. RNA sequence data obtained during the APEX03 spaceflight experiment that was collected from two Arabidopsis thaliana ecotypes at two seedling stages grown onboard the International Space Station, or as ground controls at Kennedy Space Center, were re-examined to detect alternative splicing differences induced by spaceflight. Presence/absence variation analysis was used to identify putative expression-level differences in alternatively spliced isoforms between spaceflight and ground controls and was followed by analysis of significant differential alternative splicing. This study provides the first evidence of a role for alternative splicing in the molecular processes of physiological adaptation to the spaceflight environment.
summary: This study aimed to characterize spaceflight-induced alternative splicing in *Arabidopsis thaliana* seedlings, a previously unstudied aspect of the molecular response to spaceflight. Using RNA sequence data from the APEX03 experiment conducted on the International Space Station, researchers re-examined two *Arabidopsis thaliana* ecotypes at two seedling stages to detect differential splicing compared to ground controls. The key finding is the first evidence demonstrating a role for alternative splicing in the molecular processes of physiological adaptation to the spaceflight environment.
impact: This research significantly advances scientific understanding by identifying alternative splicing as a novel molecular mechanism underlying plant adaptation to spaceflight, filling a critical knowledge gap in space biology. Practically, these findings are vital for developing strategies to support plant growth in long-duration space missions, contributing to controlled ecological life support systems and potential space agriculture. Broader implications include informing future investigations into how terrestrial plants respond to extreme environmental stressors and guiding future research into genetic and genomic mechanisms of adaptation in altered gravity environments.
original_title: Spaceflight-induced alternative splicing during seedling development in Arabidopsis thaliana.

title: Biomass Production of the EDEN ISS Space Greenhouse in Antarctica During the 2018 Experiment Phase
abstract: The EDEN ISS greenhouse is a space-analog test facility near the German Neumayer III station in Antarctica. The facility is part of the project of the same name and was designed and built starting from March 2015 and eventually deployed in Antarctica in January 2018. The nominal operation of the greenhouse started on February 7th and continued until the 20th of November. The purpose of the facility is to enable multidisciplinary research on topics related to future plant cultivation on human space exploration missions. Research on food quality and safety, plant health monitoring, microbiology, system validation, human factors and horticultural sciences was conducted. Part of the latter is the determination of the biomass production of the different crops. The data on this topic is presented in this paper. During the first season 26 different crops were grown on the 12.5 m2 cultivation area of the greenhouse. A large number of crops were grown continuously throughout the 9 months of operation, but there were also crops that were only grown a few times for test purposes. The focus of this season was on growing lettuce, leafy greens and fresh vegetables. In total more than 268 kg of edible biomass was produced by the EDEN ISS greenhouse facility in 2018. Most of the harvest was cucumbers (67 kg), lettuces (56 kg), leafy greens (49 kg), and tomatoes (50 kg) complemented with smaller amounts of herbs (12 kg), radish (8 kg), and kohlrabi (19 kg). The environmental set points for the crops were 330–600 μmol/(m2*s) LED light, 21°C, ∼65% relative humidity, 1000 ppm and the photoperiod was 17 h per day. The overall yearly productivity of the EDEN ISS greenhouse in 2018 was 27.4 kg/m2, which is equal to 0.075 kg/(m2*d). This paper shows in detail the data on edible and inedible biomass production of each crop grown in the EDEN ISS greenhouse in Antarctica during the 2018 season.
summary: This study determined the biomass production of 26 different crops grown in the EDEN ISS greenhouse, a space-analog test facility in Antarctica, during its first 9-month operation in 2018. The facility produced over 268 kg of edible biomass from its 12.5 m2 cultivation area, with major contributions from cucumbers (67 kg), lettuces (56 kg), leafy greens (49 kg), and tomatoes (50 kg). The overall yearly productivity was 27.4 kg/m2, demonstrating the potential for plant cultivation in extreme environments to support future human space exploration missions.
impact: This research provides critical empirical data on crop yields and productivity rates in a controlled environment agriculture (CEA) system under space-analog conditions, significantly advancing the scientific understanding of bio-regenerative life support systems (BLSS). Practically, these findings are invaluable for designing and validating plant cultivation systems for future long-duration space missions, ensuring food security and astronaut health beyond Earth. The study's detailed biomass production data also has broader implications for sustainable food production in harsh terrestrial environments and informs future research into optimizing plant growth parameters for space applications.
theme: Plant Biology for Space Life Support Systems
original_title: The Plant Health Monitoring System of the EDEN ISS Space Greenhouse in Antarctica during the 2018 experiment phase

title: Root Skewing-Associated Genes Impact the Spaceflight Response of Arabidopsis thaliana
abstract: The observation that plant roots skew in microgravity recently refuted the long-held conviction that skewing was a gravity-dependent phenomenon. Further, spaceflight root skewing suggests that specific root morphologies and cell wall remodeling systems may be important aspects of spaceflight physiological adaptation. However, connections between skewing, cell wall modification and spaceflight physiology are currently based on inferences rather than direct tests. Therefore, the Advanced Plant Experiments-03-2 (APEX-03-2) spaceflight study was designed to elucidate the contribution of two skewing- and cell wall-associated genes in Arabidopsis to root behavior and gene expression patterns in spaceflight, to assess whether interruptions of different skewing pathways affect the overall spaceflight-associated process. SPIRAL1 is a skewing-related protein implicated in directional cell expansion, and functions by regulating cortical microtubule dynamics. SKU5 is skewing-related glycosylphosphatidylinositol-anchored protein of the plasma membrane and cell wall implicated in stress response signaling. These two genes function in different cellular pathways that affect skewing on the Earth, and enable a test of the relevance of skewing pathways to spaceflight physiological adaptation. In this study, both sku5 and spr1 mutants showed different skewing behavior and markedly different patterns of gene expression in the spaceflight environment. The spr1 mutant showed fewer differentially expressed genes than its Col-0 wild-type, whereas sku5 showed considerably more than its WS wild-type. Developmental age played a substantial role in spaceflight acclimation in all genotypes, but particularly in sku5 plants, where spaceflight 4d seedlings had almost 10-times as many highly differentially expressed genes as the 8d seedlings. These differences demonstrated that the two skewing pathways represented by SKU5 and SPR1 have unique and opposite contributions to physiological adaptation to spaceflight. The spr1 response is less intense than wild type, suggesting that the loss of SPR1 positively impacts spaceflight adaptation. Conversely, the intensity of the sku5 responses suggests that the loss of SKU5 initiates a much more complex, deeper and more stress related response to spaceflight. This suggests that proper SKU5 function is important to spaceflight adaptation.
summary: This study investigated how two root skewing-associated genes, SPIRAL1 (spr1) and SKU5 (sku5), impact *Arabidopsis thaliana* root behavior and gene expression during spaceflight. It found that spr1 mutants exhibited fewer differentially expressed genes than wild-type, suggesting positive adaptation, while sku5 mutants showed considerably more differentially expressed genes, indicating a more complex and stress-related response. Notably, 4d sku5 seedlings had almost 10-times more highly differentially expressed genes than 8d seedlings, demonstrating that these two pathways contribute uniquely and oppositely to physiological adaptation to spaceflight.
impact: This research significantly advances our scientific understanding of plant adaptation to spaceflight by directly linking specific genetic pathways (`SPR1` and `SKU5`) to root morphology, cell wall remodeling, and gene expression in microgravity. Practically, identifying genes that enhance or hinder adaptation provides valuable targets for genetic engineering to improve crop resilience and efficiency for long-duration space missions and advanced life support systems. The insights into plant stress responses and developmental acclimation also have broader implications for improving plant adaptation to challenging abiotic environments on Earth.
original_title: Root skewing-associated genes impact the spaceflight response of Arabidopsis thaliana.

title: Articular cartilage and sternal fibrocartilage respond differently to extended microgravity
abstract: The effects of spaceflight on cartilaginous structure are largely unknown. To address this deficiency, articular cartilage (AC) and sternal cartilage (SC) from mice exposed to 30 days of microgravity on the BION-M1 craft were investigated for pathological changes. The flight AC showed some evidence of degradation at the tissue level with loss of proteoglycan staining and a reduction in mRNA expression of mechano-responsive and structural cartilage matrix proteins compared to non-flight controls. These data suggest that degradative changes are underway in the AC extracellular matrix exposed to microgravity. In contrast, there was no evidence of cartilage breakdown in SC flight samples and the gene expression profile was distinct from that of AC with a reduction in metalloproteinase gene transcription. Since the two cartilages respond differently to microgravity we propose that each is tuned to the biomechanical environments in which they are normally maintained. That is, the differences between magnitude of normal terrestrial loading and the unloading of microgravity dictates the tissue response. Weight-bearing articular cartilage, but not minimally loaded sternal fibrocartilage, is negatively affected by the unloading of microgravity. We speculate that the maintenance of physiological loading on AC during spaceflight will minimize AC damage.
summary: This study investigated the effects of 30 days of microgravity on articular cartilage (AC) and sternal cartilage (SC) in mice, aiming to understand pathological changes in cartilaginous structures during spaceflight. It found that weight-bearing AC showed evidence of degradation, including proteoglycan loss and reduced expression of structural cartilage proteins, while minimally loaded SC exhibited no breakdown and a distinct gene expression profile with reduced metalloproteinase transcription. These findings suggest that the specific biomechanical environment and magnitude of normal loading dictate a cartilage's response to microgravity, implying that maintaining physiological loading on AC during spaceflight is crucial to minimize damage.
impact: This publication significantly advances the scientific understanding of how different cartilages respond to microgravity, highlighting the vulnerability of weight-bearing articular cartilage to unloading, a previously unknown area. Practically, these findings are critical for astronaut health, providing a basis for developing countermeasures focused on maintaining physiological loading to prevent cartilage degradation during long-duration space missions. The research also has broader implications for understanding cartilage mechanobiology in terrestrial conditions of unloading and informs future research into targeted interventions for cartilage health.
original_title: Articular cartilage and sternal fibrocartilage respond differently to extended microgravity.

title: Host-Microbe Interactions in Microgravity: Assessment and Implications
abstract: Spaceflight imposes several unique stresses on biological life that together can have a profound impact on the homeostasis between eukaryotes and their associated microbes. One such stressor, microgravity, has been shown to alter host-microbe interactions at the genetic and physiological levels. Recent sequencing of the microbiomes associated with plants and animals have shown that these interactions are essential for maintaining host health through the regulation of several metabolic and immune responses. Disruptions to various environmental parameters or community characteristics may impact the resiliency of the microbiome, thus potentially driving host-microbe associations towards disease. In this review, we discuss our current understanding of host-microbe interactions in microgravity and assess the impact of this unique environmental stress on the normal physiological and genetic responses of both pathogenic and mutualistic associations. As humans move beyond our biosphere and undergo longer duration space flights, it will be essential to more fully understand microbial fitness in microgravity conditions in order to maintain a healthy homeostasis between humans, plants and their respective microbiomes.
headings: 3. Impact of Microgravity on Animal-Microbe Associations
4. Impact of Microgravity on Plant-Microbe Associations
summary: This review assesses the current understanding of how microgravity, a unique spaceflight stressor, alters host-microbe interactions at genetic and physiological levels in both pathogenic and mutualistic associations involving animals and plants. It highlights that disruptions to these interactions can drive host-microbe associations towards disease. The publication concludes that understanding microbial fitness in microgravity is essential for maintaining healthy host-microbiome homeostasis during future long-duration human space flights.
impact: This publication significantly advances scientific understanding by synthesizing current knowledge on microgravity's influence on the complex interplay between hosts and their microbiomes, covering genetic and physiological alterations in both pathogenic and mutualistic relationships. Its practical implications are critical for ensuring astronaut health and plant viability during long-duration space missions, informing strategies for maintaining host homeostasis in extreme environments. Broader implications extend to guiding future space biology research to develop effective countermeasures for disease prevention beyond Earth.
original_title: Host-microbe interactions in microgravity: assessment and implications.

title: Environmental cues and symbiont microbe-associated molecular patterns function in concert to drive the daily remodelling of the crypt-cell brush border of the Euprymna scolopes light organ
