original_title: Genes required for survival in microgravity revealed by genome-wide yeast deletion collections cultured during spaceflight.

title: Physical Forces Modulate Oxidative Status and Stress Defense Meditated Metabolic Adaptation of Yeast Colonies: Spaceflight and Microgravity Simulations
abstract: Baker’s yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) has broad genetic homology to human cells. Although typically grown as 1-2mm diameter colonies under certain conditions yeast can form very large (10 + mm in diameter) or ‘giant’ colonies on agar. Giant yeast colonies have been used to study diverse biomedical processes such as cell survival, aging, and the response to cancer pharmacogenomics. Such colonies evolve dynamically into complex stratified structures that respond differentially to environmental cues. Ammonia production, gravity driven ammonia convection, and shear defense responses are key differentiation signals for cell death and reactive oxygen system pathways in these colonies. The response to these signals can be modulated by experimental interventions such as agar composition, gene deletion and application of pharmaceuticals. In this study we used physical factors including colony rotation and microgravity to modify ammonia convection and shear stress as environmental cues and observed differences in the responses of both ammonia dependent and stress response dependent pathways We found that the effects of random positioning are distinct from rotation. Furthermore, both true and simulated microgravity exacerbated both cellular redox responses and apoptosis. These changes were largely shear-response dependent but each model had a unique response signature as measured by shear stress genes and the promoter set which regulates them These physical techniques permitted a graded manipulation of both convection and ammonia signaling and are primed to substantially contribute to our understanding of the mechanisms of drug action, cell aging, and colony differentiation.
summary: This study investigated how physical factors, including colony rotation and microgravity, modulate ammonia convection and shear stress in giant yeast colonies to affect ammonia-dependent and stress response pathways. Findings showed that random positioning effects are distinct from rotation, and both true and simulated microgravity exacerbated cellular redox responses and apoptosis. These changes were largely shear-response dependent, offering a graded manipulation of signaling relevant to understanding drug action, cell aging, and colony differentiation.
impact: Scientifically, this research advances understanding of how microgravity and shear stress influence cellular stress responses and metabolic adaptation in complex biological systems, using yeast as a model for human cells. The findings have practical applications for astronaut health by shedding light on mechanisms of redox imbalances and apoptosis in spaceflight, potentially aiding in the development of countermeasures. Broader implications include insights into drug action, aging, and colony differentiation, with relevance to both space and terrestrial biomedical research.
original_title: Physical Forces Modulate Oxidative Status and Stress Defense Meditated Metabolic Adaptation of Yeast Colonies: Spaceflight and Microgravity Simulations

title: Effects of Space Flight on Mouse Liver versus Kidney: Gene Pathway Analyses
abstract: Understanding genome wide, tissue-specific, and spaceflight-induced changes in gene expression is critical to develop effective countermeasures. Transcriptome analysis has been performed on diverse tissues harvested from animals flown in space, but not the kidney. We determined the genome wide gene expression using a gene array analysis of kidney and liver tissue from mice flown in space for 12 days versus ground based control animals. By comparing the transcriptome of liver and kidney from animals flown in space versus ground control animals, we tested a unique hypothesis: Are there common gene expression pathways activated in multiple tissue types in response to spaceflight stimuli? Although there were tissue-specific changes, both liver and kidney overexpressed genes in the same four areas: (a) cellular responses to peptides, hormones, and nitrogen/organonitrogen compounds; (b) apoptosis and cell death; (c) fat cell differentiation and (d) negative regulation of protein kinase.
summary: This study investigated genome-wide gene expression changes in mouse liver and kidney after 12 days of spaceflight using gene array analysis, aiming to identify common spaceflight-induced gene pathways across tissues. Despite observing tissue-specific alterations, both organs significantly overexpressed genes in four common areas: cellular responses to peptides/hormones, apoptosis/cell death, fat cell differentiation, and negative regulation of protein kinase. These findings are critical for understanding systemic physiological responses to spaceflight and developing effective countermeasures.
impact: This research significantly advances space biology by being the first to perform transcriptome analysis on mouse kidney following spaceflight, alongside liver tissue, and identifying shared gene expression pathways. Pinpointing these four common pathways (e.g., apoptosis, cellular responses) provides fundamental insights into systemic biological responses to microgravity, which is crucial for developing broad-spectrum countermeasures to protect astronaut health during long-duration space missions. The involvement of NASA authors and publication in a reputable journal (Int J Mol Sci.) underscores its scientific rigor and practical relevance for future human space exploration.
theme: Microgravity Effects on Organ Gene Expression and Genomics
original_title: Effects of space flight on mouse liver versus kidney: Gene pathway analyses.

title: Cryptococcus albidus meningitis: A case report and literature review
abstract:
Rationale:
Central nervous system (CNS) infections caused by Cryptococcus albidus are rarely reported, but are often associated with high mortality rates. Clinical data on the appropriate use of liposomal-amphotericin B (liposomal-AmB) with cryptococcal meningitis are limited. Here, we report for the first time the efficacious and safe use of the ideal bodyweight to calculate the dose of liposomal-AmB for a severely obese patient with C albidus meningitis. We also review the cases of CNS infection caused by C albidus and its related species.
Patient concerns:
A severely obese female patient was admitted to neurosurgical ward with lesions in the intracranial space and accompanying headache. Brain magnetic resonance imaging revealed prominent lesions in the right parietal and left frontal insular region. After glioma resection, C albidus was isolated from her cerebrospinal fluid samples.
Diagnoses, interventions, and outcomes:
She diagnosed histopathologically with a Cryptococcus species infection. The culture from her cerebrospinal fluid sample showed the growth of yeast-like colonies, which were identified as C albidus with mass spectrometry. She was treated with liposomal-AmB (50 mg day-1 intravenously) plus 5-fluorocytosine (10 g day-1 orally in 4 divided doses) for 6 weeks. The patient was asymptomatic at the time of discharge.
Lessons:
CNS infections of C albidus were uncommon. Using ideal bodyweight to calculate the dose of liposomal-AmB should be considered for severely obese patients with C albidus meningitis.
summary: This case report details the successful treatment of a rare Cryptococcus albidus meningitis in a severely obese female patient who presented with intracranial lesions and headache. Following diagnosis via cerebrospinal fluid culture and mass spectrometry, the patient was effectively treated with a 6-week regimen of liposomal-amphotericin B (50 mg day-1 intravenously) and 5-fluorocytosine (10 g day-1 orally in 4 divided doses), becoming asymptomatic at discharge. The study highlights the efficacy of this treatment and proposes considering ideal bodyweight for calculating liposomal-amphotericin B dosage in severely obese patients with this condition.
impact: Scientifically, this publication provides valuable clinical evidence on the management of a rare central nervous system fungal infection, contributing to the limited data on Cryptococcus albidus meningitis and its treatment in complex patient populations. While not directly addressing space missions, understanding fungal infection management and drug dosing in altered physiological states or challenging patient types could indirectly inform medical protocols for astronaut health and countermeasures against infections. Terrestrially, the findings offer a practical recommendation for liposomal-amphotericin B dosing in severely obese patients, potentially improving clinical outcomes and guiding future research into pharmacokinetics in this specific population.
original_title: Yeast in Space

title: Behavioral and multiomics analysis of 3D clinostat simulated microgravity effect in mice focusing on the central nervous system
abstract: A study was conducted to evaluate the three-dimensional clinostat simulated microgravity effect on mouse models, focusing on the central nervous system. Eighteen mice were divided into three groups: control, survival box, and clinostat + survival box. Behavioral tests, femur micro-CT, brain transcriptomics, serum metabolomics, and fecal microbiomics were performed. Results showed decreased activity, altered gait, enhanced fear memory, bone loss, immune/endocrine changes in brain transcriptome, and altered metabolic pathways in serum and gut microbiota in clinostat-treated mice. The model closely mimics spaceflight-induced transcriptome changes, suggesting its value in studying microgravity-related neurological alterations and highlighting the need for attention to emotional changes in space.
summary: This study evaluated the effects of 3D clinostat simulated microgravity on mouse models, specifically focusing on the central nervous system. Researchers observed decreased activity, altered gait, enhanced fear memory, bone loss, and changes in brain transcriptome (immune/endocrine pathways), serum metabolomics, and gut microbiota in treated mice. The findings suggest the 3D clinostat model accurately mimics spaceflight-induced transcriptome changes, making it valuable for studying microgravity-related neurological alterations and underscoring the importance of addressing emotional changes in space.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of microgravity's impact on the central nervous system by validating the 3D clinostat as a relevant model for spaceflight effects. Its practical applications include informing astronaut health strategies, particularly concerning mental and emotional well-being during long-duration space missions, and guiding the development of potential countermeasures. Broader implications involve identifying specific neurological pathways affected by altered gravity, paving the way for targeted future research into mechanisms and interventions.
theme: Microgravity Effects on the Central Nervous System and Behavior
original_title: Endocrine Effects of Space Flight

title: Three-Dimensional Kidney-on-a-Chip Assessment of Contrast-Induced Kidney Injury: Osmolality and Viscosity
abstract: Increased viscosity of concentrated contrast media (CM) in the renal tubules can perturb renal hemodynamics and have a detrimental effect on tubular epithelial cells. However, the effects of viscosity on contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) remain poorly understood. Conventional in vitro culture studies do not reflect the rheological properties of CM. Therefore, we investigated the effects of CM viscosity on renal tubules using a kidney-on-a-chip and two different types of CM. Renal proximal tubule epithelial cells (RPTEC) were cultured in a three-dimensional microfluidic culture platform under bidirectional fluid shear stress. We treated the RPTEC with two types of CM: low- (LOCM, iopromide) and iso-osmolar contrast media (IOCM, iodixanol). Renal tubular cell injury induced by LOCM and IOCM was examined under different iodine concentrations (50–250 mgI/mL) and shear-stress conditions. LOCM showed a significant dose-dependent cytotoxic effect, which was significantly higher than that of IOCM under static and low-to-moderate shear stress conditions. However, high shear-stress resulted in reduced cell viability in IOCM; no difference between IOCM and LOCM was found under high shear-stress conditions. The cytotoxic effects were pronounced at a mean shear stress of 1 dyn/cm2 or higher. The high viscosity of IOCM slowed the fluid flow rate and augmented fluid shear-stress. We suggest an alternative in vitro model of CIN using the three-dimensional kidney-on-a-chip. Our results indicate a vital role of viscosity-induced nephrotoxicity under high shear-stress conditions, contrary to the findings of conventional in vitro studies.
summary: This study investigated the effects of contrast media (CM) osmolality and viscosity on contrast-induced kidney injury (CIN) using a 3D kidney-on-a-chip model under bidirectional fluid shear stress. Researchers found that low-osmolar CM (LOCM) had a significant dose-dependent cytotoxic effect from 50–250 mgI/mL, which was higher than iso-osmolar CM (IOCM) under static to moderate shear. Crucially, under high shear stress (1 dyn/cm² or higher), IOCM also caused reduced cell viability with no difference from LOCM, highlighting a vital role of viscosity-induced nephrotoxicity not observed in conventional in vitro studies and proposing an improved CIN model.
impact: This publication significantly advances the scientific understanding of contrast-induced nephropathy by demonstrating the critical role of contrast media viscosity and fluid shear stress using a novel 3D kidney-on-a-chip model. This methodology offers a more physiologically relevant in vitro system than conventional models, providing a superior platform for studying drug-induced kidney injury. While directly applicable to terrestrial medical practices for optimizing contrast media selection and patient care, this technology development aligns with NASA Space Biology's interest in developing advanced, compact human physiology models for studying disease mechanisms, drug efficacy, and astronaut health risks in resource-limited space environments.
theme: Technology Development: Organ-on-a-Chip for Kidney Health
original_title: Role of shear stress on renal proximal tubular cells for nephrotoxicity assays

title: The Effect of Different Concentrations of Epinephrine in Otoendoscopic Surgery on Surgical Field Clarity: A Double-Blind, Randomized Study
abstract:
Importance
At present, there is no consensus on the concentration of epinephrine/physiological saline for subcutaneous injection into external auditory canal (EAC) under general anesthesia in otoendoscopic surgery. A randomized controlled trial (RCT) research is needed to provide reference, as this concentration can provide satisfactory surgical field clarity while maintaining patients’ hemodynamic stability.

Objective
Comparison of the effect of subcutaneous injection of different concentrations of epinephrine/physiological saline into EAC under general anesthesia in otoendoscopic surgery on surgical field clarity and hemodynamics.

Design
This double-blind, RCT study was about the effect of topical epinephrine injection in otoendoscopic surgery.

Setting
This study was conducted at a single institution.

Participants
This study included 168 patients conformed to the inclusion criteria.

Intervention
Patients were randomized to receive different concentrations of epinephrine/physiological saline injection (1:5000, 1:10,000, 1:20,000, or 1:40,000) into the junction of bone and cartilage at posterior wall of EAC during surgery.

Main Outcome Measures
Surgical field clarity was assessed with surgical field clarity grading scale and tympanic membrane flap flipping time. Hemodynamic changes were monitored by clinical parameters of blood pressure, heart rate, and ST segment of ECG.

Results
There were no statistically-significant differences in surgical field clarity grade (P = .577) and tympanic membrane flap flipping time (P = .490) among 4 concentration groups. Epinephrine injection did cause an increase in hemodynamic parameters when compared with baseline (P < .05). Compared with the relatively-lower concentration groups (1:20,000 and 1:40,000), the relatively-higher concentration groups (1:5000 and 1:10,000) had more significant and long-lasting effect until 30 minutes after injection.

Conclusions and relevance
Four concentration groups of topical epinephrine injection in otoendoscopic surgery have the same effect on surgical field clarity. For the stability of patients’ hemodynamics, we would prefer to recommend the use of concentrations with minimal impact on hemodynamics, ranging from 1:20,000 to 1:40,000.
summary: This double-blind, randomized controlled trial investigated the effect of four different epinephrine concentrations (1:5000, 1:10,000, 1:20,000, 1:40,000) injected into the external auditory canal during otoendoscopic surgery on surgical field clarity and patient hemodynamics. The study found no statistically significant differences in surgical field clarity (P=.577 for clarity grade, P=.490 for flipping time) among the groups. However, higher concentrations (1:5000, 1:10,000) caused more significant and long-lasting hemodynamic changes than lower concentrations (1:20,000, 1:40,000), leading to the recommendation of 1:20,000 to 1:40,000 concentrations for better hemodynamic stability.
impact: This study fills a clinical gap by providing evidence-based recommendations for optimal epinephrine concentration in otoendoscopic surgery, directly improving patient safety by guiding practices to maintain hemodynamic stability during procedures. While its direct application is terrestrial otolaryngology, the rigorous double-blind, randomized controlled trial design demonstrates a robust methodology for evaluating pharmacological interventions and physiological responses, which could inform similar studies in controlled, extreme environments. The recommendation for 1:20,000 to 1:40,000 concentrations will directly influence surgical protocols, aiming to reduce adverse hemodynamic events and enhance post-operative recovery for a common procedure.
theme: Health Monitoring: Hemodynamic Stability during Surgery
original_title: Bone hemodynamic responses to changes in external pressure.

title: From the international space station to the clinic: how prolonged unloading may disrupt lumbar spine stability
abstract:
BACKGROUND CONTEXT:

Prolonged microgravity exposure is associated with localized low back pain and an elevated risk of post-flight disc herniation. Although the mechanisms by which microgravity impairs the spine are unclear, they should be foundational for developing in-flight countermeasures for maintaining astronaut spine health. Because human spine anatomy has adapted to upright posture on Earth, observations of how spaceflight affects the spine should also provide new and potentially important information on spine biomechanics that benefit the general population.

PURPOSE:

This study compares quantitative measures of lumbar spine anatomy, health, and bio-mechanics in astronauts before and after 6 months of microgravity exposure on board the International Space Station (ISS).

STUDY DESIGN:

This is a prospective longitudinal study.

SAMPLE:

Six astronaut crewmember volunteers from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) with 6-month missions aboard the ISS comprised our study sample.

OUTCOME MEASURES:

For multifidus and erector spinae at L3–L4, measures include cross-sectional area (CSA), functional cross-sectional area (FCSA), and FCSA/CSA. Other measures include supine lumbar lordosis (L1–S1), active (standing) and passive (lying) flexion-extension range of motion (FE ROM) for each lumbar disc segment, disc water content from T2-weighted intensity, Pfirrmann grade, vertebral end plate pathology, and subject-reported incidence of chronic low back pain or disc injuries at 1-year follow-up.

METHODS:

3T magnetic resonance imaging and dynamic fluoroscopy of the lumbar spine were collected for each subject at two time points: approximately 30 days before launch (pre-flight) and 1 day following 6 months spaceflight on the ISS (post-flight). Outcome measures were compared between time points using paired t tests and regression analyses.

RESULTS:

Supine lumbar lordosis decreased (flattened) by an average of 11% (p=.019). Active FE ROM decreased for the middle three lumbar discs (L2–L3: −22.1%, p=.049; L3–L4: −17.3%, p=.016; L4–L5: −30.3%, p=.004). By contrast, no significant passive FE ROM changes in these discs were observed (p>.05). Disc water content did not differ systematically from pre- to post-flight. Multifidus and erector spinae changed variably between subjects, with five of six subjects experiencing an average decrease 20% for FCSA and 8%–9% for CSA in both muscles. For all subjects, changes in multifidus FCSA strongly correlated with changes in lordosis (r2=0.86, p=.008) and active FE ROM at L4–L5 (r2=0.94, p=.007). Additionally, changes in multifidus FCSA/CSA correlated with changes in lordosis (r2=0.86, p=.03). Although multifidus-associated changes in lordosis and ROM were present among all subjects, only those with severe, pre-flight end plate irregularities (two of six subjects) had post-flight lumbar symptoms (including chronic low back pain or disc herniation).

CONCLUSIONS:

We observed that multifidus atrophy, rather than intervertebral disc swelling, associated strongly with lumbar flattening and increased stiffness. Because these changes have been previously linked with detrimental spine biomechanics and pain in terrestrial populations, when combined with evidence of pre-flight vertebral end plate insufficiency, they may elevate injury risk for astronauts upon return to gravity loading. Our results also have implications for deconditioned spines on Earth. We anticipate that our results will inform new astronaut countermeasures that target the multifidus muscles, and research on the role of muscular stability in relation to chronic low back pain and disc injury. © 2017 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
summary: This prospective longitudinal study investigated lumbar spine anatomy and biomechanics in six astronauts before and after 6 months on the ISS. Key findings revealed an average 11% decrease in supine lumbar lordosis (p=.019) and significant reductions in active flexion-extension range of motion for middle lumbar discs (e.g., L4–L5: -30.3%, p=.004). Multifidus functional cross-sectional area decreased by an average of 20% in five of six subjects, with this atrophy strongly correlating with lumbar flattening (r2=0.86, p=.008) and increased stiffness, suggesting multifidus atrophy, not disc swelling, as a primary mechanism for microgravity-induced spinal changes.
impact: This research significantly advances scientific understanding of microgravity's impact on spinal stability by identifying multifidus muscle atrophy as a critical factor in lumbar flattening and increased stiffness, challenging previous hypotheses. Practically, these findings are crucial for developing targeted in-flight countermeasures to maintain astronaut spine health and mitigate the elevated risk of post-flight low back pain and disc herniation. The study also provides new insights into terrestrial spine biomechanics for deconditioned populations and informs future research on muscular stability's role in chronic low back pain.
theme: Microgravity Effects on Bone & Muscle Health
original_title: Back pain in space and post-flight spine injury: Mechanisms and countermeasure development

title: Fifteen Days Microgravity Causes Growth in Calvaria of Mice
abstract: Bone remodeling may occur in spaceflight as a response to skeletal unloading and head-ward fluid shifts. While unloading causes significant loss of bone mass and density in legs of animals exposed to microgravity, increased blood and interstitial fluid flows accompanying microgravity-induced fluid redistribution may elicit an opposite effect in the head. Seven C57BL/6 mice were randomly chosen for exposure to 15 days of microgravity on the STS-131 mission, while eight littermates served as ground controls. Upon mission completion, all 15 mice calvariae were imaged on a micro-computed tomography scanner. A standardized rectangular volume was placed on the parietal bones of each calvaria for analyses, and three parameters were determined to measure increased parietal bone volume: bone volume (BV), cross-sectional thickness (CsTh), and tissue mineral density (TMD). Microgravity exposure caused a statistically significant increase in BV of the space flight (SF) group compared to the ground control (GC) group – the mean ± SD for SF group was 10.48 ± 0.47 %, compared to 9.64 ± 0.79 % for GC group (p<0.05). CsTh demonstrated a trend of increase from 0.099 ±0.006 mm in the GC group to 0.104 ±0.005 mm in the SF group (p=0.12). TMD was similar between the two groups with 0.878 ±0.029 g/cc for GC and 0.893 ± 0.028 g/cc for SF (p=0.31). Our results indicate that microgravity causes adaptive changes in calvarial bones that do not normally bear weight. These findings suggest that fluid shifts alone accompanying microgravity may initiate bone remodeling independent of skeletal loading by tissue.
summary: This study investigated the effects of 15 days of microgravity on calvarial bone remodeling in mice, hypothesizing that head-ward fluid shifts might induce growth. Researchers found a statistically significant increase in bone volume (BV) in spaceflight mice (10.48 ± 0.47 %) compared to ground controls (9.64 ± 0.79 %, p<0.05). These results suggest that microgravity-induced fluid shifts alone can initiate adaptive bone remodeling in non-weight-bearing bones, independent of skeletal loading.
impact: This research significantly advances understanding of skeletal adaptation in space by demonstrating that microgravity-induced fluid shifts can cause bone growth in non-weight-bearing skull bones, rather than just loss in limbs. This finding is crucial for developing comprehensive countermeasures for astronaut health during long-duration space missions, expanding beyond traditional focuses on weight-bearing bone loss. It also opens new avenues for investigating the role of fluid dynamics in bone remodeling in both space and terrestrial contexts.
original_title: Fifteen days of microgravity causes growth in calvaria of mice

title: Altered Disc Compression in Children with Idiopathic Low Back Pain: An Upright MRI Backpack Study
abstract:
Study Design

This study is a repeated measures design to measure the lumbar spine’s response to common backpack loads in children with idiopathic low back pain (ILBP) using upright MRI.

Objective

The purpose of this study is to analyze the lumbar spine’s response to backpack loads with upright MRI in ILBP children in order to compare their results to previously published normal child data under the same conditions. We hypothesize that typical backpack loads will have a different effect on the lumbar spine of normal and ILBP children.

Summary of Background Data

Research in normal children shows that backpack loads compress the lumbar IVDs, increase lumbar coronal deformity, and increase pain.

Methods

Fifteen pediatric and adolescent patients with ILBP were selected. Patients were excluded if a spinal deformity, an underlying pathology, or known injury was identified. A 0.6T upright MRI scanner imaged the subjects while supine and standing wearing 0 kg, 4 kg, and 8 kg backpacks. IVD height, lumbar lordosis, lumbar coronal deformity, and pain score were recorded after each condition and compared using ANOVAs. We compared the above variables between ILBP and normal subjects using generalized least squares models.

Results

The cohort’s mean age was 13 ± 3 years. The 4 kg and 8 kg backpacks only compressed the L5-S1 IVD relative to upright with no load. Subjects experienced increasing pain with increasing load. Load had no effect on lumbar lordosis or lumbar coronal deformity. Compared to normal children, ILBP children experience significantly less disc compression at T12-L1 to L4-5, less lumbar lordosis, and more pain with increasing load.

Conclusions

In ILBP children, increasing backpack load compresses only the L5-S1 IVD. Compared to normal children, ILBP children experience less lumbar IVD compression, less lumbar lordosis, and more pain due to increasing load suggesting altered mechanisms for load tolerance in ILBP children.
summary: This study utilized upright MRI to compare lumbar spine response to backpack loads (0, 4, and 8 kg) in 15 children (mean age 13 ± 3 years) with idiopathic low back pain (ILBP) versus normal children. ILBP subjects experienced disc compression only at the L5-S1 intervertebral disc and increasing pain with load, unlike normal children where compression typically occurs across multiple levels. Compared to normal controls, ILBP children exhibited significantly less disc compression at T12-L1 to L4-5, less lumbar lordosis, and more pain with increasing load, suggesting altered load tolerance mechanisms.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of altered spinal biomechanics in pediatric idiopathic low back pain (ILBP) by quantifying differential disc compression and pain responses to varying loads using an advanced upright MRI methodology. While primarily focused on a terrestrial health issue, the study's insights into spinal load tolerance and disc health are relevant to understanding human adaptation to altered gravity environments and the biomechanical stresses experienced by astronauts. The findings contribute directly to improving diagnosis and management of ILBP in children, and the methodological approach has implications for future investigations into spinal resilience under varying mechanical loads, including those related to spaceflight and rehabilitation.
original_title: Altered disc compression in children with idiopathic low back pain: an upright magnetic resonance imaging backpack study

title: Spaceflight-Induced Bone Loss Alters Failure Mode and Reduces Bending Strength in Murine Spinal Segments
abstract: Intervertebral disc herniation rates are quadrupled in astronauts following spaceflight. While bending motions are main contributors to herniation, the effects of microgravity on the bending properties of spinal discs are unknown. Consequently, the goal of this study was to quantify the bending properties of tail discs from mice with or without microgravity exposure. Caudal motion segments from six mice returned from a 30-day Bion M1 mission and eight vivarium controls were loaded to failure in four-point bending. After testing, specimens were processed using histology to determine the location of failure, and adjacent motion segments were scanned with micro-computed tomography (μCT) to quantify bone properties. We observed that spaceflight significantly shortened the nonlinear toe region of the force-displacement curve by 32% and reduced the bending strength by 17%. Flight mouse spinal segments tended to fail within the growth plate and epiphyseal bone, while controls tended to fail at the disc-vertebra junction. Spaceflight significantly reduced vertebral bone volume fraction, bone mineral density, and trabecular thickness, which may explain the tendency of flight specimens to fail within the epiphyseal bone. Together, these results indicate that vertebral bone loss during spaceflight may degrade spine bending properties and contribute to increased disc herniation risk in astronauts.
summary: This study aimed to quantify the bending properties of tail discs from mice exposed to 30-day spaceflight, addressing the quadrupled intervertebral disc herniation rates in astronauts. Key findings show that spaceflight significantly shortened the nonlinear toe region of the force-displacement curve by 32% and reduced bending strength by 17%. Furthermore, flight specimens tended to fail within the growth plate and epiphyseal bone, correlating with significant reductions in vertebral bone volume fraction, bone mineral density, and trabecular thickness. These results suggest that spaceflight-induced vertebral bone loss degrades spine bending properties and contributes to increased disc herniation risk in astronauts.
impact: Scientifically, this research advances understanding of how microgravity affects spinal biomechanics, specifically elucidating the link between spaceflight-induced bone loss and altered failure modes and reduced strength in spinal segments. Practically, these findings are critical for assessing astronaut health, informing the development of targeted countermeasures to mitigate spinal degradation and intervertebral disc herniation risk during future long-duration space missions. Broader implications extend to terrestrial research, providing insights into bone-related spine pathologies and disc degeneration mechanisms.
theme: Microgravity Effects on Spinal Bone Health
original_title: Spaceflight-induced bone loss alters failure mode and reduces bending strength in murine spinal segments.

title: Spaceflight-Associated Vascular Remodeling and Gene Expression in Mouse Calvaria
abstract: Astronauts suffer from a loss of bone mass at a rate of 1.5% per month from lower regions of the body during the course of long-duration (>30 days) spaceflight, a phenomenon that poses important risks for returning crew. Conversely, a gain in bone mass may occur in non-load bearing regions of the body as related to microgravity-induced cephalad fluid shift. Representing non-load bearing regions with mouse calvaria and leveraging the STS-131 (15-day) and BION-M1 (30-day) flights, we examined spatial and temporal calvarial vascular remodeling and gene expression related to microgravity exposure compared between spaceflight (SF) and ground control (GC) cohorts. We examined parasagittal capillary numbers and structures in calvaria from 16 to 23 week-old C57BL/6 female mice (GC, n = 4; SF, n = 5) from STS-131 and 19–20 week-old C57BL/6 male mice (GC, n = 6; SF, n = 6) from BION-M1 using a robust isolectin-IB4 vessel marker. We found that the vessel diameter reduces significantly in mice exposed to 15 days of spaceflight relative to control. Capillarization increases by 30% (SF vs. GC, p = 0.054) in SF mice compared to GC mice. The vessel numbers and diameter remain unchanged in BION-M1 mice calvarial section. We next analyzed the parietal pro-angiogenic (VEGFA) and pro-osteogenic gene (BMP-2, DMP1, RUNX2 and OCN) expression in BION-M1 mice using quantitative RT-PCR. VEGFA gene expression increased 15-fold while BMP-2 gene expression increased 11-fold in flight mice compared to GC. The linkage between vascular morphology and gene expression in the SF conditions suggests that angiogenesis may be important in the regulation of pathological bone growth in non-weight bearing regions of the body. Short-duration microgravity-mediated bone restructuring has implications in planning effective countermeasures for long-duration flights and extraterrestrial human habitation.
summary: This study investigated spatial and temporal calvarial vascular remodeling and gene expression in mouse calvaria during 15-day (STS-131) and 30-day (BION-M1) spaceflights to understand microgravity's effects on non-load bearing bone. Key findings include a significant reduction in vessel diameter and a 30% increase in capillarization (p=0.054) after 15 days, alongside a 15-fold increase in VEGFA and an 11-fold increase in BMP-2 gene expression after 30 days. This research suggests angiogenesis is critical for pathological bone growth in non-weight bearing regions, with implications for countermeasure development in long-duration space missions and extraterrestrial habitation.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of microgravity's complex effects on bone, specifically by linking vascular remodeling and gene expression in non-load bearing regions and highlighting the role of angiogenesis. Practically, these findings are crucial for developing effective countermeasures to mitigate bone restructuring risks during long-duration spaceflight and future human habitation beyond Earth. The insights into angiogenesis's role in bone adaptation under microgravity may also inform terrestrial research on vascular-bone interactions in various physiological and pathological conditions.
original_title: Spaceflight-associated vascular remodeling and gene expression in mouse calvaria.

title: Exposure of Mycobacterium marinum to low-shear modeled microgravity: effect on growth, the transcriptome and survival under stress
abstract: Waterborne pathogenic mycobacteria can form biofilms, and certain species can cause hard-to-treat human lung infections. Astronaut health could therefore be compromised if the spacecraft environment or water becomes contaminated with pathogenic mycobacteria. This work uses Mycobacterium marinum to determine the physiological changes in a pathogenic mycobacteria grown under low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG). M. marinum were grown in high aspect ratio vessels (HARVs) using a rotary cell culture system subjected to LSMMG or the control orientation (normal gravity, NG) and the cultures used to determine bacterial growth, bacterium size, transcriptome changes, and resistance to stress. Two exposure times to LSMMG and NG were examined: bacteria were grown for ~40 h (short), or 4 days followed by re-dilution and growth for ~35 h (long). M. marinum exposed to LSMMG transitioned from exponential phase earlier than the NG culture. They were more sensitive to hydrogen peroxide but showed no change in resistance to gamma radiation or pH 3.5. RNA-Seq detected significantly altered transcript levels for 562 and 328 genes under LSMMG after short and long exposure times, respectively. Results suggest that LSMMG induced a reduction in translation, a downregulation of metabolism, an increase in lipid degradation, and increased chaperone and mycobactin expression. Sigma factor H (sigH) was the only sigma factor transcript induced by LSMMG after both short and long exposure times. In summary, transcriptome studies suggest that LSMMG may simulate a nutrient-deprived environment similar to that found within macrophage during infection. SigH is also implicated in the M. marinum LSMMG transcriptome response.
summary: This study investigated the physiological changes in pathogenic *Mycobacterium marinum* grown under low-shear modeled microgravity (LSMMG) to assess potential risks to astronaut health. Key findings revealed that LSMMG-exposed bacteria transitioned from exponential phase earlier, were more sensitive to hydrogen peroxide, and exhibited significantly altered transcript levels for 562 genes (short exposure) and 328 genes (long exposure). These transcriptomic changes suggest LSMMG simulates a nutrient-deprived environment, with implications for *M. marinum* pathogenesis.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of how pathogenic bacteria, specifically *M. marinum*, adapt to microgravity-like conditions at a molecular level, utilizing transcriptome analysis to identify specific gene regulation. The findings have direct practical implications for astronaut health by informing strategies to mitigate risks from waterborne mycobacterial contamination in spacecraft environments. Furthermore, the insights into nutrient deprivation and gene expression, including the role of Sigma factor H, could aid in developing terrestrial treatments for hard-to-treat lung infections by shedding light on bacterial survival strategies within hosts.
original_title: Exposure of Mycobacterium marinum to low-shear modeled microgravity: Effect on growth, the transcriptome and survival under stress.

title: Effects of mechanostimulation on gravitropism and signal persistence in flax roots
abstract: Gravitropism describes curvature of plants in response to gravity or differential acceleration and clinorotation is commonly used to compensate unilateral effect of gravity. We report on experiments that examine the persistence of the gravity signal and separate mechanostimulation from gravistimulation. Flax roots were reoriented (placed horizontally for 5, 10 or 15 min) and clinorotated at a rate of 0.5 to 5 rpm either vertically (parallel to the gravity vector and root axis) or horizontally (perpendicular to the gravity vector and parallel to the root axis). Image sequences showed that horizontal clinorotation did not affect root growth rate (0.81 ± 0.03 mm h−1) but vertical clinorotation reduced root growth by about 7%. The angular velocity (speed of clinorotation) did not affect growth for either direction. However, maximal curvature for vertical clinorotation decreased with increasing rate of rotation and produced straight roots at 5 rpm. In contrast, horizontal clinorotation increased curvature with increasing angular velocity. The point of maximal curvature was used to determine the longevity (memory) of the gravity signal, which lasted about 120 min. The data indicate that mechanostimulation modifies the magnitude of the graviresponse but does not affect memory persistence.
summary: This study investigated the persistence of the gravity signal and the effects of mechanostimulation on gravitropism in flax roots, aiming to differentiate these responses. Key findings include that horizontal clinorotation did not alter root growth rate (0.81 ± 0.03 mm h⁻¹), whereas vertical clinorotation reduced root growth by about 7%. The longevity of the gravity signal, or 'memory', was determined to last approximately 120 minutes, indicating that mechanostimulation modifies the magnitude of the graviresponse but does not affect its persistence.
impact: This research significantly advances the scientific understanding of plant gravitropism and the distinct roles of gravity versus mechanical stimuli on plant development. Practically, these findings are critical for optimizing plant cultivation and life support systems in altered gravity environments, such as those found on space missions or future extraterrestrial habitats, by better predicting how plants respond to various physical forces. Broader implications extend to improving agricultural practices on Earth by elucidating fundamental mechanisms of plant stress response and development.
original_title: Effects of mechanostimulation on gravitropism and signal persistence in flax roots.

title: Amelioration of the physio-biochemical responses to salinity stress and computing the primary germination index components in cauliflower on seed priming
abstract: The significant horticultural crop, cauliflower (Brassica oleracea L. var. botrytis) is vulnerable to the excessive salt concentration in the soil, which contributes to its scaled-down growth and productivity, among other indices. The current study examines the efficacy of hydropriming, halopriming, and osmopriming on the physio-biochemical attributes and tolerance to salinity (100 mM NaCl) in cauliflower under controlled conditions. The results showed that the salinity (100 mM NaCl) has significant deleterious impacts on cauliflower seed germination, seedling growth, and photosynthetic attributes, and provoked the production of reactive oxygen species. In contrast, different priming approaches proved beneficial in mitigating the negative effects of salinity and boosted the germination, vigor indices, seedling growth, and physio-biochemical attributes like photosynthetic pigments, protein, and proline content while suppressing oxidative damage and MDA content in cauliflower seedlings in treatment- and dose-dependent manner. PCA revealed 61% (PC1) and 15% (PC2) of the total variance with substantial positive relationships and high loading conditions on all germination attributes on PC1 with greater PC1 scores for PEG treatments showing the increased germination indices in PEG-treated seeds among all the priming treatments tested. All 13 distinct priming treatments tried clustered into three groups as per Ward's approach of systematic categorization, clustering the third group showing relatively poor germination performances. Most germination traits exhibited statistically significant associations at the p < 0.01 level. Overall, the results established the usefulness of the different priming approaches facilitating better germination, survival, and resistance against salinity in the cauliflower to be used further before sowing in the salt-affected agro-ecosystems.
summary: This study investigated the efficacy of hydropriming, halopriming, and osmopriming on mitigating salinity stress (100 mM NaCl) in cauliflower. Salinity significantly impaired seed germination, seedling growth, and photosynthetic attributes, while increasing reactive oxygen species; however, various priming approaches successfully ameliorated these negative effects, boosting germination, vigor, and physio-biochemical attributes while reducing oxidative damage. PCA revealed that 61% (PC1) and 15% (PC2) of the total variance were explained, with PEG treatments showing increased germination indices among all tested methods, establishing priming as a useful strategy for enhancing cauliflower's resilience in salt-affected agro-ecosystems.
impact: Scientifically, this study advances knowledge of seed priming as a countermeasure against abiotic stress, detailing physio-biochemical mechanisms and providing statistical validation through PCA (61% PC1, 15% PC2). While focused on terrestrial agriculture, its findings are highly relevant to NASA Space Biology; improving plant resilience to stress, like salinity, is crucial for controlled environment agriculture (CEA) in long-duration space missions and planetary habitats, where resource limitations and environmental stressors are common. Thus, priming techniques could be vital for developing robust bioregenerative life support systems, contributing to both sustainable terrestrial agriculture and future space crop production.
theme: Plant Biology: Stress Resilience & Seed Priming
original_title: Oxygen dependency of germinating Brassica seeds.

title: Desiccation Mitigates Heat Stress in the Resurrection Fern, Pleopeltis polypodioides
abstract: Although heat and desiccation stresses often coincide, the response to heat especially in desiccation tolerant plants is rarely studied. We subjected hydrated Pleopeltis polypodioides fronds to temperatures up to 50°C and dehydrated fronds up to 65°C for 24 h. The effect of heat stress was evaluated using morphological changes, photosystem (PS) II efficiency, and metabolic indicators. Pinnae of dried fronds exposed to more than 40°C curled tighter and became brittle compared to fronds dried at lower temperatures. Exposure to > 50°C leads to discolored fronds after rehydration. Hydrated fronds turned partially brown at > 35°C. Chlorophyll fluorescence (Ft) and quantum yield (Qy) increased following re-hydration but the recovery process after 40°C treatment lasted longer than at lower temperatures. Similarly, hydrated fronds showed reduced Qy when exposed to > 40°C. Dried and hydrated fronds remained metabolically active up to 40°C. Hydroperoxides and lipid hydroperoxides in dried samples remained high up to 50°C, but decreased in hydrated fronds at > 40°C. Catalase (CAT) and glutathione (GSH) oxidizing activities remained high up to 40°C in dehydrated fronds and up to 35°C in hydrated fronds. Major fatty acids detected in both dehydrated and hydrated fronds included palmitic (C16:0) and stearic (C18:0) acids, oleic (18:1), linoleic (C18:2); and linolenic (C18:3) acids. Linolenic acid was most abundant. In dried fronds, all fatty acids decreased at > 35°C. The combined data indicate that the thermotolerance of dry fronds is about 55°C but is at least 10°C lower for hydrated fronds.
summary: This study investigated how desiccation affects heat stress tolerance in the resurrection fern *Pleopeltis polypodioides*. Key findings reveal that desiccation significantly enhances thermotolerance, with dry fronds withstanding temperatures up to 55°C, which is at least 10°C higher than the thermotolerance of hydrated fronds. The research detailed morphological, photosynthetic (PSII efficiency), and metabolic responses, demonstrating desiccation's crucial role in protecting plants under extreme heat conditions.
impact: This research provides significant scientific insight into the mechanisms of combined stress tolerance in extremophilic plants, which is highly relevant for astrobiology and understanding plant survival in harsh environments. The finding that desiccation increases thermotolerance by at least 10°C offers valuable knowledge for developing resilient life support systems or crops for long-duration space missions, as well as for terrestrial applications in climate change adaptation. Published in Front Plant Sci. and supported by NASA Space Biology, it contributes to a deeper understanding of biological resilience critical for future space exploration and environmental challenges.
original_title: Desiccation mitigates heat stress in the resurrection fern, Pleopeltis polypodioides

title: Transcription Profile of Auxin Related Genes during Positively Gravitropic Hypocotyl Curvature of Brassica rapa
abstract: Unlike typical negative gravitropic curvature, young hypocotyls of Brassica rapa and other dicots exhibit positive gravitropism. This positive curvature occurs at the base of the hypocotyl and is followed by the typical negative gravity-induced curvature. We investigated the role of auxin in both positive and negative hypocotyl curvature by examining the transcription of PIN1, PIN3, IAA5 and ARG1 in curving tissue. We compared tissue extraction of the convex and concave flank with Solid Phase Gene Extraction (SPGE). Based on Ubiquitin1 (UBQ1) as a reference gene, the log (2) fold change of all examined genes was determined. Transcription of the examined genes varied during the graviresponse suggesting that these genes affect differential elongation. The transcription of all genes was upregulated in the lower flank and downregulated in the upper flank during the initial downward curving period. After 48 h, the transcription profile reversed, suggesting that the ensuing negative gravicurvature is controlled by the same genes as the positive gravicurvature. High-spatial resolution profiling using SPGE revealed that the transcription profile of the examined genes was spatially distinct within the curving tissue. The comparison of the hypocotyl transcription profile with the root tip indicated that the tip tissue is a suitable reference for curving hypocotyls and that root and hypocotyl curvature are controlled by the same physiological processes.
summary: This study investigated the role of auxin-related genes (PIN1, PIN3, IAA5, ARG1) in the transition from positive to negative gravitropic curvature in *Brassica rapa* hypocotyls. It found that the transcription of all examined genes was initially upregulated in the lower flank and downregulated in the upper flank during positive (downward) curvature, a profile that reversed after 48 hours for the subsequent negative curvature. High-spatial resolution profiling revealed distinct transcription profiles within the curving tissue, suggesting shared physiological processes control root and hypocotyl curvature.
impact: This research significantly advances the scientific understanding of plant gravitropism by elucidating the molecular mechanisms, particularly the role of auxin-related genes, underlying the complex positive-to-negative curvature transition in plant hypocotyls. While primarily fundamental, this work is crucial for understanding how plants perceive and respond to gravity, providing foundational knowledge essential for optimizing plant growth and yield in terrestrial agriculture and for developing sustainable plant-based life support systems for future space missions under altered gravity environments. The use of Solid Phase Gene Extraction (SPGE) also offers a methodological advancement for high-spatial resolution gene expression profiling in plant tissues.
theme: Plant Biology: Gravitropism and Gene Expression
original_title: Transcription profile of auxin related genes during positively gravitropic hypocotyl curvature of Brassica rapa.

title: High-gradient magnetic fields and starch metabolism: results from a space experiment
abstract: Directing plant growth in weightlessness requires understanding the processes that establish plant orientation and how to manipulate them. Both gravi- and phototropism determine directional growth and previous experiments showed that high gradient magnetic fields (HGMF) can induce curvature in roots and shoots. Experiments with Brassica rapa verified that that gravitropism-like induction of curvature is possible in space and that the HGMF-responsive organelles are amyloplasts. We assessed the effect of space and HGMF based on 16 genes and compared their transcription with static growth and clinorotation. Amyloplasts size in root tips increased under weightlessness but decreased under clinorotation but not in response to magnetic fields. Amyloplast size changes were correlated with reduced amylase transcription in space samples and enhanced transcription after clinorotation. Mechanostimulation and weightlessness have opposite effects on the size of amyloplasts. The data show that plants perceive weightlessness, and that their metabolism adjusts to microgravity and mechanostimulation. Thus, clinorotation as surrogate for space research may lead to incorrect interpretations.
summary: This study investigated how high gradient magnetic fields (HGMF) and weightlessness affect plant growth and orientation in Brassica rapa, focusing on amyloplasts and the transcription of 16 genes. Key findings showed that amyloplast size increased under weightlessness but decreased under clinorotation, correlating with reduced and enhanced amylase transcription, respectively, while HGMF could induce curvature in space. The research concludes that plants perceive and adjust their metabolism to weightlessness and mechanostimulation, suggesting clinorotation is an inadequate space surrogate.
impact: This publication significantly advances the understanding of plant gravitropism in microgravity, demonstrating how high-gradient magnetic fields can influence plant orientation and identifying amyloplasts as key mechano-sensing organelles. The findings are crucial for developing strategies to direct plant growth for long-duration space missions and space agriculture, while also cautioning against the sole reliance on clinorotation as a microgravity surrogate. This research opens new avenues for exploring mechanoperception in plants and has potential implications for controlled environment agriculture on Earth and in space.
original_title: High-gradient magnetic fields and starch metabolism: Results from a space experiment.

title: Lipid Rafts and Plant Gravisensitivity
abstract: The necessity to include plants as a component of a Bioregenerative Life Support System leads to investigations to optimize plant growth facilities as well as a better understanding of the plant cell membrane and its numerous activities in the signaling, transport, and sensing of gravity, drought, and other stressors. The cell membrane participates in numerous processes, including endo- and exocytosis and cell division, and is involved in the response to external stimuli. Variable but stabilized microdomains form in membranes that include specific lipids and proteins that became known as (detergent-resistant) membrane microdomains, or lipid rafts with various subclassifications. The composition, especially the sterol-dependent recruitment of specific proteins affects endo- and exo-membrane domains as well as plasmodesmata. The enhanced saturated fatty acid content in lipid rafts after clinorotation suggests increased rigidity and reduced membrane permeability as a primary response to abiotic and mechanical stress. These results can also be obtained with lipid-sensitive stains. The linkage of the CM to the cytoskeleton via rafts is part of the complex interactions between lipid microdomains, mechanosensitive ion channels, and the organization of the cytoskeleton. These intricately linked structures and functions provide multiple future research directions to elucidate the role of lipid rafts in physiological processes.
headings: 4. How Do Lipid Raft Studies Advance the Understanding of the Gravisensitivity of Plant Cells?
summary: This study investigates plant cell membrane activities, particularly the role of lipid rafts, in sensing gravity and stress to optimize plant growth in Bioregenerative Life Support Systems. Key findings indicate that lipid rafts, dynamic membrane microdomains, exhibit enhanced saturated fatty acid content after clinorotation, suggesting increased rigidity and reduced membrane permeability as a primary response to abiotic and mechanical stress. The research highlights complex interactions between lipid microdomains, mechanosensitive ion channels, and the cytoskeleton, providing crucial insights for future research into plant gravisensitivity and physiological processes.
impact: This publication significantly advances the scientific understanding of plant cell membrane dynamics, specifically how lipid rafts mediate mechanosensing and gravisensitivity, providing a molecular basis for plant responses to mechanical and abiotic stress. For NASA, this research is critical for optimizing plant growth in space for Bioregenerative Life Support Systems by unraveling fundamental plant adaptation mechanisms to altered gravity. Broadly, it offers insights into plant stress biology, with implications for improving plant resilience in various environments on Earth and guiding future investigations into plant mechanobiology.
theme: Plant Biology: Gravisensitivity and Microgravity Response
original_title: Lipid rafts and plant gravisensitivity.

title: MscS-Like10 is a stretch-activated ion channel from Arabidopsis thaliana with a preference for anions
abstract: Like many other organisms, plants are capable of sensing and responding to mechanical stimuli such as touch, osmotic pressure, and gravity. One mechanism for the perception of force is the activation of mechanosensitive (or stretch-activated) ion channels, and a number of mechanosensitive channel activities have been described in plant membranes. Based on their homology to the bacterial mechanosensitive channel MscS, the 10 MscS-Like (MSL) proteins of Arabidopsis thaliana have been hypothesized to form mechanosensitive channels in plant cell and organelle membranes. However, definitive proof that MSLs form mechanosensitive channels has been lacking. Here we used single-channel patch clamp electrophysiology to show that MSL10 is capable of providing a MS channel activity when heterologously expressed in Xenopus laevis oocytes. This channel had a conductance of ∼100 pS, consistent with the hypothesis that it underlies an activity previously observed in the plasma membrane of plant root cells. We found that MSL10 formed a channel with a moderate preference for anions, which was modulated by strongly positive and negative membrane potentials, and was reversibly inhibited by gadolinium, a known inhibitor of mechanosensitive channels. MSL10 demonstrated asymmetric activation/inactivation kinetics, with the channel closing at substantially lower tensions than channel opening. The electrophysiological characterization of MSL10 reported here provides insight into the evolution of structure and function of this important family of proteins.
summary: This study definitively demonstrates that MscS-Like10 (MSL10) from *Arabidopsis thaliana* is a stretch-activated ion channel. Using single-channel patch clamp electrophysiology in *Xenopus laevis* oocytes, researchers showed MSL10 forms a channel with ~100 pS conductance, a moderate preference for anions, and sensitivity to membrane potentials and gadolinium. These findings provide crucial insight into the structure and function of this important family of proteins involved in plant mechanosensation.
impact: Scientifically, this publication provides critical, definitive evidence for MSL10's role as a mechanosensitive channel, advancing our fundamental understanding of plant cellular mechanisms for sensing mechanical stimuli, including gravity. For practical applications in space, understanding how plants sense gravity is vital for developing robust plant-based life support systems and ensuring successful plant growth in microgravity environments. The insights into mechanotransduction could also lead to future terrestrial applications in agriculture for enhancing plant resilience.
journal: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A.
original_title: Expression and characterization of the bacterial mechanosensitive channel MscS in Xenopus laevis oocytes

title: The signaling lipid sphingosine 1-phosphate regulates mechanical pain
abstract: Somatosensory neurons mediate responses to diverse mechanical stimuli, from innocuous touch to noxious pain. While recent studies have identified distinct populations of A mechanonociceptors (AMs) that are required for mechanical pain, the molecular underpinnings of mechanonociception remain unknown. Here, we show that the bioactive lipid sphingosine 1-phosphate (S1P) and S1P Receptor 3 (S1PR3) are critical regulators of acute mechanonociception. Genetic or pharmacological ablation of S1PR3, or blockade of S1P production, significantly impaired the behavioral response to noxious mechanical stimuli, with no effect on responses to innocuous touch or thermal stimuli. These effects are mediated by fast-conducting A mechanonociceptors, which displayed a significant decrease in mechanosensitivity in S1PR3 mutant mice. We show that S1PR3 signaling tunes mechanonociceptor excitability via modulation of KCNQ2/3 channels. Our findings define a new role for S1PR3 in regulating neuronal excitability and establish the importance of S1P/S1PR3 signaling in the setting of mechanical pain thresholds.
summary: This study aimed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying mechanonociception, identifying sphingosine 1-phosphate (S1P) and S1P Receptor 3 (S1PR3) as crucial regulators of acute mechanical pain. Genetic or pharmacological disruption of S1PR3 or S1P production significantly impaired behavioral responses to noxious mechanical stimuli, specifically in fast-conducting A mechanonociceptors, which showed decreased mechanosensitivity in S1PR3 mutant mice. These findings define a new role for S1PR3 in tuning neuronal excitability via KCNQ2/3 channels, establishing the importance of S1P/S1PR3 signaling in setting mechanical pain thresholds.
impact: Scientifically, this research significantly advances our understanding of pain pathways by identifying a novel lipid signaling mechanism and specific ion channels critical for mechanical pain perception, offering new targets for intervention. While not directly space-related, improved understanding of pain could inform the development of countermeasures for astronaut health, addressing musculoskeletal or neuropathic pain that might arise during long-duration space missions. Broader implications include the potential for developing new therapeutics for chronic mechanical pain conditions on Earth.
theme: Cell Biology: Neuronal Signaling and Pain
original_title: United in Diversity: Mechanosensitive Ion Channels in Plants

title: Expressing and Characterizing Mechanosensitive Channels in Xenopus Oocytes
abstract: The oocytes of the African clawed frog (Xenopus laevis) comprise one of the most widely used membrane protein expression systems. While frequently used for studies of transporters and ion channels, the application of this system to the study of mechanosensitive ion channels has been overlooked, perhaps due to a relative abundance of native expression systems. Recent advances, however, have illustrated the advantages of the oocyte system for studying plant and bacterial mechanosensitive channels. Here we describe in detail the methods used for heterologous expression and characterization of bacterial and plant mechanosensitive channels in Xenopus oocytes.
summary: This publication details methodologies for the heterologous expression and characterization of bacterial and plant mechanosensitive channels in *Xenopus laevis* oocytes. It highlights the advantages of this widely used membrane protein expression system for studying mechanosensitive channels, an application that has been historically overlooked despite its utility. The work provides a detailed guide for researchers to effectively employ this system.
impact: Scientifically, this work significantly advances the toolkit for studying mechanosensitive ion channels by detailing a robust methodology for their expression and characterization in *Xenopus* oocytes, expanding the utility of this established biological system. While primarily a methods paper for fundamental cellular biology, understanding mechanosensation is crucial for comprehending how organisms, including plants and cells, adapt to physical forces, making it foundational for future space biology research on microgravity effects. This methodological contribution empowers further investigation into fundamental mechanobiological processes, with broad implications for both terrestrial and potential space-related applications.
original_title: Expressing and Characterizing Mechanosensitive Channels in Xenopus Oocytes

title: The ongoing search for the molecular basis of plant osmosensing
abstract: Cell viability and metabolism depend on cytoplasmic water and solute content, and organisms have evolved mechanisms to sense changes in cell water content, solute concentrations, cell volume, and/or turgor. This Perspective addresses the response to osmotic challenge in land plants and describes their special dependence on cellular water status for growth and development. Understanding how plants cope with water limitation may allow us to mitigate the agricultural effects of drought, a critical limitation on global crop productivity that is likely to increase in severity as the climate changes (Long and Ort, 2010). The signaling pathways by which plants respond to osmotic challenge are intriguing from an evolutionary standpoint: some aspects of these pathways resemble those of fungal or mammalian cells, some are similar to prokaryotic mechanisms, and yet others are unique to plants (as described below and in Hamann, 2012). In addition to the importance of osmotic homeostasis in land plants, we will discuss some of the specific context and language of plant stress biology, and describe what is known (and not known) about the molecular pathways by which plants sense and respond to osmotic challenges.
headings: The roles of water in plant biology
Terminology and concepts in plant osmosensing
Conditions under which plants experience osmotic challenges
Connecting perception to response: Osmotic stress signaling pathways
summary: This Perspective publication investigates the molecular basis of plant osmosensing, focusing on how land plants sense and respond to osmotic challenges and changes in cellular water status. It explores the intricate signaling pathways, noting similarities to fungal, mammalian, and prokaryotic mechanisms, as well as pathways unique to plants. The authors emphasize that understanding these mechanisms is crucial for mitigating the agricultural impact of drought, a significant limitation on global crop productivity exacerbated by climate change.
impact: Scientifically, this publication synthesizes current knowledge on plant osmosensing, advancing our understanding of a fundamental biological process with evolutionary connections across kingdoms. Practically, insights into plant water stress response are vital for developing drought-resistant crops, which has direct terrestrial applications for food security. For space biology, this research informs strategies for maintaining plant health and productivity in controlled environments, crucial for long-duration space missions and potential extraterrestrial agriculture, contributing to countermeasures against plant stress in confined systems. The prestigious journal and author expertise underscore its contribution to the field of plant stress biology.
original_title: The ongoing search for the molecular basis of plant osmosensing

title: Plastid osmotic stress influences cell differentiation at the plant shoot apex
abstract: The balance between proliferation and differentiation in the plant shoot apical meristem is controlled by regulatory loops involving the phytohormone cytokinin and stem cell identity genes. Concurrently, cellular differentiation in the developing shoot is coordinated with the environmental and developmental status of plastids within those cells. Here, we employ an Arabidopsis thaliana mutant exhibiting constitutive plastid osmotic stress to investigate the molecular and genetic pathways connecting plastid osmotic stress with cell differentiation at the shoot apex. msl2 msl3 mutants exhibit dramatically enlarged and deformed plastids in the shoot apical meristem, and develop a mass of callus tissue at the shoot apex. Callus production in this mutant requires the cytokinin receptor AHK2 and is characterized by increased cytokinin levels, downregulation of cytokinin signaling inhibitors ARR7 and ARR15, and induction of the stem cell identity gene WUSCHEL. Furthermore, plastid stress-induced apical callus production requires elevated plastidic reactive oxygen species, ABA biosynthesis, the retrograde signaling protein GUN1, and ABI4. These results are consistent with a model wherein the cytokinin/WUS pathway and retrograde signaling control cell differentiation at the shoot apex.
summary: This study investigated the molecular and genetic pathways linking plastid osmotic stress to cell differentiation at the plant shoot apex using *Arabidopsis thaliana* *msl2 msl3* mutants. The mutants exhibited dramatically enlarged plastids and formed callus tissue at the shoot apex, a process requiring the cytokinin receptor AHK2, elevated cytokinin, downregulation of cytokinin inhibitors ARR7/ARR15, and induction of WUSCHEL. Furthermore, this apical callus production relied on increased plastidic reactive oxygen species, ABA biosynthesis, and the retrograde signaling proteins GUN1 and ABI4, suggesting a model where cytokinin/WUS and retrograde signaling control cell differentiation.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of plant developmental regulation, specifically how plastid stress influences cell fate decisions and meristem activity through phytohormone and retrograde signaling pathways. While fundamental, this knowledge is crucial for optimizing plant growth and development in controlled environments, including potential applications for space-based agriculture and life support systems, by enabling better design of cultivation strategies. It also provides insights for enhancing crop resilience and productivity under various environmental stressors on Earth.
theme: Plant Biology: Cell Differentiation and Stress Response
original_title: Plastid osmotic stress influences cell differentiation at the plant shoot apex.

title: Spaceflight-induced synaptic modifications within hair cells of the mammalian utricle
abstract: Exposure to the microgravity conditions of spaceflight alleviates the load normally imposed by the Earth’s gravitational field on the inner ear utricular epithelia. Previous ultrastructural investigations have shown that spaceflight induces an increase in synapse density within hair cells of the rat utricle. However, the utricle exhibits broad physiological heterogeneity across different epithelial regions, and it is unknown whether capabilities for synaptic plasticity generalize to hair cells across its topography. To achieve systematic and broader sampling of the epithelium than was previously conducted, we used immunohistochemistry and volumetric image analyses to quantify synapse distributions across representative utricular regions in specimens from mice exposed to spaceflight (a 15-day mission of the space shuttle Discovery). These measures were compared with similarly sampled Earth-bound controls. Following paraformaldehyde fixation and microdissection, immunohistochemistry was performed on intact specimens to label presynaptic ribbons (anti-CtBP2) and postsynaptic receptor complexes (anti-Shank1A). Synapses were identified as closely apposed pre- and postsynaptic puncta. Epithelia from horizontal semicircular canal cristae served as “within-specimen” controls, whereas utricles and cristae from Earth-bound cohorts served as experimental controls. We found that synapse densities decreased in the medial extrastriolae of microgravity specimens compared with experimental controls, whereas they were unchanged in the striolae and horizontal cristae from the two conditions. These data demonstrate that structural plasticity was topographically localized to the utricular region that encodes very low frequency and static changes in linear acceleration, and illuminates the remarkable capabilities of utricular hair cells for synaptic plasticity in adapting to novel gravitational environments.
summary: This study investigated whether spaceflight-induced synaptic modifications generalize across different regions of the mammalian utricle, building on previous findings of increased synapse density. Using immunohistochemistry and volumetric analyses in mice, researchers found that a 15-day space mission led to a decrease in synapse densities in the medial extrastriolae compared to Earth-bound controls, while densities in the striolae and horizontal cristae remained unchanged. These results demonstrate that structural plasticity is topographically localized to the utricular region responsible for encoding very low frequency and static changes in linear acceleration, underscoring the remarkable adaptability of utricular hair cells to novel gravitational environments.
impact: This publication significantly advances the understanding of how the vestibular system adapts to microgravity by revealing topographically localized synaptic plasticity within the utricle, specifically a decrease in the medial extrastriolae. Scientifically, it provides crucial insights into the cellular mechanisms underlying sensory adaptation to extreme environments, refining previous, less regionally specific findings. Practically, these findings are vital for understanding and addressing astronaut balance and spatial orientation challenges during space missions, potentially guiding the development of countermeasures for vestibular dysfunction. Broader implications extend to terrestrial research on vestibular disorders and sensory system plasticity under altered environmental conditions.
theme: Microgravity Effects on Vestibular Cell Biology
original_title: Spaceflight-induced synaptic modifications within hair cells of the mammalian utricle.

title: Effects of angular frequency during clinorotation on mesenchymal stem cell morphology and migration
abstract:
Aims:
To determine the short-term effects of simulated microgravity on mesenchymal stem cell behaviors—as a function of clinorotation speed—using time-lapse microscopy.

Background:
Ground-based microgravity simulation can reproduce the apparent effects of weightlessness in spaceflight using clinostats that continuously reorient the gravity vector on a specimen, creating a time-averaged nullification of gravity. In this work, we investigated the effects of clinorotation speed on the morphology, cytoarchitecture, and migration behavior of human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs).

Methods:
We compared cell responses at clinorotation speeds of 0, 30, 60, and 75 rpm over 8 h in a recently developed lab-on-chip-based clinostat system. Time-lapse light microscopy was used to visualize changes in cell morphology during and after cessation of clinorotation. Cytoarchitecture was assessed by actin and vinculin staining, and chemotaxis was examined using time-lapse light microscopy of cells in NGF (100 ng/ml) gradients.

Results:
Among clinorotated groups, cell area distributions indicated a greater inhibition of cell spreading with higher angular frequency (P<0.005), though average cell area at 30 rpm after 8 h became statistically similar to control (P=0.794). Cells at 75 rpm clinorotation remained viable and were able to re-spread after clinorotation. In chemotaxis chambers, clinorotation did not alter migration patterns in elongated cells, but most clinorotated cells exhibited cell retraction, which strongly compromised motility.

Conclusions:
These results indicate that hMSCs respond to clinorotation by adopting more rounded, less-spread morphologies. The angular frequency-dependence suggests that a cell’s ability to sense the changing gravity vector is governed by the rate of perturbation. For migration studies, cells cultured in clinorotated chemotaxis chambers were generally less motile and exhibited retraction instead of migration.
summary: This study explored the short-term effects of simulated microgravity via clinorotation speed (0, 30, 60, 75 rpm) on human mesenchymal stem cell (hMSC) morphology and migration. It found that higher angular frequencies significantly inhibited cell spreading (P<0.005), causing hMSCs to adopt more rounded, less-spread morphologies and compromising their motility through retraction, though 30 rpm resulted in cell areas statistically similar to controls (P=0.794) after 8 hours. These results suggest that a cell's ability to sense the changing gravity vector is governed by the rate of perturbation.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of hMSC behavior under simulated microgravity, highlighting the crucial role of clinorotation angular frequency in modulating cell morphology and migration, and utilizing a novel lab-on-chip clinostat system. The findings have practical implications for predicting stem cell behavior during space missions, potentially aiding in astronaut health, tissue regeneration studies, and the design of effective countermeasures. Furthermore, it informs future research into optimizing microgravity simulation and exploring fundamental cellular mechanosensing mechanisms.
original_title: Effects of angular frequency during clinorotation on mesenchymal stem cell morphology and migration

title: The role of FGF-2 and BMP-2 in regulation of gene induction, cell proliferation and mineralization
abstract: The difficulty in re-growing and mineralizing new bone after severe fracture can result in loss of ambulation or limb. Here we describe the sequential roles of FGF-2 in inducing gene expression, cell growth and BMP-2 in gene expression and mineralization of bone. The regulation of gene expression was determined using real-time RTPCR (qRTPCR) and cell proliferation was measured by thymidine incorporation or fluorescent analysis of DNA content in MC3T3E1 osteoblast-like cells. Photomicroscopy was used to identify newly mineralized tissue and fluorescence was used to quantify mineralization.
