Fibroblast growth factor-2 (FGF-2) had the greatest ability to induce proliferation after 24 hours of treatment when compared to transforming growth factor beta (TGFβ, insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), bone morphogenic protein (BMP-2), platelet derived growth factor (PDGF) or prostaglandin E2 (PGE2). We found that FGF-2 caused the most significant induction of expression of early growth response-1 (egr-1), fgf-2, cyclo-oxygenase-2 (cox-2), tgfβ and matrix metalloproteinase-3 (mmp-3) associated with proliferation and expression of angiogenic genes like vascular endothelial growth factor A (vegfA) and its receptor vegfr1. We found that FGF-2 significantly reduced gene expression associated with mineralization, e.g. collagen type-1 (col1a1), fibronectin (fn), osteocalcin (oc), IGF-1, noggin, bone morphogenic protein (bmp-2) and alkaline phosphatase (alp). In contrast, BMP-2 significantly stimulated expression of the mineralization associated genes but had little or no effect on gene expression associated with growth. The ability of FGF-2 to re-program a mineralizing gene expression profile to one of proliferation suggests that FGF-2 plays a critical role of osteoblast growth in early fracture repair while BMP-2 is instrumental in stimulating mineralization.
summary: This NASA Space Biology study investigated the sequential roles of FGF-2 and BMP-2 in regulating gene induction, cell proliferation, and mineralization in MC3T3E1 osteoblast-like cells to improve bone regeneration after severe fracture. FGF-2 demonstrated the greatest ability to induce proliferation after 24 hours compared to other growth factors, significantly inducing early growth and angiogenic genes while reducing mineralization gene expression. Conversely, BMP-2 stimulated mineralization-associated genes with minimal effect on growth, highlighting FGF-2's critical role in early osteoblast growth and BMP-2's in stimulating mineralization.
impact: This research significantly advances the scientific understanding of the distinct and sequential roles of FGF-2 and BMP-2 in regulating bone cell behavior, crucial for bone repair. Practically, these findings are instrumental for developing targeted therapeutic strategies to enhance bone regeneration, directly benefiting astronaut health by addressing fracture healing and bone density issues in space. The insights into these growth factor mechanisms could inform future countermeasure development for spaceflight-induced bone demineralization and inspire novel approaches to regenerative medicine on Earth.
original_title: The role of FGF-2 and BMP-2 in regulation of gene induction, cell proliferation and mineralization.

title: Nutritional supplements, COX-2 and IGF-1 expression in men on active surveillance for prostate cancer
abstract:
Background
Nutritional factors are associated with reduced risk of prostate cancer progression, yet mechanisms remain unclear. We examined the effects of lycopene and fish oil supplements versus placebo on the normal prostate microenvironment, among men pursuing active surveillance for low-burden prostate cancer. We hypothesized that lycopene or fish oil supplements would down-regulate insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) and cyclooxygenase 2 (COX-2) gene expression, respectively, reflecting putative proliferation (IGF-1) and inflammatory (COX-2) pathways relevant to carcinogenesis.
Methods
We conducted a 3-month randomized, double-blinded, clinical trial comparing prostate tissue gene expression profiles (assessed by qRT–PCR) among men with favorable-risk prostate cancer receiving either 30 mg/day lycopene, 3 g/day fish oil (including 1,098 mg eicosapentaenoic and 549 mg docosahexaenoic fatty acids) or placebo.
Results
Among 69 men (22 assigned to lycopene, 21 to fish, and 26 to placebo), there was no difference in the change from baseline to the 3 months in IGF-1 expression level between the placebo and lycopene arms (p = 0.93) nor in COX-2 expression between the placebo and fish arms (p = 0.99).
Conclusion
Compared to placebo, 3-month intervention with lycopene or fish oil did not significantly change IGF-1 and COX-2 gene expression in the normal prostate microenvironment in men with low-burden prostate cancer. Further analysis of global gene expression profiles may shed light on the bioactivity and relevance of these nutrients in prostate cancer.
headings: Study participants, eligibility criteria, and enrollment
summary: This randomized, double-blinded clinical trial investigated whether 3-month supplementation with lycopene (30 mg/day) or fish oil (3 g/day) could down-regulate IGF-1 and COX-2 gene expression, respectively, in the normal prostate microenvironment of 69 men on active surveillance for low-burden prostate cancer. The study found no significant difference in the change from baseline in IGF-1 expression between the placebo and lycopene arms (p = 0.93), nor in COX-2 expression between the placebo and fish oil arms (p = 0.99). These results conclude that, compared to placebo, the 3-month intervention with lycopene or fish oil did not significantly change IGF-1 and COX-2 gene expression in the normal prostate microenvironment.
impact: This study rigorously tested specific nutritional interventions against hypothesized molecular pathways in prostate cancer, contributing to scientific understanding by providing evidence for the *lack* of effect of lycopene and fish oil on IGF-1 and COX-2 gene expression under these conditions. The findings are valuable for refining dietary recommendations and preventing misdirected interventions for prostate cancer patients, prompting further investigation into global gene expression profiles. For NASA Space Biology, this research informs fundamental knowledge about human nutrition, disease mechanisms, and the efficacy of dietary countermeasures, which is critical for maintaining astronaut health and mitigating disease risks during long-duration space missions, despite its direct terrestrial application.
original_title: Nutritional supplements, COX-2 and IGF-1 expression in men on active surveillance for prostate cancer.

title: To infinity … and beyond! Human spaceflight and life science
summary: This publication reviews critical physiological challenges encountered by humans during spaceflight, specifically focusing on fluid shifts leading to space anemia, the development of space osteoporosis, and immunosuppression. It synthesizes current understanding of these major microgravity effects on the human body. The review aims to inform future human spaceflight missions and life science research.
impact: This publication holds significant scientific value by consolidating knowledge on major physiological changes in space, including cardiovascular fluid shifts, bone loss, and immune dysfunction. Its practical applications are crucial for astronaut health, informing the development of countermeasures and strategies for long-duration space missions. Authored by Millie Hughes-Fulford in FASEB J., it serves as a foundational resource guiding future research in space biology and human adaptation to extreme environments.
original_title: To Infinity and Beyond! Human spaceflight and life science.

title: Over-activation of iNKT cells aggravate lung injury in bronchopulmonary dysplasia mice
abstract: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a severe lung disease in preterm infants, the abnormal proliferate and differentiate ability of type II epithelial cells (AEC II) is the key to the pathological basis of BPD. Mechanisms regarding abnormal AEC II in BPD remain unclear. The present work investigated the role and mechanisms of invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells in lung disorder in BPD using public datasets, clinical samples, a hyperoxia-induced BPD mouse model and AEC II-iNKT cells transwell co-culture system. Firstly, we found that the NKT cells development factor IL-15 increased over time in patients with BPD in public databases, and clinically collected peripheral blood NKT cells in patients with BPD were increased. Subsequently, the percentage of iNKT cells increased in hyperoxia group compared with normoxia group, with the highest at P7, accompanied by increased activation with abnormal lung development. The administration of anti-CD1d neutralizing antibody to inhibit iNKT cells could alleviate the abnormal lung development of hyperoxia group mice, while α-GalCer administration could aggravate lung injury in hyperoxia group mice, and adoptive transfer of iNKT cells could aggravate the abnormal lung development in hyperoxia group mice. In addition, to further verify the role of iNKT cells on AEC II, AEC II-iNKT cells co-culture system was established. The presence of iNKT cells could aggravate the abnormal expression of SP-C and T1α under hyperoxia. Meanwhile, RNA-seq analysis showed that ferroptosis-related genes were highly expressed in AEC II co-cultured with iNKT cells under hyperoxia. We further validated the effect of the presence of iNKT cells under hyperoxia environment on AEC II ferroptosis levels, suggested that iNKT cells promote AEC II ferroptosis under hyperoxia, accompanied by decreased expression of SP-C and T1α. Our study found that the recruitment of iNKT cells in the lung may be an important cause of alveolarization disorder in BPD.
summary: This study investigated the role and mechanisms of invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells in bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) lung injury, focusing on abnormal type II epithelial cells (AEC II). Researchers observed increased IL-15 and NKT cells in BPD patients, and in a hyperoxia-induced BPD mouse model, iNKT cells significantly increased with highest levels at P7, correlating with abnormal lung development. The study concluded that iNKT cell over-activation promotes AEC II ferroptosis and decreases critical lung markers (SP-C and T1α), suggesting that iNKT cell recruitment is a significant cause of alveolarization disorder in BPD.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of BPD pathogenesis by pinpointing iNKT cells and their induction of ferroptosis in alveolar type II epithelial cells as a critical mechanism of lung injury. While primarily a terrestrial medical study, its insights into immune dysregulation and specific lung cell death pathways could indirectly inform strategies for maintaining astronaut lung health in varied space environments, particularly under conditions of altered oxygen levels or immune system stress. The findings provide potential new therapeutic targets for BPD by modulating iNKT cell activity or ferroptosis, offering broader implications for managing lung health both on Earth and in challenging extraterrestrial settings.
original_title: Hyperoxia inhibits T cell activation in mice

title: Effects of Gravitational Mechanical Unloading in Endothelial Cells: Association between Caveolins, Inflammation and Adhesion Molecules
abstract: Mechanical forces including gravity affect endothelial cell (ECs) function, and have been implicated in vascular disease as well as physiologic changes associated with low gravity environments. The goal of this study was to investigate the impact of gravitational mechanical unloading on ECs phenotype as determined by patterns of gene expression. Human umbilical vascular endothelial cells were exposed to 1-gravity environment or mechanical unloading (MU) for 24 hours, with or without periods of mechanical loading (ML). MU led to a significant decrease in gene expression of several adhesion molecules and pro-inflammatory cytokines. On the contrary, eNOS, Caveolin-1 and -2 expression were significantly increased with MU. There was a decrease in the length and width of the cells with MU. Addition of ML during the MU period was sufficient to reverse the changes triggered by MU. Our results suggest that gravitational loading could dramatically affect vascular endothelial cell function.
summary: This study investigated the impact of gravitational mechanical unloading (MU) on human umbilical vascular endothelial cell (EC) phenotype and gene expression. Mechanical unloading for 24 hours significantly decreased gene expression of adhesion molecules and pro-inflammatory cytokines, while increasing eNOS, Caveolin-1, and Caveolin-2 expression. Additionally, MU led to a decrease in cell length and width, but these changes were reversible with periods of mechanical loading, suggesting gravitational loading critically affects vascular endothelial cell function.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of how microgravity-like mechanical unloading affects endothelial cell function at a molecular level, linking specific gene expression changes (e.g., caveolins, adhesion molecules) to morphological alterations. Practically, these findings are crucial for understanding physiological changes in astronauts in low-gravity environments, contributing to the development of countermeasures for vascular health during space missions. Broader implications extend to terrestrial vascular diseases where mechanical forces play a role, opening avenues for future research into mechanotransduction pathways and therapeutic targets, further supported by its publication in a reputable journal (Sci Rep.) and by expertise like Millie Hughes-Fulford.
original_title: Effects of gravitational mechanical unloading in endothelial cells: association between caveolins, inflammation and adhesion molecules

title: Fish Oil Increases Specialized Pro-resolving Lipid Mediators in PAD (The OMEGA-PAD II Trial)
abstract:
Background:
N-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA) supplementation has been associated with reduced mortality and inflammation in patients with cardiovascular disease. There are limited data on the effects of n-3 PUFA supplementation in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
Materials and methods:
The OMEGA-PAD II trial was a double-blinded, randomized, placebo-controlled trial to assess the effect of 3 mo of high-dose oral n-3 PUFA supplementation on inflammation, endothelial function, and walking ability in patients with PAD.
Results:
Twenty-four patients with claudication received 4.4 g/d of fish oil or placebo for 3 mo. Outcomes measured included high-sensitivity C-reactive protein levels, the omega-3 index, endothelial function as measured via flow-mediated vasodilation, walking impairment questionnaire, and a 6-min walk test. Plasma levels of specialized pro-resolving lipid mediators (SPMs) were measured by liquid-chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry. In patients treated with fish oil, the absolute mean omega-3 index significantly increased from baseline (fish oil: 7.2 ± 1.2%, P < 0.001; placebo: −0.4 ± 0.9%, P = 0.31; between-group P < 0.001). Furthermore, there were significant increases in several pathway markers of SPM biosynthesis, including several mono-hydroxyeicosapentaenoic acids and mono-hydroxydocosahexaenoic acids. We also observed significant increases in the SPM lipoxin A5 (fish oil: 0.57 ± 0.70 pg/mL, P = 0.05; placebo: 0.01 ± 0.38 pg/mL, P = 0.93; between-group P = 0.04) and resolvin E3 (fish oil: 154 ± 171 pg/mL, P = 0.04; placebo: 32 ± 54 pg/mL, P = 0.08; between-group P = 0.04). There were no significant changes in high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, flow-mediated vasodilation, walking impairment questionnaire, or 6-min walk test in the fish oil group.
Conclusions:
Fish oil increases SPMs in plasma of patients with PAD. Further studies are required to determine whether these early changes translate to clinical improvements in patients with PAD.
summary: The OMEGA-PAD II trial, a double-blinded, randomized, placebo-controlled study, investigated the effects of 3 months of high-dose oral n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA) supplementation (4.4 g/d fish oil) in 24 patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and claudication. The study observed a significant increase in the omega-3 index and elevated levels of several specialized pro-resolving lipid mediator (SPM) biosynthesis pathway markers, including mono-hydroxyeicosapentaenoic acids and mono-hydroxydocosahexaenoic acids, in the fish oil group. Furthermore, specific SPMs like lipoxin A5 and resolvin E3 significantly increased with fish oil treatment compared to placebo. However, no significant changes were found in high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, endothelial function (flow-mediated vasodilation), or walking ability (walking impairment questionnaire, 6-min walk test). The study concludes that fish oil effectively increases SPMs in the plasma of PAD patients, suggesting a mechanistic effect, but further studies are needed to determine if these early changes lead to clinical improvements.
impact: This research provides crucial insights into the biochemical mechanisms by which fish oil supplementation influences the inflammatory response in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD). By demonstrating a significant increase in specialized pro-resolving lipid mediators (SPMs), the study identifies a novel pathway through which n-3 PUFAs may exert their beneficial effects, shifting the focus from general inflammation reduction to active resolution. This mechanistic understanding could pave the way for targeted therapeutic interventions. For NASA Space Biology, understanding how dietary interventions like fish oil impact inflammation and cardiovascular health is vital, as astronauts experience unique physiological stressors that can affect these systems during long-duration space missions. Insights into dietary modulation of inflammation and resolution pathways could contribute to maintaining astronaut well-being and mitigating health risks in space.
theme: Investigation of the impact of n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid (fish oil) supplementation on specialized pro-resolving lipid mediators (SPMs) and clinical markers in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
original_title: n-3 Polyunsaturated fatty acids supplementation in peripheral artery disease: the OMEGA-PAD trial

title: Molecular mechanisms underlying the enhanced functions of three-dimensional hepatocyte aggregates
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) culture of hepatocytes leads to improved and prolonged synthetic and metabolic functions, but the underlying molecular mechanisms are unknown. In order to investigate the role of 3D cell-cell interactions in maintaining hepatocyte differentiated functions ex vivo, primary mouse hepatocytes were cultured either as monolayers on tissue culture dishes (TCD) or as 3D aggregates in rotating wall vessel (RWV) bioreactors. Global gene expression analyses revealed that genes upregulated in 3D culture were distinct from those upregulated during liver development and liver regeneration. Instead, they represented a diverse array of hepatocyte-specific functional genes with significant over-representation of hepatocyte nuclear factor 4α (Hnf4a) binding sites in their promoters. Expression of Hnf4a and many of its downstream target genes were significantly increased in RWV cultures as compared to TCD. Conversely, there was concomitant suppression of mesenchymal and cytoskeletal genes in RWV cultures that were induced in TCDs. These findings illustrate the importance of 3D cell-cell interactions in maintaining fundamental molecular pathways of hepatocyte function and serve as a basis for rational design of biomaterials that aim to optimize hepatocyte functions ex vivo for biomedical applications.

3.1. Morphology and function of primary mouse hepatocytes cultured within RWVs and on TCDs
3.2. Global gene expression profiles of hepatocytes cultured as 3D aggregates or as monolayers
3.3. Gene expression profile of 3D aggregate cultures compared to liver development and liver regeneration
3.4. Characterization of differential gene expression between 3D aggregate and monolayer cultures
3.5. Promoter region analysis of genes upregulated in RWVs compared to TCDs
3.6. Characterization of mesenchymal and cytoskeletal gene expression in monolayer cultures compared to 3D aggregate cultures
summary: This NASA Space Biology study investigated the molecular mechanisms underlying the enhanced functions of three-dimensional (3D) hepatocyte aggregates. Primary mouse hepatocytes were cultured either as monolayers or as 3D aggregates in rotating wall vessel (RWV) bioreactors. Global gene expression analyses revealed that genes upregulated in 3D culture were distinct from those involved in liver development or regeneration, instead representing diverse hepatocyte-specific functional genes. These genes showed a significant over-representation of hepatocyte nuclear factor 4α (Hnf4a) binding sites in their promoters, with Hnf4a and many of its downstream targets being significantly increased in RWV cultures. Conversely, mesenchymal and cytoskeletal genes, which were induced in monolayer cultures, were suppressed in RWV cultures. These findings demonstrate the importance of 3D cell-cell interactions in maintaining fundamental molecular pathways of hepatocyte function.
impact: This research provides a crucial molecular understanding of how 3D cell culture enhances hepatocyte function, which is valuable for space biology research utilizing bioreactors. The insights gained serve as a basis for the rational design of biomaterials and culture systems aimed at optimizing hepatocyte functions ex vivo, with broad implications for biomedical applications such as drug discovery, toxicology screening, and regenerative medicine, potentially including systems for long-duration space missions.
theme: Space Biology; Three-dimensional cell culture; Hepatocyte differentiation and function; Gene expression regulation; Bioreactor technology; Molecular mechanisms of tissue engineering.
original_title: Molecular mechanisms underlying the enhanced functions of three-dimensional hepatocyte aggregates

title: Spaceflight alters expression of microRNA during T-cell activation
abstract: Altered immune function has been demonstrated in astronauts during spaceflights dating back to Apollo and Skylab; this could be a major barrier to long-term space exploration. We tested the hypothesis that spaceflight causes changes in microRNA (miRNA) expression. Human leukocytes were stimulated with mitogens on board the International Space Station using an onboard normal gravity control. Bioinformatics showed that miR-21 was significantly up-regulated 2-fold during early T-cell activation in normal gravity, and gene expression was suppressed under microgravity. This was confirmed using quantitative real-time PCR (n = 4). This is the first report that spaceflight regulates miRNA expression. Global microarray analysis showed significant (P < 0.05) suppression of 85 genes under microgravity conditions compared to normal gravity samples. EGR3, FASLG, BTG2, SPRY2, and TAGAP are biologically confirmed targets and are co-up-regulated with miR-21. These genes share common promoter regions with pre-mir-21; as the miR-21 matures and accumulates, it most likely will inhibit translation of its target genes and limit the immune response. These data suggest that gravity regulates T-cell activation not only by transcription promotion but also by blocking translation via noncoding RNA mechanisms. Moreover, this study suggests that T-cell activation itself may induce a sequence of gene expressions that is self-limited by miR-21.—Hughes-Fulford, M., Chang, T. T., Martinez, E. M., Li, C.-F. Spaceflight alters expression of microRNA during T-cell activation.
headings: miR-21 is dysregulated in true ISS microgravity during T-cell activation
Analysis of mRNA gene arrays for significantly dysregulated microgravity genes
qRT-PCR of immediate early genes in nonactivated, normal gravity onboard activated, and onboard microgravity-activated T cells with 3′-UTR miR-21 seed sequences
Predictions of transcription factor locations in promoter regions of gravity-sensitive genes
summary: This study investigated the impact of spaceflight on microRNA (miRNA) expression during T-cell activation, a critical component of immune function. Using human leukocytes stimulated on the International Space Station with an onboard normal gravity control, the researchers found that miR-21 was significantly up-regulated in normal gravity during early T-cell activation, but its expression was suppressed under microgravity conditions. This was confirmed by qRT-PCR. Global microarray analysis identified 85 genes significantly suppressed under microgravity, including EGR3, FASLG, BTG2, SPRY2, and TAGAP, which are co-up-regulated with miR-21 and share common promoter regions. The findings suggest that gravity regulates T-cell activation not only through transcriptional promotion but also by inhibiting translation via noncoding RNA mechanisms, and that T-cell activation itself may be self-limited by miR-21.
impact: The demonstration that spaceflight alters microRNA expression, specifically dysregulating miR-21 and suppressing target genes critical for immune response, provides a novel mechanism for the observed altered immune function in astronauts. This understanding is crucial because compromised immune function could be a major barrier to the success and safety of long-duration human space exploration, necessitating the development of countermeasures or predictive biomarkers.
theme: Spaceflight effects on immune gene regulation via microRNA mechanisms
original_title: Spaceflight alters expression of microRNA during T-cell activation

title: Spaceflight impairs antigen-specific tolerance induction in vivo and increases inflammatory cytokines
abstract: The health risks of a dysregulated immune response during spaceflight are important to understand as plans emerge for humans to embark on long-term space travel to Mars. In this first-of-its-kind study, we used adoptive transfer of T-cell receptor transgenic OT-II CD4 T cells to track an in vivo antigen-specific immune response that was induced during the course of spaceflight. Experimental mice destined for spaceflight and mice that remained on the ground received transferred OT-II cells and cognate peptide stimulation with ovalbumin (OVA) 323-339 plus the inflammatory adjuvant, monophosphoryl lipid A. Control mice in both flight and ground cohorts received monophosphoryl lipid A alone without additional OVA stimulation. Numbers of OT-II cells in flight mice treated with OVA were significantly increased by 2-fold compared with ground mice treated with OVA, suggesting that tolerance induction was impaired by spaceflight. Production of proinflammatory cytokines were significantly increased in flight compared with ground mice, including a 5-fold increase in IFN-γ and a 10-fold increase in IL-17. This study is the first to show that immune tolerance may be impaired in spaceflight, leading to excessive inflammatory responses.—Chang, T. T., Spurlock, S. M, Candelario, T. L. T., Grenon, S. M., Hughes-Fulford, M. Spaceflight impairs antigen-specific tolerance induction in vivo and increases inflammatory cytokines.
headings: Preparation and adoptive transfer of OT-II memory cells
Antigen and adjuvant delivery by subcutaneous minipump
Carboxyfluorescein succinimidyl ester (CFSE) labeling and proliferation analysis
RNA isolation and quantitative real-time reverse transcription PCR
Antigen-specific challenge in vivo during spaceflight resulted in greater numbers of antigen-specific T cells compared with ground-based responses
In vivo OVA peptide plus MPLA stimulation by minipump delivery led to induction of antigen-specific tolerance
Spaceflight had differential effects on CD62L, CD25, and CD44 expression on endogenous and transferred CD4 T cells
Spaceflight differentially impaired subsequent expression of CD25, Foxp3, and CD44 upon antigen-specific restimulation in vitro
Splenocyte cultures from mice exposed to spaceflight produced increased antigen-specific proinflammatory cytokines
summary: This groundbreaking NASA Space Biology study investigated the impact of spaceflight on antigen-specific immune responses and tolerance induction using an adoptive transfer model with OT-II CD4 T cells in mice. Mice exposed to spaceflight, when stimulated with ovalbumin (OVA) peptide and a pro-inflammatory adjuvant, exhibited a significant 2-fold increase in antigen-specific T cells compared to ground controls, indicating impaired tolerance induction. Furthermore, spaceflight led to a substantial increase in pro-inflammatory cytokines, specifically a 5-fold rise in IFN-γ and a 10-fold increase in IL-17. The study concludes that spaceflight may compromise immune tolerance, leading to heightened inflammatory responses.
impact: This research is the first of its kind to demonstrate that spaceflight can impair immune tolerance and exacerbate inflammatory cytokine production in an in vivo antigen-specific context. These findings are crucial for understanding and mitigating the health risks associated with dysregulated immune responses during long-duration human space missions, such as those planned for Mars, and highlight a significant challenge for astronaut health.
theme: Spaceflight immunology, immune tolerance, inflammation, antigen-specific T-cell responses, and the physiological effects of microgravity on the mammalian immune system.
original_title: Spaceflight impairs antigen-specific tolerance induction in vivo and increases inflammatory cytokines.

title: From Cellular Mechanotransduction to Biologically Inspired Engineering
abstract: This article is based on a lecture I presented as the recipient of the 2009 Pritzker Distinguished Lecturer Award at the Biomedical Engineering Society annual meeting in October 2009. Here, I review more than thirty years of research from my laboratory, beginning with studies designed to test the theory that cells use tensegrity (tensional integrity) architecture to stabilize their shape and sense mechanical signals, which I believed to be critical for control of cell function and tissue development. Although I was trained as a cell biologist, I found that the tools I had at my disposal were insufficient to experimentally test these theories, and thus I ventured into engineering to find critical solutions. This path has been extremely fruitful as it has led to confirmation of the critical role that physical forces play in developmental control, as well as how cells sense and respond to mechanical signals at the molecular level through a process known as cellular mechanotransduction. Many of the predictions of the cellular tensegrity model relating to cell mechanical behaviors have been shown to be valid, and this vision of cell structure led to discovery of the central role that transmembrane adhesion receptors, such as integrins, and the cytoskeleton play in mechanosensing and mechanochemical conversion. In addition, these fundamental studies have led to significant unexpected technology fallout, including development of micromagnetic actuators for non-invasive control of cellular signaling, microfluidic systems as therapeutic extracorporeal devices for sepsis therapy, and new DNA-based nanobiotechnology approaches that permit construction of artificial tensegrities that mimic properties of living materials for applications in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.
headings: THE LIVING CELL AS A MECHANICAL STRUCTURE
A STRANGE IDEA: TENSEGRITY IN CELLS
ENGINEERING APPROACHES PROVIDE NEW INSIGHTS INTO CELL STRUCTURE
STRUCTURAL HIERARCHIES FOR FORCE TRANSMISSION IN LIVING SYSTEMS
MECHANICAL CONTROL OF CELL FUNCTION AND TISSUE DEVELOPMENT
summary: This article, based on the author's 2009 Pritzker Distinguished Lecturer Award talk, reviews over thirty years of research focusing on the theory that cells utilize tensegrity (tensional integrity) architecture to maintain shape and sense mechanical signals. Starting from a cell biology background, the author ventured into engineering to develop tools to test these theories, leading to the confirmation of the critical role of physical forces in developmental control and the understanding of cellular mechanotransduction at a molecular level. Key findings include the validation of the cellular tensegrity model's predictions and the discovery of the central role of transmembrane adhesion receptors (like integrins) and the cytoskeleton in mechanosensing and mechanochemical conversion.
impact: The fundamental research discussed has led to significant technological advancements, including the development of micromagnetic actuators for non-invasive control of cellular signaling, microfluidic systems for sepsis therapy, and new DNA-based nanobiotechnology approaches for constructing artificial tensegrities. These biomimetic materials have potential applications in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine, demonstrating how a deeper understanding of cellular mechanics can translate into practical engineering solutions.
theme: The overarching theme is the interdisciplinary exploration of cellular mechanotransduction, using engineering principles to understand how cells perceive and respond to mechanical forces via tensegrity architecture, and the subsequent application of this knowledge to bio-inspired engineering and medical technologies.
original_title: From cellular mechanotransduction to biologically inspired engineering: 2009 Pritzker Award Lecture, BMES Annual Meeting October 10, 2009.

title: Crewmember microbiome may influence microbial composition of ISS habitable surfaces
abstract: The International Space Station (ISS) is a complex built environment physically isolated from Earth. Assessing the interplay between the microbial community of the ISS and its crew is important for preventing biomedical and structural complications for long term human spaceflight missions. In this study, we describe one crewmember’s microbial profile from body swabs of mouth, nose, ear, skin and saliva that were collected at eight different time points pre-, during and post-flight. Additionally, environmental surface samples from eight different habitable locations in the ISS were collected from two flights. Environmental samples from one flight were collected by the crewmember and samples from the next flight were collected after the crewmember departed. The microbial composition in both environment and crewmember samples was measured using shotgun metagenomic sequencing and processed using the Livermore Metagenomics Analysis Toolkit. Ordination of sample to sample distances showed that of the eight crew body sites analyzed, skin, nostril, and ear samples are more similar in microbial composition to the ISS surfaces than mouth and saliva samples; and that the microbial composition of the crewmember’s skin samples are more closely related to the ISS surface samples collected by the crewmember on the same flight than ISS surface samples collected by other crewmembers on different flights. In these collections, species alpha diversity in saliva samples appears to decrease during flight and rebound after returning to Earth. This is the first study to compare the ISS microbiome to a crewmember’s microbiome via shotgun metagenomic sequencing. We observed that the microbiome of the surfaces inside the ISS resemble those of the crew’s skin. These data support future crew and ISS microbial surveillance efforts and the design of preventive measures to maintain crew habitat onboard spacecraft destined for long term space travel.
headings: Prevalent and abundant microbial genera and species
Similarity of microbial profiles from crewmember and ISS surface samples
Microbial contribution from crewmember to surfaces
Comparison of surface microbiome from Flights 4–5 to Flights 1–3
summary: This study employed shotgun metagenomic sequencing to analyze the microbial profiles of one crewmember (body swabs of mouth, nose, ear, skin, saliva collected pre-, during, and post-flight) and habitable surfaces within the International Space Station (ISS). The research found that the crewmember's skin, nostril, and ear microbiomes were more similar in composition to ISS surfaces than their mouth and saliva samples. Notably, the crewmember's skin microbiome was more closely related to ISS surfaces collected by them during their flight. Species alpha diversity in saliva samples was observed to decrease during flight and rebound post-flight. This is the first study to use shotgun metagenomic sequencing to compare the ISS microbiome directly with a crewmember's microbiome, concluding that ISS surface microbiomes resemble those of the crew's skin.
impact: The findings are significant for understanding microbial dynamics in isolated, built environments like the ISS. They provide crucial data supporting future microbial surveillance efforts for both crew and spacecraft. This research informs the design of preventive measures essential for maintaining crew habitat health and preventing biomedical and structural complications during long-duration human spaceflight missions, ultimately contributing to the safety and success of future space exploration.
theme: Space microbiology; Human-built environment microbiome interactions; Crew health in space; Microbial ecology of confined environments; Spaceflight epidemiology; Microbiome transfer and surveillance.
original_title: Crewmember microbiome may influence microbial composition of ISS habitable surfaces

title: Sierra Nevada sweep: Metagenomic measurements of bioaerosols vertically distributed across the troposphere.
abstract: To explore how airborne microbial patterns change with height above the Earth’s surface, we flew NASA’s C-20A aircraft on two consecutive days in June 2018 along identical flight paths over the US Sierra Nevada mountain range at four different altitudes ranging from 10,000 ft to 40,000 ft. Bioaerosols were analyzed by metagenomic DNA sequencing and traditional culturing methods to characterize the composition and diversity of atmospheric samples compared to experimental controls. The relative abundance of taxa changed significantly at each altitude sampled, and the diversity profile shifted across the two sampling days, revealing a regional atmospheric microbiome that is dynamically changing. The most proportionally abundant microbial genera were Mycobacterium and Achromobacter at 10,000 ft; Stenotrophomonas and Achromobacter at 20,000 ft; Delftia and Pseudoperonospora at 30,000 ft; and Alcaligenes and Penicillium at 40,000 ft. Culture-based detections also identified viable Bacillus zhangzhouensis, Bacillus pumilus, and Bacillus spp. in the upper troposphere. To estimate bioaerosol dispersal, we developed a human exposure likelihood model (7-day forecast) using general aerosol characteristics and measured meteorological conditions. By coupling metagenomics to a predictive atmospheric model, we aim to set the stage for field campaigns that monitor global bioaerosol emissions and impacts.
summary: This NASA Space Biology study investigated the vertical distribution and composition of bioaerosols over the Sierra Nevada mountains, utilizing the C-20A aircraft to collect samples at altitudes ranging from 10,000 ft to 40,000 ft. Through metagenomic DNA sequencing and traditional culturing, the researchers found significant changes in microbial diversity and relative abundance across different altitudes and sampling days, indicating a dynamic atmospheric microbiome. Specific microbial genera, such as Mycobacterium, Achromobacter, Stenotrophomonas, Delftia, Pseudoperonospora, Alcaligenes, and Penicillium, showed varying proportional abundance with height, and viable Bacillus species were detected in the upper troposphere. The study also developed a human exposure likelihood model to predict bioaerosol dispersal, aiming to advance global bioaerosol monitoring and impact assessment by integrating metagenomics with atmospheric modeling.
impact: This research significantly enhances our understanding of the Earth's atmospheric microbiome and its vertical stratification, providing critical baseline data for environmental monitoring and public health. The methodology of coupling metagenomics with atmospheric modeling offers a powerful framework for predicting bioaerosol dispersal, which is vital for tracking the movement of airborne microbes, including potential pathogens or allergens, over long distances. This capability has broad implications for terrestrial applications such as disease surveillance and climate science, and for space biology by informing our understanding of planetary atmospheric biology and processes relevant to planetary protection and astrobiology.
theme: Bioaerosols, Atmospheric Microbiology, Metagenomics, Environmental Science, Predictive Modeling
original_title: Sierra Nevada sweep: Metagenomic measurements of bioaerosols vertically distributed across the troposphere.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Fungi Isolated from the International Space Station during the Microbial Tracking-2 Experiment
abstract: As part of the Microbial Tracking-2 study, 94 fungal strains were isolated from surfaces on the International Space Station, and whole-genome sequences were assembled. Characterization of these draft genomes will allow evaluation of microgravity adaption, risks to human health and spacecraft functioning, and biotechnological applications of fungi.
summary: This publication announces the draft whole-genome sequences of 94 fungal strains isolated from surfaces on the International Space Station (ISS) as part of the Microbial Tracking-2 study. These genomes are now available for further characterization.
impact: The characterization of these fungal draft genomes will facilitate the evaluation of microbial adaptation to microgravity, assessment of potential risks to human health and spacecraft operations, and exploration of biotechnological applications of these fungi in space environments.
theme: Space Biology, Microbial Genomics, Fungal Isolation, International Space Station (ISS) Microbes, Microbial Tracking, Environmental Microbiology

title: Microbial tracking-2, a metagenomics analysis of bacteria and fungi onboard the International Space Station.
abstract:
The International Space Station (ISS) is a unique and complex built environment with the ISS surface microbiome originating from crew and cargo or from life support recirculation in an almost entirely closed system. The Microbial Tracking 1 (MT-1) project was the first ISS environmental surface study to report on the metagenome profiles without using whole-genome amplification. The study surveyed the microbial communities from eight surfaces over a 14-month period. The Microbial Tracking 2 (MT-2) project aimed to continue the work of MT-1, sampling an additional four flights from the same locations, over another 14 months.
Eight surfaces across the ISS were sampled with sterile wipes and processed upon return to Earth. DNA extracted from the processed samples (and controls) were treated with propidium monoazide (PMA) to detect intact/viable cells or left untreated and to detect the total DNA population (free DNA/compromised cells/intact cells/viable cells). DNA extracted from PMA-treated and untreated samples were analyzed using shotgun metagenomics. Samples were cultured for bacteria and fungi to supplement the above results.
Staphylococcus sp. and Malassezia sp. were the most represented bacterial and fungal species, respectively, on the ISS. Overall, the ISS surface microbiome was dominated by organisms associated with the human skin. Multi-dimensional scaling and differential abundance analysis showed significant temporal changes in the microbial population but no spatial differences. The ISS antimicrobial resistance gene profiles were however more stable over time, with no differences over the 5-year span of the MT-1 and MT-2 studies. Twenty-nine antimicrobial resistance genes were detected across all samples, with macrolide/lincosamide/streptogramin resistance being the most widespread. Metagenomic assembled genomes were reconstructed from the dataset, resulting in 82 MAGs. Functional assessment of the collective MAGs showed a propensity for amino acid utilization over carbohydrate metabolism. Co-occurrence analyses showed strong associations between bacterial and fungal genera. Culture analysis showed the microbial load to be on average 3.0 × 105 cfu/m2
Utilizing various metagenomics analyses and culture methods, we provided a comprehensive analysis of the ISS surface microbiome, showing microbial burden, bacterial and fungal species prevalence, changes in the microbiome, and resistome over time and space, as well as the functional capabilities and microbial interactions of this unique built microbiome. Data from this study may help to inform policies for future space missions to ensure an ISS surface microbiome that promotes astronaut health and spacecraft integrity.
headings: Taxonomic profile of ISS microbial community
Sample kit preparation and sample collection
Shotgun metagenomics sequencing and taxonomic classification
summary: The Microbial Tracking 2 (MT-2) project extended the analysis of the International Space Station (ISS) surface microbiome, sampling eight locations over 14 months. Employing sterile wipes, propidium monoazide (PMA) treatment for viable cells, shotgun metagenomics, and culture analysis, the study aimed to characterize bacterial and fungal communities. Key findings include the dominance of Staphylococcus sp. and Malassezia sp. as the most prevalent bacterial and fungal species, respectively, with the overall microbiome reflecting human skin-associated organisms. While significant temporal changes in microbial populations were observed, no spatial differences were found. Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) gene profiles remained stable over a five-year period (combining MT-1 and MT-2 data), with 29 genes detected, macrolide/lincosamide/streptogramin resistance being the most widespread. Eighty-two metagenome-assembled genomes (MAGs) were reconstructed, indicating a functional propensity for amino acid utilization. Strong co-occurrence associations between bacterial and fungal genera were identified, and the average microbial load was 3.0 × 10^5 cfu/m^2. This study provided a comprehensive characterization of the ISS surface microbiome, covering microbial burden, species prevalence, temporal dynamics, resistome, functional capabilities, and microbial interactions.
impact: This study offers crucial data for developing informed policies for future space missions, aiming to ensure an ISS surface microbiome that promotes astronaut health and preserves spacecraft integrity. Understanding the dynamics of microbial communities, their functional capabilities, and antimicrobial resistance in a unique built environment like the ISS is vital for long-duration space exploration and crew well-being.

title: Detection of Target Genes for Drug Repurposing to Treat Skeletal Muscle Atrophy in Mice Flown in Spaceflight
abstract: Skeletal muscle atrophy is a common condition in aging, diabetes, and in long duration spaceflights due to microgravity. This article investigates multi-modal gene disease and disease drug networks via link prediction algorithms to select drugs for repurposing to treat skeletal muscle atrophy. Key target genes that cause muscle atrophy in the left and right extensor digitorum longus muscle tissue, gastrocnemius, quadriceps, and the left and right soleus muscles are detected using graph theoretic network analysis, by mining the transcriptomic datasets collected from mice flown in spaceflight made available by GeneLab. We identified the top muscle atrophy gene regulators by the Pearson correlation and Bayesian Markov blanket method. The gene disease knowledge graph was constructed using the scalable precision medicine knowledge engine. We computed node embeddings, random walk measures from the networks. Graph convolutional networks, graph neural networks, random forest, and gradient boosting methods were trained using the embeddings, network features for predicting links and ranking top gene-disease associations for skeletal muscle atrophy. Drugs were selected and a disease drug knowledge graph was constructed. Link prediction methods were applied to the disease drug networks to identify top ranked drugs for therapeutic treatment of skeletal muscle atrophy. The graph convolution network performs best in link prediction based on receiver operating characteristic curves and prediction accuracies. The key genes involved in skeletal muscle atrophy are associated with metabolic and neurodegenerative diseases. The drugs selected for repurposing using the graph convolution network method were nutrients, corticosteroids, anti-inflammatory medications, and others related to insulin.
headings: 2.2. Finding Regulatory Relationships between Gene Pairs (Stage 1)
Graph Concepts and Properties for Analysis of GDKG and DDKG
Link Prediction Using GCN and Other ML Methods
summary: This NASA Space Biology publication describes a computational approach using multi-modal gene-disease and disease-drug networks to identify target genes and repurpose existing drugs for treating skeletal muscle atrophy. Researchers analyzed transcriptomic datasets from mice flown in spaceflight (GeneLab) to detect key gene regulators of muscle atrophy in various leg muscles. They constructed gene-disease and disease-drug knowledge graphs and employed machine learning methods like Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN), Graph Neural Networks (GNN), Random Forest, and Gradient Boosting for link prediction. GCN demonstrated the best performance in identifying top-ranked drugs. The study found that key genes involved in skeletal muscle atrophy are associated with metabolic and neurodegenerative diseases, and identified potential repurposed drugs including nutrients, corticosteroids, anti-inflammatory medications, and insulin-related compounds.
impact: This research provides a powerful computational framework, leveraging machine learning and knowledge graphs, to accelerate the discovery of therapeutic targets and drug repurposing strategies for skeletal muscle atrophy. This is particularly impactful for addressing muscle wasting experienced by astronauts during long-duration spaceflights due to microgravity, and also holds significant relevance for terrestrial conditions like aging and diabetes. By identifying existing drugs, this method could potentially shorten the timeline for developing effective treatments, benefiting both space exploration and human health on Earth.
theme: Space Biology; Computational Drug Repurposing; Machine Learning in Biomedicine; Skeletal Muscle Atrophy Research.
original_title: Detection of Target Genes for Drug Repurposing to Treat Skeletal Muscle Atrophy in Mice Flown in Spaceflight

title: Release of CD36-associated cell-free mitochondrial DNA and RNA as a hallmark of space environment response
abstract: A detailed understanding of how spaceflight affects human health is essential for long-term space exploration. Liquid biopsies allow for minimally-invasive multi-omics assessments that can resolve the molecular heterogeneity of internal tissues. Here, we report initial results from the JAXA Cell-Free Epigenome Study, a liquid biopsy study with six astronauts who resided on the International Space Station (ISS) for more than 120 days. Analysis of plasma cell-free RNA (cfRNA) collected before, during, and after spaceflight confirms previously reported mitochondrial dysregulation in space. Screening with 361 cell surface marker antibodies identifies a mitochondrial DNA-enriched fraction associated with the scavenger receptor CD36. RNA-sequencing of the CD36 fraction reveals tissue-enriched RNA species, suggesting the plasma mitochondrial components originated from various tissues. We compare our plasma cfRNA data to mouse plasma cfRNA data from a previous JAXA mission, which had used on-board artificial gravity, and discover a link between microgravity and the observed mitochondrial responses.
headings: Plasma cfRNA analysis of six astronauts
Mitochondrial DNA quantification and statistical analysis
Visualization of mapped RNA-seq and DNA-seq reads
Antibody screening and immunopurification of plasma fraction
summary: This JAXA Cell-Free Epigenome Study analyzed plasma cell-free RNA (cfRNA) and DNA from six astronauts on the ISS (over 120 days). It confirmed mitochondrial dysregulation in space and identified a novel CD36-associated plasma fraction enriched with mitochondrial DNA (cf-mtDNA) and tissue-enriched RNA, suggesting a multi-tissue origin of these components. By comparing with mouse plasma cfRNA data from an artificial gravity mission, the study links microgravity to the observed mitochondrial responses, highlighting the release of CD36-associated cf-mtDNA and RNA as a hallmark of space environment response.
impact: The findings provide crucial insights into how spaceflight impacts human health, essential for long-duration space exploration. By utilizing minimally-invasive liquid biopsies, the study offers a multi-omics approach to understand molecular changes. The identification of CD36-associated cell-free mitochondrial DNA and RNA serves as a potential novel biomarker for monitoring physiological responses to the space environment, with implications for developing countermeasures against microgravity-induced mitochondrial dysregulation.

title: Increasing the Number of Unloading/Reambulation Cycles does not Adversely Impact Body Composition and Lumbar Bone Mineral Density but Reduces Tissue Sensitivity
abstract: A single exposure to hindlimb unloading leads to changes in body mass, body composition and bone, but the consequences of multiple exposures are not yet understood. Within a 18wk period, adult C57BL/6 male mice were exposed to one (1x-HLU), two (2x-HLU) or three (3x-HLU) cycles of 2 wk of hindlimb unloading (HLU) followed by 4 wk of reambulation (RA), or served as ambulatory age-matched controls. In vivo µCT longitudinally tracked changes in abdominal adipose and lean tissues, lumbar vertebral apparent volumetric bone mineral density (vBMD) and upper hindlimb muscle cross-sectional area before and after the final HLU and RA cycle. Significant decreases in total adipose tissue and vertebral vBMD were observed such that all unloaded animals reached similar values after the final unloading cycle. However, the magnitude of these losses diminished in mice undergoing their 2nd or 3rd HLU cycle. Irrespective of the number of HLU/RA cycles, total adipose tissue and vertebral vBMD recovered and were no different from age-matched controls after the final RA period. In contrast, upper hindlimb muscle cross-sectional area was significantly lower than controls in all unloaded groups after the final RA period. These results suggest that tissues in the abdominal region are more resilient to multiple bouts of unloading and more amenable to recovery during reambulation than the peripheral musculoskeletal system.
headings: Loss of Bone, Adipose and Lean Tissue during First, Second, or Third HLU Cycle
Recovery of Bone, Adipose and Lean Tissue during First, Second, or Third RA Cycle
Effect of Number of Unloading/Reambulation Cycles on Tissue Volume/Mass after last RA Cycle
summary: This study investigated the effects of repeated cycles of hindlimb unloading (HLU) and reambulation (RA) on body composition, bone mineral density, and muscle mass in C57BL/6 mice. Over an 18-week period, mice were exposed to one, two, or three cycles of 2-week HLU followed by 4-week RA. While initial HLU cycles led to significant decreases in total adipose tissue and lumbar vertebral vBMD, the magnitude of these losses diminished in subsequent cycles, suggesting adaptation. After the final RA period, total adipose tissue and vertebral vBMD fully recovered to control levels, regardless of the number of cycles. However, upper hindlimb muscle cross-sectional area remained significantly lower than controls in all unloaded groups after the final RA, indicating less resilience or recovery capacity. The findings suggest that abdominal tissues are more resilient and recover better from multiple unloading bouts than the peripheral musculoskeletal system.
impact: This research provides crucial insights into the physiological adaptation and recovery responses to repeated bouts of unloading, relevant to understanding the effects of repeated spaceflight missions or intermittent gravity exposure on astronauts. The differential recovery observed between abdominal tissues (adipose, bone) and peripheral muscle highlights the need for targeted countermeasures and monitoring strategies. The finding that tissues become less sensitive to subsequent unloading cycles suggests a potential for adaptation that could mitigate some long-term health risks associated with space travel or periods of immobility on Earth.
theme: Repeated stress response and tissue adaptation in musculoskeletal and metabolic systems under simulated microgravity conditions.
original_title: Increasing the number of unloading/reambulation cycles does not adversely impac body composition and lumbar bone mineral density but reduces tissue sensitivity

title: Bone shaft bending strength index is unaffected by exercise and unloading in mice
abstract: Anthropologists frequently use the shaft bending strength index to infer the physical activity levels of humans living in the past from their lower limb bone remains. This index is typically calculated as the ratio of bone shaft second moments of area about orthogonal principal axes (i.e. Imax/Imin). Individuals with high Imax/Imin values are inferred to have been very active, whereas individuals with low values are inferred to have been more sedentary. However, there is little direct evidence that activity has a causal and predictable effect on the shaft bending strength index. Here, we report the results of two experiments that were designed to test the model within which anthropologists commonly interpret the shaft bending strength index. In the first experiment, mice were treated daily with treadmill exercise for 1 month to simulate a high-activity lifestyle. In the second experiment, in an attempt to simulate a low-activity lifestyle, functional weight-bearing was removed from the hindlimbs of mice for 1 month. Femoral mid-shaft structure was determined with μCT. We found that while exercise resulted in significant enhancement of Imax and Imin compared with controls, it failed to significantly increase the Imax/Imin index. Similarly, stunted bone growth caused by unloading resulted in significantly diminished Imax and Imin compared with controls, but low activity did not lead to significantly decreased Imax/Imin compared with normal activity. Together, these results suggest that caution is required when the bone shaft bending strength index is used to reconstruct the activity levels of past humans.
summary: This study investigated whether physical activity levels causally affect the bone shaft bending strength index (Imax/Imin), a metric often used by anthropologists to infer activity in past human populations. Two experiments were conducted in mice: one simulating high activity (treadmill exercise) and another simulating low activity (hindlimb unloading). While exercise significantly increased both Imax and Imin, and unloading significantly decreased them, neither intervention significantly altered the Imax/Imin ratio compared to controls. This suggests that the Imax/Imin index may not be a reliable indicator of activity levels.
impact: The findings challenge the common anthropological practice of using the bone shaft bending strength index (Imax/Imin) to reconstruct physical activity levels of past humans. The results indicate that this index might not be causally affected by activity, urging caution and re-evaluation of its utility in bioarchaeology and related fields.
theme: Bone functional adaptation, biomechanics of skeletal loading, and the reliability of bioarchaeological indicators for physical activity.
original_title: Bone shaft bending strength index is unaffected by exercise and unloading in mice

title: Focal enhancement of the skeleton to exercise correlates with responsivity of bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells rather than peak external forces
abstract: Force magnitudes have been suggested to drive the structural response of bone to exercise. As importantly, the degree to which any given bone can adapt to functional challenges may be enabled, or constrained, by regional variation in the capacity of marrow progenitors to differentiate into bone-forming cells. Here, we investigate the relationship between bone adaptation and mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) responsivity in growing mice subject to exercise. First, using a force plate, we show that peak external forces generated by forelimbs during quadrupedal locomotion are significantly higher than hindlimb forces. Second, by subjecting mice to treadmill running and then measuring bone structure with μCT, we show that skeletal effects of exercise are site-specific but not defined by load magnitudes. Specifically, in the forelimb, where external forces generated by running were highest, exercise failed to augment diaphyseal structure in either the humerus or radius, nor did it affect humeral trabecular structure. In contrast, in the ulna, femur and tibia, exercise led to significant enhancements of diaphyseal bone areas and moments of area. Trabecular structure was also enhanced by running in the femur and tibia. Finally, using flow cytometry, we show that marrow-derived MSCs in the femur are more responsive to exercise-induced loads than humeral cells, such that running significantly lowered MSC populations only in the femur. Together, these data suggest that the ability of the progenitor population to differentiate toward osteoblastogenesis may correlate better with bone structural adaptation than peak external forces caused by exercise.
headings: Effects of running on skeletal structure
summary: This study investigated the relationship between bone adaptation and mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) responsivity in growing mice subjected to treadmill exercise. While forelimbs generated significantly higher peak external forces during locomotion compared to hindlimbs, exercise-induced bone structural enhancements (diaphyseal and trabecular) were observed in the ulna, femur, and tibia, but not in the humerus or radius. Notably, exercise significantly lowered marrow-derived MSC populations only in the femur, indicating a greater cellular responsivity in this specific bone. The findings suggest that the ability of the progenitor population to differentiate toward osteoblastogenesis correlates better with bone structural adaptation than the peak external forces caused by exercise.
impact: This research challenges the conventional view that bone adaptation to exercise is solely driven by peak external forces. It emphasizes the critical, site-specific role of the intrinsic responsiveness of bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (osteoprogenitors) in determining a bone's capacity for structural adaptation. This understanding is significant for developing more effective strategies to promote bone health, particularly in scenarios involving altered mechanical loading, by focusing on enhancing cellular responsiveness rather than just load magnitude.
theme: The primary theme is the mechanisms underlying bone adaptation to mechanical loading, specifically investigating whether bone's structural response to exercise is dictated by external force magnitudes or by the local responsivity of bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (osteoprogenitors).
original_title: Focal enhancement of the skeleton to exercise correlates to mesenchymal stem cell responsivity rather than peak external forces.

title: Cytoskeletal Configuration Modulates Mechanically Induced Changes in Mesenchymal Stem Cell Osteogenesis, Morphology, and Stiffness.
abstract: Mesenchymal stem cells (MSC) responding to mechanical cues generated by physical activity is critical for skeletal development and remodeling. Here, we utilized low intensity vibrations (LIV) as a physiologically relevant mechanical signal and hypothesized that the confined cytoskeletal configuration imposed by 2D culture will enable human bone marrow MSCs (hBMSC) to respond more robustly when LIV is applied in-plane (horizontal-LIV) rather than out-of-plane (vertical-LIV). All LIV signals enhanced hBMSC proliferation, osteogenic differentiation, and upregulated genes associated with cytoskeletal structure. The cellular response was more pronounced at higher frequencies (100 Hz vs 30 Hz) and when applied in the horizontal plane. Horizontal but not vertical LIV realigned the cell cytoskeleton, culminating in increased cell stiffness. Our results show that applying very small oscillatory motions within the primary cell attachment plane, rather than perpendicular to it, amplifies the cell’s response to LIV, ostensibly facilitating a more effective transfer of intracellular forces. Transcriptional and structural changes in particular with horizontal LIV, together with the strong frequency dependency of the signal, emphasize the importance of intracellular cytoskeletal configuration in sensing and responding to high-frequency mechanical signals at low intensities.
headings: Higher frequency enhanced gene expression induced by both horizontal and vertical LIV
LIV changes in cell stiffness and orientation
Relative role of LIV frequency and acceleration
summary: This NASA Space Biology study investigated how the orientation of low-intensity vibrations (LIV)—applied either in-plane (horizontal) or out-of-plane (vertical)—influences human bone marrow mesenchymal stem cell (hBMSC) response, particularly concerning cytoskeletal configuration. The researchers found that all LIV applications enhanced hBMSC proliferation and osteogenic differentiation, and upregulated genes related to cytoskeletal structure. Critically, the cellular response was more pronounced at higher frequencies (100 Hz vs 30 Hz) and when LIV was applied horizontally. Horizontal LIV, unlike vertical LIV, caused cytoskeletal realignment and increased cell stiffness, suggesting a more effective transfer of intracellular forces. These results underscore the significant role of intracellular cytoskeletal configuration in sensing and responding to high-frequency, low-intensity mechanical signals, especially when mechanical stimuli are applied within the primary cell attachment plane.
impact: This research provides crucial insights into the mechanobiology of mesenchymal stem cells, particularly how the direction and frequency of mechanical stimuli influence cellular responses critical for skeletal development and remodeling. Understanding that in-plane mechanical signals more effectively modulate cytoskeletal configuration and enhance osteogenesis could inform the design of targeted mechanical therapies, such as optimized low-intensity vibration protocols, to promote bone formation and combat conditions like osteoporosis by enhancing the efficacy of physical activity or rehabilitation strategies, especially in environments like space where mechanical loading is altered.
theme: Mechanobiology, Mesenchymal Stem Cells, Cytoskeleton, Osteogenesis, Mechanical Stimulation, Low Intensity Vibration, Cellular Response, Biophysics.
original_title: Cytoskeletal configuration modulates mechanically induced changes in mesenchymal stem cell osteogenesis, morphology, and stiffness.

title: Genetic and tissue level muscle-bone interactions during unloading and reambulation.
abstract: Little is known about interactions between muscle and bone during the removal and application of mechanical signals. Here, we applied 3wk of hindlimb unloading followed by 3wk of reambulation to a genetically heterogeneous population of 352 adult mice and tested the hypothesis that changes in muscle are associated with changes in bone at the level of the tissue and the genome. During unloading and relative to normally ambulating control mice, most mice lost muscle and cortical bone with large variability across the population. During reambulation, individual mice regained bone and muscle at different rates. Across mice, changes in muscle and trabecular/cortical bone were not correlated to each other during unloading or reambulation. For unloading, we found one significant quantitative trait locus (QTL) for muscle area and five QTLs for cortical bone without overlap between mechano-sensitive muscle and cortical bone QTLs (but some overlap between muscle and trabecular QTLs). The low correlations between morphological changes in muscle and bone, together with the largely distinct genetic regulation of the response indicate that the premise of a muscle-bone unit that co-adjusts its size during (un)loading may need to be reassessed.
headings: Changes in muscle and cortical bone assessed by in vivo µCT
summary: This study investigated muscle-bone interactions during 3 weeks of hindlimb unloading followed by 3 weeks of reambulation in 352 adult mice. It aimed to determine if changes in muscle are associated with changes in bone at both tissue and genomic levels. During unloading, most mice experienced muscle and cortical bone loss with significant variability across the population. Upon reambulation, bone and muscle were regained at varying individual rates. Crucially, changes in muscle and trabecular/cortical bone were not correlated with each other during either unloading or reambulation. Genetic analysis for unloading revealed distinct quantitative trait loci (QTLs) for muscle area and cortical bone, with no overlap between these mechano-sensitive muscle and cortical bone QTLs (though some overlap was observed with trabecular QTLs). The findings suggest that the premise of a co-adjusting 'muscle-bone unit' during mechanical loading and unloading may need to be reassessed due to low morphological correlations and largely distinct genetic regulation of their responses.
impact: This research significantly challenges the long-held 'muscle-bone unit' concept, suggesting that muscle and bone may not co-adjust their size or share common genetic regulation in response to changes in mechanical loading. This has profound implications for understanding and mitigating disuse atrophy and facilitating recovery in contexts such as spaceflight, bed rest, or immobilization, where both tissues are significantly impacted. By demonstrating the heterogeneity of responses and distinct genetic pathways, the study points towards the need for more targeted interventions that account for independent tissue responses.
theme: Muscle-bone interactions; mechanical unloading and reambulation; genetic regulation of tissue adaptation; reassessment of the muscle-bone unit concept; physiological responses to altered gravity (disuse atrophy).
original_title: Genetic and tissue level muscle-bone interactions during unloading and reambulation.

title: Osteocyte apoptosis caused by hindlimb unloading is required to trigger osteocyte RANKL production and subsequent resorption of cortical and trabecular bone in mice femurs.
abstract: Osteocyte apoptosis is essential to activate bone remodeling in response to fatigue microdamage and estrogen withdrawal, such that apoptosis inhibition in vivo prevents the onset of osteoclastic resorption. Osteocyte apoptosis has also been spatially linked to bone resorption owing to disuse, but whether apoptosis plays a similar controlling role is unclear. We, therefore, 1) evaluated the spatial and temporal effects of disuse from hindlimb unloading (HLU) on osteocyte apoptosis, receptor activator of NF-κB ligand (RANKL) expression, bone resorption, and loss in mouse femora, and 2) tested whether osteocyte apoptosis was required to activate osteoclastic activity in cortical and trabecular bone by treating animals subjected to HLU with the pan-caspase apoptosis inhibitor, QVD (quinolyl-valyl-O-methylaspartyl-[-2,6-difluorophenoxy]-methylketone). Immunohistochemistry was used to identify apoptotic and RANKL-producing osteocytes in femoral diaphysis and distal trabecular bone, and μCT was used to determine the extent of trabecular bone loss owing to HLU. In both cortical and trabecular bone, 5 days of HLU increased osteocyte apoptosis significantly (3- and 4-fold, respectively, p < 0.05 versus Ctrl). At day 14, the apoptotic osteocyte number in femoral cortices declined to near control levels but remained elevated in trabeculae (3-fold versus Ctrl, p < 0.05). The number of osteocytes producing RANKL in both bone compartments was also significantly increased at day 5 of HLU (>1.5-fold versus Ctrl, p <0.05) and further increased by day 14. Increases in osteocyte apoptosis and RANKL production preceded increases in bone resorption at both endocortical and trabecular surfaces. QVD completely inhibited not only the HLU-triggered increases in osteocyte apoptosis but also RANKL production and activation of bone resorption at both sites. Finally, μCT studies revealed that apoptosis inhibition completely prevented the trabecular bone loss caused by HLU. Together these data indicate that osteocyte apoptosis plays a central and controlling role in triggering osteocyte RANKL production and the activation of new resorption leading to bone loss in disuse.
