QVD effects on osteocyte RANKL expression
Bone architecture assessment via micro computed tomography (μCT)
Immunohistochemistry (IHC) for osteocyte apoptosis and RANKL expression
Cortical bone osteocyte apoptosis, osteocyte RANKL expression, and bone resorption with HLU
Trabecular bone osteocyte apoptosis, RANKL expression, and bone resorption after HLU
Effects of the pan-caspase inhibitor QVD on osteoclastogenesis and osteocyte RANKL expression in vitro
In vivo inhibition of osteocyte apoptosis
summary: This study demonstrates that osteocyte apoptosis, induced by hindlimb unloading (HLU), is a necessary trigger for subsequent osteocyte RANKL production and the activation of bone resorption in both cortical and trabecular bone of mouse femurs. HLU significantly increased osteocyte apoptosis and RANKL expression, preceding observed increases in bone resorption and loss. Critically, pharmacological inhibition of osteocyte apoptosis using the pan-caspase inhibitor QVD completely prevented HLU-triggered increases in apoptosis, RANKL production, bone resorption, and ultimately, trabecular bone loss. These findings establish osteocyte apoptosis as a central, controlling mechanism for disuse-induced bone loss.
impact: This research reveals a fundamental mechanistic pathway governing disuse-induced bone loss, a significant challenge in spaceflight where microgravity causes rapid bone demineralization. By identifying osteocyte apoptosis as a required initial event for RANKL-mediated bone resorption, this study provides a crucial target for developing countermeasures to prevent or mitigate bone loss in astronauts during long-duration space missions, as well as for terrestrial conditions involving disuse osteopenia.
theme: Space Biology: Bone remodeling and loss mechanisms in response to disuse and microgravity environments.
original_title: Osteocyte apoptosis caused by hindlimb unloading is required to trigger osteocyte RANKL production and subsequent resorption of cortical and trabecular bone in mice femurs.

title: Differential Single Cell Responses of Embryonic Stem Cells Versus Embryoid Bodies to Gravity Mechanostimulation
abstract: The forces generated by gravity have shaped life on Earth and impact gene expression and morphogenesis during early development. Conversely, disuse on Earth or during spaceflight, reduces normal mechanical loading of organisms, resulting in altered cell and tissue function. Although gravity mechanical loading in adult mammals is known to promote increased cell proliferation and differentiation, little is known about how distinct cell types respond to gravity mechanostimulation during early development. In this study we sought to understand, with single cell RNA-sequencing resolution, how a 60-min pulse of 50 g hypergravity (HG)/5 kPa hydrostatic pressure, influences transcriptomic regulation of developmental processes in the embryoid body (EB) model. Our study included both day-9 EBs and progenitor mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) with or without the HG pulse. Single cell t-distributed stochastic neighbor mapping shows limited transcriptome shifts in response to the HG pulse in either ESCs or EBs; this pulse however, induces greater positional shifts in EB mapping compared to ESCs, indicating the influence of mechanotransduction is more pronounced in later states of cell commitment within the developmental program. More specifically, HG resulted in upregulation of self-renewal and angiogenesis genes in ESCs, while in EBs, HG loading was associated with upregulation of Gene Ontology-pathways for multicellular development, mechanical signal transduction, and DNA damage repair. Cluster transcriptome analysis of the EBs show HG promotes maintenance of transitory cell phenotypes in early development; including EB cluster co-expression of markers for progenitor, post-implant epiblast, and primitive endoderm phenotypes with HG pulse but expression exclusivity in the non-pulsed clusters. Pseudotime analysis identified three branching cell types susceptible to HG induction of cell fate decisions. In totality, this study provides novel evidence that ESC maintenance and EB development can be regulated by gravity mechanostimulation and that stem cells committed to a differentiation program are more sensitive to gravity-induced changes to their transcriptome.
headings: Single cell library preparation, sequencing, analysis, and visualization
1/3 of mechanoregulated genes are shared between ESCs and day 9 EBs
Gene ontology pathway analysis demonstrates HG pulse correlates differentiation and developmental programs to increased mechanotransduction signaling pathways
HG pulse increases EB growth markers in extra-embryonic tissue cell types and pre- and post-implant epiblasts
HG pulse increases transcriptomic signature of transitory cells
HG pulse introduces unique cell signatures but does not cause divergence from developmental trajectory in germ layer lineages
summary: This study investigated the single-cell transcriptomic responses of mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs) and day-9 embryoid bodies (EBs) to a 60-minute pulse of 50g hypergravity (HG) and 5 kPa hydrostatic pressure. Using single-cell RNA sequencing, the researchers found that while overall transcriptome shifts were limited, EBs exhibited greater positional shifts in their mapping compared to ESCs, indicating that cells already committed to a differentiation program are more sensitive to mechanotransduction signals. Specifically, HG upregulated self-renewal and angiogenesis genes in ESCs. In contrast, in EBs, HG loading was associated with the upregulation of Gene Ontology pathways related to multicellular development, mechanical signal transduction, and DNA damage repair. Cluster analysis of EBs revealed that HG promoted the maintenance of transitory cell phenotypes, such as progenitor, post-implant epiblast, and primitive endoderm markers. Pseudotime analysis identified three branching cell types whose cell fate decisions were susceptible to HG induction. The study concludes that both ESC maintenance and EB development are regulated by gravity mechanostimulation, with stem cells committed to differentiation showing higher sensitivity to gravity-induced transcriptomic changes.
impact: This research provides novel insights into the fundamental role of gravity mechanostimulation in regulating early developmental processes and stem cell differentiation at a single-cell level. Understanding the differential sensitivity of embryonic stem cells versus more committed embryoid bodies to gravity's mechanical cues has significant implications for space biology, informing how altered gravity environments during spaceflight might impact embryonic development and overall organismal health. Furthermore, these findings contribute to a deeper understanding of mechanotransduction pathways in developmental biology and could potentially guide strategies in regenerative medicine by using mechanical stimuli to control stem cell fate and tissue engineering.
theme: The differential single-cell transcriptomic responses of embryonic stem cells and embryoid bodies to gravity mechanostimulation and its implications for early development and cell fate.
original_title: Differential Single Cell Responses of Embryonic Stem Cells Versus Embryoid Bodies to Gravity Mechanostimulation

title: Macrophages inhibit Aspergillus fumigatus germination and neutrophil-mediated fungal killing.
abstract: In immunocompromised individuals, Aspergillus fumigatus causes invasive fungal disease that is often difficult to treat. Exactly how immune mechanisms control A. fumigatus in immunocompetent individuals remains unclear. Here, we use transparent zebrafish larvae to visualize and quantify neutrophil and macrophage behaviors in response to different A. fumigatus strains. We find that macrophages form dense clusters around spores, establishing a protective niche for fungal survival. Macrophages exert these protective effects by inhibiting fungal germination, thereby inhibiting subsequent neutrophil recruitment and neutrophil-mediated killing. Germination directly drives fungal clearance as faster-growing CEA10-derived strains are killed better in vivo than slower-growing Af293-derived strains. Additionally, a CEA10 pyrG-deficient strain with impaired germination is cleared less effectively by neutrophils. Host inflammatory activation through Myd88 is required for killing of a CEA10-derived strain but not sufficient for killing of an Af293-derived strain, further demonstrating the role of fungal-intrinsic differences in the ability of a host to clear an infection. Altogether, we describe a new role for macrophages in the persistence of A. fumigatus and highlight the ability of different A. fumigatus strains to adopt diverse modes of virulence.

summary: This study utilized transparent zebrafish larvae to visualize immune responses to *Aspergillus fumigatus*, revealing an unexpected role for macrophages. Macrophages were found to form dense clusters around *A. fumigatus* spores, inhibiting fungal germination and subsequent neutrophil recruitment and killing. This activity created a 'protective niche' for fungal survival, contributing to persistence. The research demonstrated that fungal germination directly drives neutrophil-mediated clearance, with faster-germinating strains (CEA10-derived) being killed more effectively than slower-germinating ones (Af293-derived). Host inflammatory activation via Myd88 was essential for clearing CEA10 but insufficient for Af293, highlighting the significance of fungal-intrinsic differences in determining host outcomes. Overall, the study describes a novel mechanism by which macrophages facilitate *A. fumigatus* persistence and underscores the diverse virulence strategies employed by different fungal strains.
impact: The findings challenge the conventional understanding of macrophage function in fungal infections, demonstrating a role in promoting *A. fumigatus* persistence rather than solely clearance. This insight into host-pathogen dynamics, particularly the macrophage-mediated inhibition of fungal germination, could pave the way for novel therapeutic strategies to combat difficult-to-treat invasive fungal diseases in immunocompromised individuals. By highlighting strain-specific virulence factors and the nuanced host immune responses, the study emphasizes the need for tailored approaches in diagnosis and treatment. The use of the transparent zebrafish model offers a powerful tool for real-time visualization of immune cell behaviors, advancing our understanding of infection pathogenesis.

title: Contributions of Spore Secondary Metabolites to UV-C Protection and Virulence Vary in Different Aspergillus fumigatus Strains
abstract: Fungi are versatile organisms which thrive in hostile environments, including the International Space Station (ISS). Several isolates of the human pathogen Aspergillus fumigatus have been found contaminating the ISS, an environment with increased exposure to UV radiation. Secondary metabolites (SMs) in spores, such as melanins, have been shown to protect spores from UV radiation in other fungi. To test the hypothesis that melanin and other known spore SMs provide UV protection to A. fumigatus isolates, we subjected SM spore mutants to UV-C radiation. We found that 1,8-dihydroxynaphthalene (DHN)-melanin mutants of two clinical A. fumigatus strains (Af293 and CEA17) but not an ISS-isolated strain (IF1SW-F4) were more sensitive to UV-C than their respective wild-type (WT) strains. Because DHN-melanin has been shown to shield A. fumigatus from the host immune system, we examined all DHN mutants for virulence in the zebrafish model of invasive aspergillosis. Following recent studies highlighting the pathogenic variability of different A. fumigatus isolates, we found DHN-melanin to be a virulence factor in CEA17 and IF1SW-F4 but not Af293. Three additional spore metabolites were examined in Af293, where fumiquinazoline also showed UV-C-protective properties, but two other spore metabolites, monomethylsulochrin and fumigaclavine, provided no UV-C-protective properties. Virulence tests of these three SM spore mutants indicated a slight increase in virulence of the monomethylsulochrin deletion strain. Taken together, this work suggests differential roles of specific spore metabolites across Aspergillus isolates and by types of environmental stress.

title: Regulation of Hemocytes in Drosophila Requires dappled Cytochrome b5
abstract: A major category of mutant hematopoietic phenotypes in Drosophila is melanotic tumors or nodules, which consist of abnormal and overproliferated blood cells, similar to granulomas. Our analyses of the melanotic mutant dappled have revealed a novel type of gene involved in blood cell regulation. The dappled gene is an essential gene that encodes cytochrome b5, a conserved hemoprotein that participates in electron transfer in multiple biochemical reactions and pathways. Viable mutations of dappled cause melanotic nodules and hemocyte misregulation during both hematopoietic waves of development. The sexes are similarly affected, but hemocyte number is different in females and males of both mutants and wild type. Additionally, initial tests show that curcumin enhances the dappled melanotic phenotype and establish screening of endogenous and xenobiotic compounds as a route for analysis of cytochrome b5 function. Overall, dappled provides a tractable genetic model for cytochrome b5, which has been difficult to study in higher organisms.
summary: This study identifies the `dappled` gene in Drosophila as encoding Cytochrome b5, a conserved hemoprotein essential for electron transfer. Mutations in `dappled` lead to melanotic nodules and misregulated hemocytes, resembling granulomas, affecting both hematopoietic waves of development. The research establishes `dappled` as a tractable genetic model for studying Cytochrome b5 function, noting sex-specific differences in hemocyte numbers and demonstrating that compounds like curcumin can modulate the melanotic phenotype, thus providing a method for screening compounds relevant to Cytochrome b5.
impact: This research provides a novel and tractable genetic model in Drosophila (`dappled`) for investigating Cytochrome b5, a hemoprotein notoriously difficult to study in higher organisms. It offers critical insights into the genetic regulation of hematopoiesis and immune response, specifically linking Cytochrome b5 to blood cell development and the formation of granuloma-like structures. Furthermore, the study's approach of screening endogenous and xenobiotic compounds to analyze Cytochrome b5 function opens avenues for potential drug discovery, toxicology studies, and understanding metabolic pathways relevant to organismal health, which is foundational to Space Biology's interest in fundamental biological processes and their resilience.
theme: Genetic regulation of hematopoiesis and immune system function through the study of conserved metabolic enzymes in a model organism, relevant to understanding fundamental biological processes in diverse environments.
original_title: Regulation of hemocytes in Drosophila requires dappled cytochrome b5.

title: A novel blue-light phototropic response is revealed in roots of Arabidopsis thaliana in microgravity
abstract:
Main conclusion Blue-light positive phototropism in roots is masked by gravity and revealed in conditions of microgravity. In addition, the magnitude of red-light positive phototropic curvature is correlated to the magnitude of gravity.
Due to their sessile nature, plants utilize environmental cues to grow and respond to their surroundings. Two of these cues, light and gravity, play a substantial role in plant orientation and directed growth movements (tropisms). However, very little is currently known about the interaction between light- (phototropic) and gravity (gravitropic)-mediated growth responses. Utilizing the European Modular Cultivation System on board the International Space Station, we investigated the interaction between phototropic and gravitropic responses in three Arabidopsis thaliana genotypes, Landsberg wild type, as well as mutants of phytochrome A and phytochrome B. Onboard centrifuges were used to create a fractional gravity gradient ranging from reduced gravity up to 1g. A novel positive blue-light phototropic response of roots was observed during conditions of microgravity, and this response was attenuated at 0.1g. In addition, a red-light pretreatment of plants enhanced the magnitude of positive phototropic curvature of roots in response to blue illumination. In addition, a positive phototropic response of roots was observed when exposed to red light, and a decrease in response was gradual and correlated with the increase in gravity. The positive red-light phototropic curvature of hypocotyls when exposed to red light was also confirmed. Both red-light and blue-light phototropic responses were also shown to be affected by directional light intensity. To our knowledge, this is the first characterization of a positive blue-light phototropic response in Arabidopsis roots, as well as the first description of the relationship between these phototropic responses in fractional or reduced gravities.

Continued technical improvements to space experiments on plant tropisms
summary: This NASA Space Biology study investigated the interaction between light-mediated (phototropic) and gravity-mediated (gravitropic) growth responses in Arabidopsis thaliana roots and hypocotyls using the European Modular Cultivation System on the International Space Station. Plants were exposed to a fractional gravity gradient from microgravity up to 1g. The study revealed a novel positive blue-light phototropic response in roots that is masked by gravity, becoming apparent only in microgravity conditions and attenuated at 0.1g. Additionally, a positive red-light phototropic response in roots was observed, with its magnitude decreasing proportionally to increasing gravity. Red-light pretreatment enhanced the blue-light phototropic response in roots. The positive red-light phototropic curvature of hypocotyls was confirmed, and both blue-light and red-light phototropic responses were found to be affected by directional light intensity. This research represents the first characterization of a positive blue-light phototropic response in Arabidopsis roots and the first description of the relationship between these phototropic responses under fractional or reduced gravities.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of how gravity influences and potentially masks intrinsic plant growth responses, particularly phototropism in roots. By demonstrating a blue-light phototropic response in roots that is only revealed in microgravity, it highlights the complex interplay between environmental cues like light and gravity in plant orientation. These findings are crucial for developing strategies for plant growth in space environments, supporting long-duration space missions, and understanding fundamental plant adaptation mechanisms on Earth and beyond.

title: Plant cell proliferation and growth are altered by microgravity conditions in spaceflight.
abstract: Discovering the adaptation mechanisms of plants to the space environment is essential for supporting human space exploration. Transcriptomic analyses allow the identification of adaptation response pathways by detecting changes in gene expression at the global genome level caused by the main factors of the space environment, namely altered gravity and cosmic radiation. This article reviews transcriptomic studies carried out from plants grown in spaceflights and in different ground-based microgravity simulators. Despite differences in plant growth conditions, these studies have shown that cell wall remodeling, oxidative stress, defense response, and photosynthesis are common altered processes in plants grown under spaceflight conditions. European scientists have significantly contributed to the acquisition of this knowledge, e.g., by showing the role of red light in the adaptation response of plants (EMCS experiments) and the mechanisms of cellular response and adaptation mostly affecting cell cycle regulation, using cell cultures in microgravity simulators.

title: Light and gravity signals synergize in modulating plant development
abstract: Tropisms are growth-mediated plant movements that help plants to respond to changes in environmental stimuli. The availability of water and light, as well as the presence of a constant gravity vector, are all environmental stimuli that plants sense and respond to via directed growth movements (tropisms). The plant response to gravity (gravitropism) and the response to unidirectional light (phototropism) have long been shown to be interconnected growth phenomena. Here, we discuss the similarities in these two processes, as well as the known molecular mechanisms behind the tropistic responses. We also highlight research done in a microgravity environment in order to decouple two tropisms through experiments carried out in the absence of a significant unilateral gravity vector. In addition, alteration of gravity, especially the microgravity environment, and light irradiation produce important effects on meristematic cells, the undifferentiated, highly proliferating, totipotent cells which sustain plant development. Microgravity produces the disruption of meristematic competence, i.e., the decoupling of cell proliferation and cell growth, affecting the regulation of the cell cycle and ribosome biogenesis. Light irradiation, especially red light, mediated by phytochromes, has an activating effect on these processes. Phytohormones, particularly auxin, also are key mediators in these alterations. Upcoming experiments on the International Space Station will clarify some of the mechanisms and molecular players of the plant responses to these environmental signals involved in tropisms and the cell cycle.

summary: This publication analyzes the synergistic relationship between light and gravity signals in modulating plant development, specifically focusing on gravitropism and phototropism. It discusses the molecular mechanisms underlying these tropistic responses and highlights how microgravity environments can be used to decouple them, offering unique insights. The paper also examines the significant effects of altered gravity (microgravity) and light irradiation on meristematic cells, noting that microgravity disrupts meristematic competence by decoupling cell proliferation and growth, affecting the cell cycle and ribosome biogenesis. Conversely, light, particularly red light mediated by phytochromes, activates these processes, with phytohormones like auxin playing key mediating roles. Upcoming International Space Station experiments are expected to further elucidate these mechanisms.
impact: Understanding the interplay of light and gravity on plant development, especially in microgravity, is crucial for advancing space biology and enabling sustainable plant growth in extraterrestrial environments. By revealing how altered gravity affects fundamental processes like meristematic cell function, cell proliferation, and the cell cycle, this research contributes to optimizing plant cultivation for long-duration space missions and developing strategies to mitigate spaceflight-induced developmental challenges in plants.

title: Comparative transcriptomics indicate changes in cell wall organization and stress response in seedlings during spaceflight
abstract:
PREMISE OF THE STUDY Plants will play an important role in the future of space exploration as part of bioregenerative life support. Thus, it is important to understand the effects of microgravity and spaceflight on gene expression in plant development.
METHODS We analyzed the transcriptome of Arabidopsis thaliana using the Biological Research in Canisters (BRIC) hardware during Space Shuttle mission STS-131. The bioinformatics methods used included RMA (robust multi-array average), MAS5 (Microarray Suite 5.0), and PLIER (probe logarithmic intensity error estimation). Glycome profiling was used to analyze cell wall composition in the samples. In addition, our results were compared to those of two other groups using the same hardware on the same mission (BRIC-16).
KEY RESULTS In our BRIC-16 experiments, we noted expression changes in genes involved in hypoxia and heat shock responses, DNA repair, and cell wall structure between spaceflight samples compared to the ground controls. In addition, glycome profiling supported our expression analyses in that there was a difference in cell wall components between ground control and spaceflight-grown plants. Comparing our studies to those of the other BRIC-16 experiments demonstrated that, even with the same hardware and similar biological materials, differences in results in gene expression were found among these spaceflight experiments.
C ONCLUSIONS A common theme from our BRIC-16 space experiments and those of the other two groups was the downregulation of water stress response genes in spaceflight. In addition, all three studies found differential regulation of genes associated with cell wall remodeling and stress responses between spaceflight-grown and ground control plants.

Microarray preparations for the BRIC-16-Cyt seedlings
Quantitative real-time PCR (qRT-PCR) of BRIC-16-Cyt seedlings

summary: This study investigated the effects of spaceflight on gene expression and cell wall composition in *Arabidopsis thaliana* seedlings using the BRIC hardware during Space Shuttle mission STS-131. Employing transcriptome analysis (RMA, MAS5, PLIER) and glycome profiling, the researchers identified significant changes in gene expression related to hypoxia, heat shock responses, DNA repair, and cell wall structure in spaceflight samples compared to ground controls. Glycome profiling further supported differences in cell wall components. A comparative analysis with other BRIC-16 experiments, despite some discrepancies, revealed common themes: downregulation of water stress response genes and differential regulation of genes associated with cell wall remodeling and stress responses in spaceflight.
impact: Understanding how plants respond to microgravity and spaceflight at the genetic and cellular level is crucial for developing bioregenerative life support systems for future space exploration. This research contributes to that understanding by identifying specific molecular and structural changes in plant cell walls and stress responses, which can inform strategies for optimizing plant growth and resilience in space environments.
theme: Plant adaptation to spaceflight, cell wall remodeling, stress response, and transcriptomic changes under microgravity.
original_title: Comparative transcriptomics indicate changes in cell wall organization and stress response in seedlings during spaceflight

title: RNAseq Analysis of the Response of Arabidopsis thaliana to Fractional Gravity Under Blue-Light Stimulation During Spaceflight
abstract: Introduction: Traveling to nearby extraterrestrial objects having a reduced gravity level (partial gravity) compared to Earth’s gravity is becoming a realistic objective for space agencies. The use of plants as part of life support systems will require a better understanding of the interactions among plant growth responses including tropisms, under partial gravity conditions. Materials and Methods: Here, we present results from our latest space experiments on the ISS, in which seeds of Arabidopsis thaliana were germinated, and seedlings grew for six days under different gravity levels, namely micro-g, several intermediate partial-g levels, and 1g, and were subjected to irradiation with blue light for the last 48 h. RNA was extracted from 20 samples for subsequent RNAseq analysis. Transcriptomic analysis was performed using the HISAT2-Stringtie-DESeq pipeline. Differentially expressed genes were further characterized for global responses using the GEDI tool, gene networks and for Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment. Results: Differential gene expression analysis revealed only one differentially expressed gene (AT4G21560, VPS28-1 a vacuolar protein) across all gravity conditions using FDR correction (q < 0.05). However, the same 14 genes appeared differentially expressed when comparing either micro-g, low-g level (< 0.1g) or the Moon g-level with 1g control conditions. Apart from these 14-shared genes, the number of differentially expressed genes was similar in microgravity and the Moon g-level and increased in the intermediate g-level (< 0.1g), but it was then progressively reduced as the difference with the Earth gravity became smaller. The GO groups were differentially affected at each g-level: light and photosynthesis GO under microgravity, genes belonged to general stress, chemical and hormone responses under low-g, and a response related to cell wall and membrane structure and function under the Moon g-level. Discussion: Transcriptional analyses of plants under blue light stimulation suggests that root blue-light phototropism may be enough to reduce the gravitational stress response caused by the lack of gravitropism in microgravity. Competition among tropisms induces an intense perturbation at the micro-g level, which shows an extensive stress response that is progressively attenuated. Our results show a major effect on cell wall/membrane remodeling (detected at the interval from the Moon to Mars gravity), which can be potentially related to graviresistance mechanisms.
headings: Blue Light Phototropism May Be Enough to Reduce the Gravitational Stress Response on Orbit
Low-g Effect: Competition Between Tropisms or Artifacts of Reduced-Gravity Simulation?
Moon and Mars-g Effects and the Consequences for Manned Spaceflight Missions
summary: This study investigated the transcriptomic response of *Arabidopsis thaliana* seedlings to different gravity levels (micro-g, various partial-g, and 1g) on the International Space Station (ISS), combined with blue-light stimulation. RNAseq analysis revealed that while only one gene (AT4G21560, VPS28-1) was consistently differentially expressed across all gravity conditions after FDR correction, 14 common genes were differentially expressed when comparing micro-g, low-g (< 0.1g), or Moon g-level to 1g. The number of differentially expressed genes varied across gravity levels, peaking at intermediate low-g and decreasing as gravity approached Earth's. Distinct Gene Ontology groups were affected at each g-level, ranging from light/photosynthesis in microgravity to general stress/hormone responses in low-g, and cell wall/membrane structure and function at Moon g-level. The findings suggest that blue-light phototropism may reduce gravitational stress in microgravity, and a major effect on cell wall/membrane remodeling observed from Moon to Mars gravity levels could be related to graviresistance mechanisms.
impact: This research provides critical insights into plant adaptation to fractional gravity, which is essential for developing robust plant-based life support systems for future long-duration human space missions to the Moon and Mars. Understanding the molecular mechanisms, particularly cell wall/membrane remodeling and the interplay of plant tropisms under reduced gravity and blue light, is key to optimizing plant growth and productivity in extraterrestrial environments and ensuring astronaut well-being.
theme: Plant molecular response to fractional gravity and blue-light stimulation during spaceflight, focusing on gene expression, graviperception, tropisms, and adaptation mechanisms for space life support systems.
original_title: RNAseq analysis of the response of Arabidopsis thaliana to fractional gravity under blue-light stimulation during spaceflight

title: Comparison of Microgravity Analogs to Spaceflight in Studies of Plant Growth and Development
abstract: Life on Earth has evolved under the influence of gravity. This force has played an important role in shaping development and morphology from the molecular level to the whole organism. Although aquatic life experiences reduced gravity effects, land plants have evolved under a 1-g environment. Understanding gravitational effects requires changing the magnitude of this force. One method of eliminating gravity’s influence is to enter into a free-fall orbit around the planet, thereby achieving a balance between centripetal force of gravity and the centrifugal force of the moving object. This balance is often mistakenly referred to as microgravity, but is best described as weightlessness. In addition to actually compensating gravity, instruments such as clinostats, random-positioning machines (RPM), and magnetic levitation devices have been used to eliminate effects of constant gravity on plant growth and development. However, these platforms do not reduce gravity but constantly change its direction. Despite these fundamental differences, there are few studies that have investigated the comparability between these platforms and weightlessness. Here, we provide a review of the strengths and weaknesses of these analogs for the study of plant growth and development compared to spaceflight experiments. We also consider reduced or partial gravity effects via spaceflight and analog methods. While these analogs are useful, the fidelity of the results relative to spaceflight depends on biological parameters and environmental conditions that cannot be simulated in ground-based studies.
headings: Plant Responses in Reduced or Partial Gravity in Spaceflight
Plant Responses to Simulated Partial or Reduced Gravity Using Analogs
summary: This review paper compares various ground-based microgravity and reduced gravity analogs (e.g., clinostats, random-positioning machines, magnetic levitation) to actual spaceflight (weightlessness) for studying plant growth and development. It highlights that ground analogs primarily change the direction of gravity rather than eliminating or reducing its magnitude. The authors analyze the strengths and weaknesses of these analogs, including those for simulating reduced/partial gravity, noting that the fidelity of analog results relative to spaceflight depends on specific biological parameters and environmental conditions that cannot be fully replicated on Earth.
impact: This analysis provides critical guidance for researchers in space biology, elucidating the capabilities and significant limitations of ground-based microgravity and reduced gravity analogs. It underscores the importance of actual spaceflight experiments for achieving accurate results for certain biological parameters, thereby informing more rigorous experimental design and interpretation in the study of gravitational effects on plant life.
theme: Comparison and evaluation of ground-based microgravity and reduced gravity simulation platforms against actual spaceflight conditions for plant growth and development studies.
original_title: Comparison of Microgravity Analogs to Spaceflight in Studies of Plant Growth and Development

title: The Importance of Earth Reference Controls in Spaceflight -Omics Research: Characterization of Nucleolin Mutants from the Seedling Growth Experiments
abstract: Understanding plant adaptive responses to the space environment is a requisite for enabling space farming. Spaceflight produces deleterious effects on plant cells, particularly affecting ribosome biogenesis, a complex stress-sensitive process coordinated with cell division and differentiation, known to be activated by red light. Here, in a series of ground studies, we have used mutants from the two Arabidopsis nucleolin genes (NUC1 and NUC2, nucleolar regulators of ribosome biogenesis) to better understand their role in adaptive response mechanisms to stress on Earth. Thus, we show that nucleolin stress-related gene NUC2 can compensate for the environmental stress provided by darkness in nuc1 plants, whereas nuc2 plants are not able to provide a complete response to red light. These ground control findings, as part of the ESA/NASA Seedling Growth spaceflight experiments, will determine the basis for the identification of genetic backgrounds enabling an adaptive advantage for plants in future space experiments.

summary: This NASA Space Biology publication focuses on establishing Earth-based reference controls for future spaceflight -omics research aimed at understanding plant adaptive responses to the space environment. The study utilizes ground experiments with *Arabidopsis thaliana* mutants of nucleolin genes (NUC1 and NUC2), which regulate ribosome biogenesis and are crucial for stress response. The researchers characterized the transcriptional profiles of these mutants under various conditions, including darkness and red light photostimulation. Key findings include NUC2's ability to compensate for environmental stress (darkness) in nuc1 plants and nuc2 plants' incomplete response to red light. These ground control results, part of the ESA/NASA Seedling Growth spaceflight experiments, are essential for identifying genetic backgrounds that could provide adaptive advantages for plants in future space missions.
impact: This research is crucial for enabling space farming and understanding how plants adapt to the unique stressors of the space environment. By establishing robust Earth reference controls for nucleolin mutants, it provides a critical baseline for interpreting data from future spaceflight experiments. This will help identify specific genetic traits that confer adaptive advantages to plants in space, paving the way for developing more resilient crops for long-duration space missions and supporting human exploration beyond Earth. It underscores the importance of ground-based studies in Space Biology to accurately assess the impact of microgravity and other space-related factors.
theme: Plant adaptation to the space environment, molecular mechanisms of plant stress response, ribosome biogenesis, the role of nucleolin genes in plant stress, and the importance of Earth reference controls in space biology and -omics research for future space farming applications.

title: Effects of altered gravity on growth and morphology in Wolffia globosa implications for bioregenerative life support systems and space-based agriculture
authors: Jack J W A van Loon
abstract: Understanding the response of plants to varied gravitational conditions is vital for developing effective food production in space bioregenerative life support systems. This study examines the impact of altered gravity conditions on the growth and morphological responses of Wolffia globosa (commonly known as “water lentils” or “duckweed”), assessing its potential as a space crop. Although an experiment testing the effect of simulated microgravity on Wolffia globosa has been previously conducted, for the first time, we investigated the effect of multiple gravity levels on the growth and morphological traits of Wolffia globosa plants. The plant responses to simulated microgravity, simulated partial gravity (Moon), and hypergravity environments were evaluated using random positioning machines and the large-diameter centrifuge. As hypothesized, we observed a slight reaction to different gravitational levels in the growth and morphological traits of Wolffia globosa. The relative growth rates (RGR) of plants subjected to simulated microgravity and partial gravity were reduced when compared to those in other gravity levels. The morphological analysis revealed differences in plant dimensions and frond length-to-width ratios under diverse gravity conditions. Our findings showed that Wolffia globosa is responsive to gravitational changes, with its growth and morphological adaptations being slightly influenced by varying gravitational environments. As for other crop species, growth was reduced by the microgravity conditions; however, RGR remained substantial at 0.33 a day. In conclusion, this study underscores the potential of Wolffia globosa as a space crop and its adaptability to diverse gravitational conditions, contributing to the development of sustainable food production and bioregenerative life support systems for future space exploration missions.
summary: This study investigated the growth and morphological responses of *Wolffia globosa* (water lentils) to various altered gravity conditions, including simulated microgravity, simulated partial gravity (Moon), and hypergravity. It was the first time multiple gravity levels were tested on this plant. The research found that *Wolffia globosa* exhibited a slight reaction to different gravitational levels; relative growth rates (RGR) were reduced in simulated microgravity and partial gravity compared to other levels, though RGR remained substantial (0.33 a day) even under microgravity conditions. Morphological analysis revealed differences in plant dimensions and frond length-to-width ratios across diverse gravity environments.
impact: The findings underscore the potential of *Wolffia globosa* as a viable space crop, demonstrating its adaptability to diverse gravitational conditions. This research is crucial for advancing the development of sustainable food production systems and bioregenerative life support systems, essential for future long-duration space exploration missions.
theme: Space biology, plant adaptation to altered gravity, bioregenerative life support systems, space-based agriculture, plant growth and morphology.
original_title: Conducting plant experiments in space and on the Moon

title: Red Light Enhances Plant Adaptation to Spaceflight and Mars g-Levels
abstract: Understanding how plants respond and adapt to extraterrestrial conditions is essential for space exploration initiatives. Deleterious effects of the space environment on plant development have been reported, such as the unbalance of cell growth and proliferation in the root meristem, or gene expression reprogramming. However, plants are capable of surviving and completing the seed-to-seed life cycle under microgravity. A key research challenge is to identify environmental cues, such as light, which could compensate the negative effects of microgravity. Understanding the crosstalk between light and gravity sensing in space was the major objective of the NASA-ESA Seedling Growth series of spaceflight experiments (2013–2018). Different g-levels were used, with special attention to micro-g, Mars-g, and Earth-g. In spaceflight seedlings illuminated for 4 days with a white light photoperiod and then photostimulated with red light for 2 days, transcriptomic studies showed, first, that red light partially reverted the gene reprogramming induced by microgravity, and that the combination of microgravity and photoactivation was not recognized by seedlings as stressful. Two mutant lines of the nucleolar protein nucleolin exhibited differential requirements in response to red light photoactivation. This observation opens the way to directed-mutagenesis strategies in crop design to be used in space colonization. Further transcriptomic studies at different g-levels showed elevated plastid and mitochondrial genome expression in microgravity, associated with disturbed nucleus–organelle communication, and the upregulation of genes encoding auxin and cytokinin hormonal pathways. At the Mars g-level, genes of hormone pathways related to stress response were activated, together with some transcription factors specifically related to acclimation, suggesting that seedlings grown in partial-g are able to acclimate by modulating genome expression in routes related to space-environment-associated stress.
headings: 3. However, Plants May Overcome Gravitational Stress and Adapt to the Space Environment
4. Plant Culture in Space May Benefit from Other Environmental Cues Replacing Gravity
5. The Advantages of Red Light Illumination to Improve Seedling Viability in Space, as Revealed by the SEEDLING GROWTH Experiments
summary: This NASA Space Biology publication highlights how plants respond and adapt to extraterrestrial conditions, particularly altered gravity levels. While microgravity can induce detrimental effects like unbalanced cell growth in root meristems and gene reprogramming, plants are capable of completing their life cycle in space. The NASA-ESA Seedling Growth experiments demonstrated that red light is a crucial environmental cue that can compensate for the negative effects of microgravity. Transcriptomic studies revealed that red light partially reverts gene reprogramming induced by microgravity, and that the combination of microgravity and red light photoactivation was not perceived as stressful. Experiments at micro-g showed elevated plastid and mitochondrial genome expression, disturbed nucleus-organelle communication, and upregulation of auxin and cytokinin pathways. At Mars g-levels, stress-related hormone pathways and acclimation-related transcription factors were activated, suggesting plants can acclimate through gene expression modulation. The study also identified differential requirements in nucleolin mutants, opening avenues for targeted genetic engineering.
impact: The findings suggest that red light illumination can significantly enhance plant adaptation and viability in space, offering a strategy to improve crop performance for long-duration space missions and future colonization efforts on Mars. The identification of differential responses in nucleolin mutants provides a foundation for developing directed-mutagenesis strategies to design more resilient crops optimized for space environments.
theme: Plant adaptation to altered gravity (microgravity and Mars g-levels) in space, focusing on the role of red light as an environmental cue to mitigate stress and promote growth, and the underlying transcriptomic and hormonal pathway responses.
original_title: Red light enhances plant adaptation to spaceflight and Mars g-levels.

title: EUK-134 ameliorates nNOSµ translocation and skeletal muscle fiber atrophy during short-term mechanical unloading.
abstract: Reduced mechanical loading during bedrest, spaceflight, and casting, causes rapid morphological changes in skeletal muscle: fiber atrophy and reduction of slow-twitch fibers. An emerging signaling event in response to unloading is the translocation of neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOSμ) from the sarcolemma to the cytosol. We used EUK-134, a cell-permeable mimetic of superoxide dismutase and catalase, to test the role of redox signaling in nNOSμ translocation and muscle fiber atrophy as a result of short-term (54 h) hindlimb unloading. Fischer-344 rats were divided into ambulatory control, hindlimb-unloaded (HU), and hindlimb-unloaded + EUK-134 (HU-EUK) groups. EUK-134 mitigated the unloading-induced phenotype, including muscle fiber atrophy and muscle fiber-type shift from slow to fast. nNOSμ immunolocalization at the sarcolemma of the soleus was reduced with HU, while nNOSμ protein content in the cytosol increased with unloading. Translocation of nNOS from the sarcolemma to cytosol was virtually abolished by EUK-134. EUK-134 also mitigated dephosphorylation at Thr-32 of FoxO3a during HU. Hindlimb unloading elevated oxidative stress (4-hydroxynonenal) and increased sarcolemmal localization of Nox2 subunits gp91phox (Nox2) and p47phox, effects normalized by EUK-134. Thus, our findings are consistent with the hypothesis that oxidative stress triggers nNOSμ translocation from the sarcolemma and FoxO3a dephosphorylation as an early event during mechanical unloading. Thus, redox signaling may serve as a biological switch for nNOS to initiate morphological changes in skeletal muscle fibers.
headings: Alterations in soleus muscle morphology with 54 h of mechanical unloading are regulated by oxidative stress.
EUK-134 attenuates nNOS translocation with hindlimb unloading.
EUK-134 protects against unloading-related reduction in FoxO3a phosphorylation (Thr-32).
Unloading-induced elevation of oxidative stress and Nox2 is reduced by EUK-134.
EUK-134 attenuation of nNOS translocation and morphological changes.
summary: This study investigated the role of oxidative stress in skeletal muscle atrophy and nNOSμ translocation during short-term mechanical unloading (54 hours hindlimb unloading) in Fischer-344 rats. The researchers used EUK-134, a mimetic of superoxide dismutase and catalase, to modulate redox signaling. They found that hindlimb unloading caused muscle fiber atrophy, a shift from slow-twitch to fast-twitch fibers, and the translocation of nNOSμ from the sarcolemma to the cytosol. Unloading also increased oxidative stress (4-hydroxynonenal) and the sarcolemmal localization of Nox2 subunits. EUK-134 treatment effectively mitigated these unloading-induced changes, including muscle fiber atrophy, fiber-type shift, nNOSμ translocation, and oxidative stress markers. It also protected against the dephosphorylation of FoxO3a at Thr-32. The findings suggest that oxidative stress acts as an early trigger for nNOSμ translocation and FoxO3a dephosphorylation, leading to morphological changes in skeletal muscle during mechanical unloading.
impact: This research provides critical insights into the early molecular events underlying skeletal muscle atrophy in response to reduced mechanical loading, a common challenge in spaceflight, bedrest, and disuse. By identifying oxidative stress and subsequent nNOSμ translocation as key biological 'switches', the study offers potential therapeutic targets. EUK-134's efficacy in ameliorating these effects suggests that antioxidant strategies could be valuable in developing countermeasures to preserve muscle health and function for astronauts during long-duration space missions and for patients experiencing prolonged immobility on Earth, ultimately contributing to human health and performance in space.

title: MnSOD Overexpression Reduces Fibrosis and Pro-Apoptotic Signaling in the Aging Mouse Heart
abstract: Contractility of the heart is impaired with advancing age via mechanical remodeling, as myocytes are lost through apoptosis and collagenous fibers accumulate. Exercise training confers protection against fibrosis and apoptosis in the aging heart, but the mechanisms remain poorly understood. We recently reported that exercise training elevates Mn isoform of superoxide dismutase (MnSOD) in the aging heart, concomitant with reduction in oxidative stress and fibrosis. Here, we tested the hypothesis that overexpression of MnSOD would be causal in protection against fibrosis and apoptosis in the aging heart. Hearts were extracted from young (8 months) wild-type, young mice overexpressing the Sod2 (MnSOD) gene, old (28 months) wild-type, and old transgenic mice. Left ventricle MnSOD protein levels were elevated in young mice overexpressing the Sod2 (MnSOD) gene and old transgenic mice. MnSODTg mice exhibited lower oxidative stress (total hydroperoxides, 4-hydroxynonenal, and 8-isoprostane) in the old group. Age-related cardiac remodeling and fibrosis was mitigated in MnSOD Tg mice with reductions in extramyocyte space (−65%), collagen-I, and transforming growth factor-β. Pro-apoptotic markers Bax (−38%) and caspase-3 cleavage (−41%) were reduced and apoptosis (terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase-mediated dUTP nick-end labeling-positive nuclei, DNA laddering) was mitigated in MnSOD Tg hearts compared with old wild-type. We conclude that MnSOD elevation is indeed protective against oxidative stress, fibrosis, and apoptosis in the aging heart.

MnSOD Overexpression and Fibrosis in Aging Heart

summary: This study investigated whether the overexpression of manganese superoxide dismutase (MnSOD) causally protects against age-related cardiac fibrosis and apoptosis. Using young and old wild-type and MnSOD transgenic mice, researchers found that elevated MnSOD levels in the heart reduced oxidative stress markers (hydroperoxides, 4-hydroxynonenal, 8-isoprostane) in old mice. Furthermore, MnSOD overexpression mitigated age-related cardiac remodeling and fibrosis, evidenced by reductions in extramyocyte space, collagen-I, and transforming growth factor-β. Pro-apoptotic markers (Bax, caspase-3 cleavage) and apoptosis (TUNEL, DNA laddering) were also significantly reduced in aging MnSOD transgenic hearts. The study concludes that MnSOD elevation is protective against oxidative stress, fibrosis, and apoptosis in the aging heart.
impact: The findings suggest that enhancing MnSOD activity could be a therapeutic strategy to combat age-related cardiac dysfunction by reducing oxidative stress, preventing fibrosis, and mitigating cell loss through apoptosis. This research sheds light on the mechanisms by which interventions like exercise, known to elevate MnSOD, confer cardioprotection in aging, potentially leading to novel approaches for maintaining heart health in older populations.

title: Lifelong Wheel Running Exercise and Mild Caloric Restriction Attenuate Nuclear EndoG in the Aging Plantaris Muscle
abstract: Apoptosis plays an important role in atrophy and sarcopenia in skeletal muscle. Recent evidence suggests that insufficient heat shock proteins (HSPs) may contribute to apoptosis and muscle wasting. In addition, long-term caloric restriction (CR) and lifelong wheel running exercise (WR) with CR provide significant protection against caspase-dependent apoptosis and sarcopenia. Caspase-independent mediators (endonuclease G: EndoG; apoptosis-inducing factor: AIF) of apoptosis are also linked to muscles wasting with disuse and aging. However, the efficacy of CR and WR with CR to attenuate caspase-independent apoptosis and preserve HSPs in aging skeletal muscle are unknown. Therefore, we tested the hypothesis that CR and WR with CR would ameliorate age-induced elevation of EndoG and AIF while protecting HSP27 and HSP70 levels in the plantaris. Male Fischer-344 rats were divided into 4 groups at 11 weeks: ad libitum feeding until 6 mo. (YAL); fed ad libitum until 24 mo. old (OAL); 8%CR to 24 mo. (OCR); WR + 8%CR to 24 mo. (OExCR). Nuclear EndoG levels were significantly higher in OAL (+153%) than in YAL, while CR (−38%) and WR with CR (−46%) significantly attenuated age-induced increment in nuclear EndoG. HSP27 (−63%) protein content and phosphorylation at Ser82 (−49%) were significantly lower in OAL than in YAL, while HSP27 protein content was significantly higher in OCR (+136%) and OExCR (+155%) and p-HSP27 (+254%) was significantly higher in OExCR compared with OAL, respectively. In contrast, AIF and HSP70 were unaltered by CR or WR with CR in aging muscle. These data indicate that CR and WR with CR attenuate age-associated upregulation of EndoG translocation in the nucleus, potentially involved with HSP27 signaling.
headings: Age-associated changes in HSPs with caloric restriction and exercise
summary: This study investigated whether caloric restriction (CR) and lifelong wheel running exercise (WR) with CR could attenuate caspase-independent apoptosis mediators (EndoG, AIF) and preserve heat shock proteins (HSP27, HSP70) in the aging plantaris muscle of male Fischer-344 rats. Researchers found that nuclear EndoG levels were significantly elevated in aged, ad libitum-fed rats (OAL) compared to young rats (YAL). However, both CR and WR with CR significantly attenuated this age-induced increase in nuclear EndoG. HSP27 protein content and its phosphorylation at Ser82 were reduced in OAL rats, but CR and WR with CR significantly increased HSP27 protein, and WR with CR also boosted p-HSP27. AIF and HSP70 levels remained unchanged. The findings suggest that CR and WR with CR effectively attenuate age-associated upregulation of nuclear EndoG translocation, potentially involving HSP27 signaling, thus offering protection against age-related muscle wasting.
impact: This research highlights the protective role of lifestyle interventions, specifically caloric restriction and exercise, in mitigating age-related muscle decline (sarcopenia) by modulating specific caspase-independent apoptotic pathways (EndoG) and enhancing the levels of protective heat shock proteins (HSP27). The findings provide a mechanistic basis for how these interventions preserve muscle health with aging, suggesting potential targets for therapeutic strategies aimed at combating muscle wasting and maintaining functional independence in older adults.
theme: The protective effects of caloric restriction and lifelong wheel running exercise on attenuating age-related caspase-independent apoptosis and preserving heat shock proteins in skeletal muscle.
original_title: Lifelong wheel running exercise and mild caloric restriction attenuate nuclear EndoG in the aging plantaris muscle.

title: Age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment are attenuated by lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise
abstract: Age-related loss of skeletal muscle mass and function, referred to as sarcopenia, is mitigated by lifelong calorie restriction as well as exercise. In aged skeletal muscle fibers there is compromised integrity of the cell membrane that may contribute to sarcopenia. The purpose of this study was to determine if lifelong mild (8%) caloric restriction (CR) and lifelong CR + voluntary wheel running (WR) could ameliorate disruption of membrane scaffolding and signaling proteins during the aging process, thus maintaining a favorable, healthy membrane environment in plantaris muscle fibers. Fischer-344 rats were divided into four groups: 24-month old adults fed ad libitum (OAL); 24-month old on 8% caloric restriction (OCR); 24 month old 8% caloric restriction + wheel running (OCRWR); 6-month old sedentary adults fed ad libitum (YAL) were used to determine age-related changes. Aging resulted in discontinuous membrane expression of dystrophin glycoprotein complex (DGC) proteins: dystrophin and α-syntrophin. Older muscle also displayed decreased content of neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOS), a key DGC signaling protein. In contrast, OCR and OCRWR provided significant protection against age-related DGC disruption. In conjunction with the age-related decline in membrane DGC patency, key membrane repair proteins (MG53, dysferlin, annexin A6, and annexin A2) were significantly increased in the OAL plantaris. However, lifelong CR and CRWR interventions were effective at maintaining membrane repair proteins near YAL levels of. OAL fibers also displayed reduced protein content of NADPH oxidase isoform 2 (Nox2) subunits (p67phox and p47phox), consistent with a perturbed sarcolemmal environment. Loss of Nox2 subunits was prevented by lifelong CR and CRWR. Our results are therefore consistent with the hypothesis that lifelong CR and WR are effective countermeasures against age-related alterations in the myofiber membrane environment.

3.4. Lifelong CR and WR ameliorate the age-related reduction in Nox2 abundance

4.2. Protection by CR and WR against DGC alterations in aged plantaris muscle
4.3. Effect of aging on sarcolemmal repair
summary: This study investigated the impact of lifelong mild (8%) caloric restriction (CR) and CR combined with voluntary wheel running (WR) on age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment of Fischer-344 rat plantaris muscle, which contribute to sarcopenia. Aged, sedentary rats displayed significant disruptions, including discontinuous membrane expression of dystrophin glycoprotein complex (DGC) proteins (dystrophin, α-syntrophin) and decreased neuronal nitric oxide synthase (nNOS). Concurrently, key membrane repair proteins (MG53, dysferlin, annexin A6, A2) were significantly increased, and NADPH oxidase isoform 2 (Nox2) subunits (p67phox, p47phox) were reduced. Lifelong CR and CR + WR interventions effectively attenuated these age-related changes, providing significant protection against DGC disruption, maintaining membrane repair proteins near levels seen in young adults, and preventing the loss of Nox2 subunits. The findings conclude that lifelong CR and WR are effective countermeasures against age-related deterioration of the myofiber membrane environment.
impact: This research provides critical insights into the molecular mechanisms by which lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise preserve muscle health during aging. By demonstrating that these lifestyle interventions can mitigate age-related compromise of the muscle cell membrane's structural integrity and signaling capabilities, the study offers valuable strategies for combating sarcopenia. These findings underscore the importance of sustained healthy lifestyle choices in maintaining muscle function and overall well-being as we age, potentially leading to improved quality of life for the elderly population.
theme: The primary theme is the investigation of age-related changes in the sarcolemmal environment of skeletal muscle, specifically focusing on how lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise act as protective countermeasures against these molecular and structural deteriorations associated with sarcopenia.
original_title: Age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment are attenuated by lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise.

title: The Impact of SRT2104 on Skeletal Muscle Mitochondrial Function, Redox Biology, and Loss of Muscle Mass in Hindlimb Unloaded Rats
abstract: Mechanical unloading during microgravity causes skeletal muscle atrophy and impairs mitochondrial energetics. The elevated production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) by mitochondria and Nox2, coupled with impairment of stress protection (e.g., SIRT1, antioxidant enzymes), contribute to atrophy. We tested the hypothesis that the SIRT1 activator, SRT2104 would rescue unloading-induced mitochondrial dysfunction. Mitochondrial function in rat gastrocnemius and soleus muscles were evaluated under three conditions (10 days): ambulatory control (CON), hindlimb unloaded (HU), and hindlimb-unloaded-treated with SRT2104 (SIRT). Oxidative phosphorylation, electron transfer capacities, H2O2 production, and oxidative and antioxidant enzymes were quantified using high-resolution respirometry and colorimetry. In the gastrocnemius, (1) integrative (per mg tissue) proton LEAK was lesser in SIRT than in HU or CON; (2) intrinsic (relative to citrate synthase) maximal noncoupled electron transfer capacity (ECI+II) was lesser, while complex I-supported oxidative phosphorylation to ECI+II was greater in HU than CON; (3) the contribution of LEAK to ECI+II was greatest, but cytochrome c oxidase activity was lowest in HU. In both muscles, H2O2 production and concentration was greatest in SIRT, as was gastrocnemius superoxide dismutase activity. In the soleus, H2O2 concentration was greater in HU compared to CON. These results indicate that SRT2104 preserves mitochondrial function in unloaded skeletal muscle, suggesting its potential to support healthy muscle cells in microgravity by promoting necessary energy production in mitochondria.
summary: This study investigated the impact of the SIRT1 activator, SRT2104, on skeletal muscle mitochondrial function, redox biology, and muscle mass loss in hindlimb unloaded (HU) rats, a model for microgravity. Mechanical unloading typically causes muscle atrophy and impairs mitochondrial energetics. The researchers evaluated mitochondrial function in rat gastrocnemius and soleus muscles under ambulatory control (CON), HU, and HU with SRT2104 treatment (SIRT) for 10 days. Key findings included that SRT2104 significantly reduced integrative proton LEAK in the gastrocnemius. While HU impaired intrinsic maximal noncoupled electron transfer capacity (ECI+II) and cytochrome c oxidase activity, and increased the contribution of LEAK, SRT2104 treatment preserved mitochondrial function. Interestingly, H2O2 production and concentration, along with gastrocnemius superoxide dismutase activity, were highest in the SRT2104 group, while soleus H2O2 was highest in HU. Overall, the results suggest that SRT2104 preserves mitochondrial function in unloaded skeletal muscle.
impact: The findings suggest that SRT2104 has the potential to support healthy muscle cells in microgravity environments by promoting necessary energy production in mitochondria. This offers a promising pharmacological countermeasure to mitigate skeletal muscle atrophy and impaired mitochondrial energetics experienced by astronauts during spaceflight.
theme: Space Biology, Microgravity Countermeasures, Skeletal Muscle Physiology, Mitochondrial Function, Redox Biology, Pharmacological Interventions for Muscle Atrophy
original_title: The impact of SRT2104 on skeletal muscle mitochondrial function, redox biology, and loss of muscle mass in hindlimb unloaded rats.

title: Bioreactor development for skeletal muscle hypertrophy and atrophy by manipulating uniaxial cyclic strain: proof of concept
abstract: Skeletal muscles overcome terrestrial, gravitational loading by producing tensile forces that produce movement through joint rotation. Conversely, the microgravity of spaceflight reduces tensile loads in working skeletal muscles, causing an adaptive muscle atrophy. Unfortunately, the design of stable, physiological bioreactors to model skeletal muscle tensile loading during spaceflight experiments remains challenging. Here, we tested a bioreactor that uses initiation and cessation of cyclic, tensile strain to induce hypertrophy and atrophy, respectively, in murine lineage (C2C12) skeletal muscle myotubes. Uniaxial cyclic stretch of myotubes was conducted using a StrexCell® (STB-1400) stepper motor system (0.75 Hz, 12% strain, 60 min day^-1). Myotube groups were assigned as follows: (a) quiescent over 2- or (b) 5-day (no stretch), (c) experienced 2-days (2dHY) or (d) 5-days (5dHY) of cyclic stretch, or (e) 2-days of cyclic stretch followed by a 3-day cessation of stretch (3dAT). Using ß-sarcoglycan as a sarcolemmal marker, mean myotube diameter increased significantly following 2dAT (51%) and 5dAT (94%) vs. matched controls. The hypertrophic, anabolic markers talin and Akt phosphorylation (Thr308) were elevated with 2dHY but not in 3dAT myotubes. Inflammatory, catabolic markers IL-1ß, IL6, and NF-kappaB p65 subunit were significantly higher in the 3dAT group vs. all other groups. The ratio of phosphorylated FoxO3a/total FoxO3a was significantly lower in 3dAT than in the 2dHY group, consistent with elevated catabolic signaling during unloading. In summary, we demonstrated proof-of-concept for a spaceflight research bioreactor, using uniaxial cyclic stretch to produce myotube hypertrophy with increased tensile loading, and myotube atrophy with subsequent cessation of stretch.

Functional protein turnover marker with cyclic stretching and cessation of stretch
Akt and Foxo3a signaling is altered by cyclic stretch and removal of cyclic stretch
Catabolic, inflammatory signaling in response to daily cyclic stretch and cessation of stretch
Cell culture proliferation and differential protocol
summary: This study developed and tested a bioreactor using uniaxial cyclic tensile strain to model skeletal muscle hypertrophy and atrophy. Using C2C12 murine myotubes, researchers applied cyclic stretch (0.75 Hz, 12% strain, 60 min day^-1) to induce hypertrophy and then ceased the stretch to induce atrophy. Myotube diameter significantly increased with stretch (51-94%). Hypertrophic markers (talin, Akt phosphorylation) were elevated with stretch, while inflammatory/catabolic markers (IL-1ß, IL6, NF-kappaB p65) and catabolic signaling (lower phosphorylated FoxO3a/total FoxO3a ratio) were elevated during the cessation phase (atrophy). This work provides a proof-of-concept for a spaceflight-relevant bioreactor capable of recapitulating both muscle hypertrophy and atrophy by manipulating mechanical loading.
impact: This research provides a critical tool for space biology by developing a stable, physiological bioreactor to model skeletal muscle mechanical loading changes in microgravity. It offers a robust in vitro platform to study the mechanisms of spaceflight-induced muscle atrophy and potential countermeasures. By demonstrating the ability to induce both hypertrophy and atrophy, this bioreactor can accelerate research into understanding muscle adaptation to altered gravitational loads, informing strategies to maintain astronaut health during long-duration space missions.
theme: Modeling skeletal muscle adaptation (hypertrophy and atrophy) to mechanical loading changes, particularly relevant to microgravity conditions, using an in vitro bioreactor system.
original_title: Bioreactor development for skeletal muscle hypertrophy and atrophy by manipulating uniaxial cyclic strain: Proof of concept.

title: Genomic and phenotypic characterization of Burkholderia isolates from the potable water system of the International Space Station
abstract: Urine, humidity condensate, and other sources of non-potable water are processed onboard the International Space Station (ISS) by the Water Recovery System (WRS) yielding potable water. While some means of microbial control are in place, including a phosphoric acid/hexavalent chromium urine pretreatment solution, many areas within the WRS are not available for routine microbial monitoring. Due to refurbishment needs, two flex lines from the Urine Processor Assembly (UPA) within the WRS were removed and returned to Earth. The water from within these lines, as well as flush water, was microbially evaluated. Culture and culture-independent analysis revealed the presence of Burkholderia, Paraburkholderia, and Leifsonia. Fungal culture also identified Fusarium and Lecythophora. Hybrid de novo genome analysis of the five distinct Burkholderia isolates identified them as B. contaminans, while the two Paraburkholderia isolates were identified as P. fungorum. Chromate-resistance gene clusters were identified through pangenomic analysis that differentiated these genomes from previously studied isolates recovered from the point-of-use potable water dispenser and/or current NCBI references, indicating that unique populations exist within distinct niches in the WRS. Beyond genomic analysis, fixed samples directly from the lines were imaged by environmental scanning electron microscopy, which detailed networks of fungal-bacterial biofilms. This is the first evidence of biofilm formation within flex lines from the UPA onboard the ISS. For all bacteria isolated, biofilm potential was further characterized, with the B. contaminans isolates demonstrating the most considerable biofilm formation. Moreover, the genomes of the B. contaminans revealed secondary metabolite gene clusters associated with quorum sensing, biofilm formation, antifungal compounds, and hemolysins. The potential production of these gene cluster metabolites was phenotypically evaluated through biofilm, bacterial-fungal interaction, and hemolytic assays. Collectively, these data identify the UPA flex lines as a unique ecological niche and novel area of biofilm growth within the WRS. Further investigation of these organisms and their resistance profiles will enable engineering controls directed toward biofilm prevention in future space station water systems.

summary: This study conducted genomic and phenotypic characterization of microbial isolates from the Urine Processor Assembly (UPA) flex lines of the International Space Station's Water Recovery System (WRS). Culture and culture-independent analyses identified *Burkholderia* (specifically *B. contaminans*), *Paraburkholderia* (*P. fungorum*), *Leifsonia*, *Fusarium*, and *Lecythophora*. Genomic analysis of the *B. contaminans* isolates revealed unique chromate-resistance gene clusters, distinguishing them from previously studied ISS isolates. Environmental scanning electron microscopy provided the first evidence of complex fungal-bacterial biofilm formation within these UPA flex lines. *B. contaminans* isolates demonstrated the most significant biofilm formation potential, correlating with the presence of gene clusters associated with quorum sensing, biofilm formation, antifungal compounds, and hemolysins, which were phenotypically validated. The research concludes that the UPA flex lines represent a unique ecological niche and a novel area of biofilm growth within the ISS WRS.
impact: This research identifies a critical and previously unrecognized niche for microbial growth and robust biofilm formation within the International Space Station's potable water system. The discovery of unique, chromate-resistant microbial populations and significant biofilm potential, particularly in *B. contaminans*, highlights potential challenges for water system integrity and crew health. Understanding these organisms and their resistance profiles is crucial for developing and implementing effective engineering controls and biofilm prevention strategies in current and future space station water systems, ensuring the sustained safety and potability of water for long-duration space missions.

title: CAMDLES: CFD-DEM Simulation of Microbial Communities in Spaceflight and Artificial Microgravity
abstract: We present CAMDLES (CFD-DEM Artificial Microgravity Developments for Living Ecosystem Simulation), an extension of CFDEM®Coupling to model biological flows, growth, and mass transfer in artificial microgravity devices. For microbes that accompany humans into space, microgravity-induced alterations in the fluid environment are likely to be a major factor in the microbial experience of spaceflight. Computational modeling is needed to investigate how well ground-based microgravity simulation methods replicate that experience. CAMDLES incorporates agent-based modeling to study inter-species metabolite transport within microbial communities in rotating wall vessel bioreactors (RWVs). Preexisting CFD modeling of RWVs has not yet incorporated growth; CAMDLES employs the simultaneous modeling of biological, chemical, and mechanical processes in a micro-scale rotating reference frame environment. Simulation mass transfer calculations were correlated with Monod dynamic parameters to predict relative growth rates between artificial microgravity, spaceflight microgravity, and 1 g conditions. By simulating a microbial model community of metabolically cooperative strains of Escherichia coli and Salmonella enterica, we found that the greatest difference between microgravity and an RWV or 1 g gravity was when species colocalized in dense aggregates. We also investigated the influence of other features of the system on growth, such as spatial distribution, product yields, and diffusivity. Our simulation provides a basis for future laboratory experiments using this community for investigation in artificial microgravity and spaceflight microgravity. More broadly, our development of these models creates a framework for novel hypothesis generation and design of biological experiments with RWVs, coupling the effects of RWV size, rotation rate, and mass transport directly to bacterial growth in microbial communities.

summary: This study introduces CAMDLES (CFD-DEM Artificial Microgravity Developments for Living Ecosystem Simulation), an extension of CFDEM®Coupling designed to model biological flows, growth, and mass transfer in artificial microgravity devices. Focusing on microbial communities in spaceflight, CAMDLES uses agent-based modeling to investigate inter-species metabolite transport within rotating wall vessel bioreactors (RWVs), simultaneously simulating biological, chemical, and mechanical processes. By correlating mass transfer calculations with Monod dynamic parameters, the study predicts relative growth rates under artificial microgravity, spaceflight microgravity, and 1 g conditions. Simulating a cross-feeding community of *Escherichia coli* and *Salmonella enterica*, the researchers found that the most significant differences between microgravity and RWV/1 g conditions occurred when species colocalized in dense aggregates. The simulation also explored the influence of spatial distribution, product yields, and diffusivity on growth. This work provides a foundation for future laboratory experiments and a framework for hypothesis generation and experimental design with RWVs, directly linking device parameters to bacterial growth in microbial communities.

By integrating biological, chemical, and mechanical processes, it allows for a deeper understanding of microbial community dynamics in microgravity. This development offers a basis for designing future space biology experiments, generating new hypotheses, and optimizing artificial microgravity systems to better mimic true spaceflight conditions. It enhances our ability to predict and understand the behavior of microbes that accompany humans into space, which is crucial for astronaut health and spacecraft habitability.

title: Hardware Validation of the Advanced Plant Habitat on ISS: Canopy Photosynthesis in Reduced Gravity
abstract: The Advanced Plant Habitat (APH) is the largest research plant growth facility deployed on the International Space Station (ISS). APH is a fully enclosed, closed-loop plant life support system with an environmentally controlled growth chamber designed for conducting both fundamental and applied plant research during experiments extending as long as 135 days. APH was delivered to the ISS in parts aboard two commercial resupply missions: OA-7 in April 2017 and SpaceX-11 in June 2017, and was assembled and installed in the Japanese Experiment Module Kibo in November 2018. We report here on a 7-week-long hardware validation test that utilized a root module planted with both Arabidopsis (cv. Col 0) and wheat (cv. Apogee) plants. The validation test examined the APH’s ability to control light intensity, spectral quality, humidity, CO2 concentration, photoperiod, temperature, and root zone moisture using commanding from ground facilities at the Kennedy Space Center (KSC). The test also demonstrated the execution of programmed experiment profiles that scheduled: (1) changes in environmental combinations (e.g., a daily photoperiod at constant relative humidity), (2) predetermined photographic events using the three APH cameras [overhead, sideview, and sideview near-infrared (NIR)], and (3) execution of experimental sequences during the life cycle of a crop (e.g., measure photosynthetic CO2 drawdown experiments). Arabidopsis and wheat were grown in microgravity to demonstrate crew procedures, planting protocols and watering schemes within APH. The ability of APH to contain plant debris was assessed during the harvest of mature Arabidopsis plants. Wheat provided a large evaporative load that tested root zone moisture control and the recovery of transpired water by condensation. The wheat canopy was also used to validate the ability of APH to measure gas exchange of plants from non-invasive gas exchange measurements (i.e., canopy photosynthesis and respiration). These features were evaluated by executing experiment profiles that utilized the CO2 drawdown technique to measure daily rates of canopy photosynthesis and dark-period CO2 increase for respiration. This hardware validation test confirmed that APH can measure fundamental plant responses to spaceflight conditions.
