title: Spatiotemporal expression and control of haemoglobin in space
abstract: It is now widely recognised that the environment in space activates a diverse set of genes involved in regulating fundamental cellular pathways. This includes the activation of genes associated with blood homeostasis and erythropoiesis, with a particular emphasis on those involved in globin chain production. Haemoglobin biology provides an intriguing model for studying space omics, as it has been extensively explored at multiple -omic levels, spanning DNA, RNA, and protein analyses, in both experimental and clinical contexts. In this study, we examined the developmental expression of haemoglobin over time and space using a unique suite of multi-omic datasets available on NASA GeneLab, from the NASA Twins Study, the JAXA CFE study, and the Inspiration4 mission. Our findings reveal significant variations in globin gene expression corresponding to the distinct spatiotemporal characteristics of the collected samples. This study sheds light on the dynamic nature of globin gene regulation in response to the space environment and provides valuable insights into the broader implications of space omics research.

Utilizing a unique suite of multi-omic datasets from NASA GeneLab, including the NASA Twins Study, JAXA CFE study, and Inspiration4 mission, the research revealed significant variations in globin gene expression corresponding to the distinct spatiotemporal characteristics of the collected samples.

This understanding is vital for addressing potential health challenges like anaemia in astronauts and has broader implications for space omics research, informing the development of countermeasures for long-duration space missions.

title: Single-cell multi-ome and immune profiles of the Inspiration4 crew reveal conserved, cell-type, and sex-specific responses to spaceflight
abstract: Spaceflight induces an immune response in astronauts. To better characterize this effect, we generated single-cell, multi-ome, cell-free RNA (cfRNA), biochemical, and hematology data for the SpaceX Inspiration4 (I4) mission crew. We found that 18 cytokines/chemokines related to inflammation, aging, and muscle homeostasis changed after spaceflight. In I4 single-cell multi-omics data, we identified a “spaceflight signature” of gene expression characterized by enrichment in oxidative phosphorylation, UV response, immune function, and TCF21 pathways. We confirmed the presence of this signature in independent datasets, including the NASA Twins Study, the I4 skin spatial transcriptomics, and 817 NASA GeneLab mouse transcriptomes. Finally, we observed that (1) T cells showed an up-regulation of FOXP3, (2) MHC class I genes exhibited long-term suppression, and (3) infection-related immune pathways were associated with microbiome shifts. In summary, this study reveals conserved and distinct immune disruptions occurring and details a roadmap for potential countermeasures to preserve astronaut health.

summary: This study comprehensively characterized the immune response to spaceflight in the Inspiration4 (I4) crew using single-cell multi-ome, cell-free RNA, biochemical, and hematology data. Researchers identified changes in 18 cytokines/chemokines related to inflammation, aging, and muscle homeostasis post-flight. A 'spaceflight signature' of gene expression, characterized by enrichment in oxidative phosphorylation, UV response, immune function, and TCF21 pathways, was discovered and validated across independent datasets including the NASA Twins Study and GeneLab mouse transcriptomes. Key immune disruptions observed included upregulation of FOXP3 in T cells, long-term suppression of MHC class I genes, and associations between infection-related immune pathways and microbiome shifts. The study also noted sex-dependent differences in response.
impact: The findings provide a detailed understanding of the conserved and distinct immune disruptions that occur during short-duration spaceflight, contributing significantly to space biology and astronaut health. By characterizing a 'spaceflight signature' and specific immune cell changes, this research offers a roadmap for developing potential countermeasures to mitigate negative health impacts and preserve astronaut well-being during future space missions, including those involving diverse crews and varying mission lengths.

title: Single-cell analysis identifies conserved features of immune dysfunction in simulated microgravity and spaceflight
abstract: Microgravity is associated with immunological dysfunction, though the mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, using single-cell analysis of human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) exposed to short term (25 hours) simulated microgravity, we characterize altered genes and pathways at basal and stimulated states with a Toll-like Receptor-7/8 agonist. We validate single-cell analysis by RNA sequencing and super-resolution microscopy, and against data from the Inspiration-4 (I4) mission, JAXA (Cell-Free Epigenome) mission, Twins study, and spleens from mice on the International Space Station. Overall, microgravity alters specific pathways for optimal immunity, including the cytoskeleton, interferon signaling, pyroptosis, temperature-shock, innate inflammation (e.g., Coronavirus pathogenesis pathway and IL-6 signaling), nuclear receptors, and sirtuin signaling. Microgravity directs monocyte inflammatory parameters, and impairs T cell and NK cell functionality. Using machine learning, we identify numerous compounds linking microgravity to immune cell transcription, and demonstrate that the flavonol, quercetin, can reverse most abnormal pathways. These results define immune cell alterations in microgravity, and provide opportunities for countermeasures to maintain normal immunity in space.

title: The Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA) and international astronaut biobank
abstract: Spaceflight induces molecular, cellular and physiological shifts in astronauts and poses myriad biomedical challenges to the human body, which are becoming increasingly relevant as more humans venture into space1–6. Yet current frameworks for aerospace medicine are nascent and lag far behind advancements in precision medicine on Earth, underscoring the need for rapid development of space medicine databases, tools and protocols. Here we present the Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA), an integrated data and sample repository for clinical, cellular and multi-omic research profiles from a diverse range of missions, including the NASA Twins Study7, JAXA CFE study8,9, SpaceX Inspiration4 crew10–12, Axiom and Polaris. The SOMA resource represents a more than tenfold increase in publicly available human space omics data, with matched samples available from the Cornell Aerospace Medicine Biobank. The Atlas includes extensive molecular and physiological profiles encompassing genomics, epigenomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics and microbiome datasets, which reveal some consistent features across missions, including cytokine shifts, telomere elongation and gene expression changes, as well as mission-specific molecular responses and links to orthologous, tissue-specific mouse datasets. Leveraging the datasets, tools and resources in SOMA can help to accelerate precision aerospace medicine, bringing needed health monitoring, risk mitigation and countermeasure data for upcoming lunar, Mars and exploration-class missions.
headings: Access to datasets and crew samples
summary: The Space Omics and Medical Atlas (SOMA) is presented as an integrated data and sample repository encompassing clinical, cellular, and multi-omic research profiles from diverse space missions, including the NASA Twins Study, JAXA CFE, SpaceX Inspiration4, Axiom, and Polaris. This resource dramatically increases publicly available human space omics data, offering matched samples via the Cornell Aerospace Medicine Biobank. SOMA includes extensive molecular and physiological profiles across genomics, epigenomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, metabolomics, and microbiome datasets. Analysis reveals consistent features across missions, such as cytokine shifts, telomere elongation, and gene expression changes, as well as mission-specific molecular responses.
impact: SOMA addresses the critical need for advanced aerospace medicine by providing a robust database, tools, and protocols to accelerate precision space medicine. This resource will facilitate enhanced health monitoring, risk mitigation, and the development of countermeasures essential for upcoming lunar, Mars, and exploration-class missions, bridging the current gap between nascent aerospace medicine and sophisticated precision medicine on Earth.
theme: Integrated multi-omics data repository for advancing precision aerospace medicine and astronaut health research.

title: Secretome profiling reveals acute changes in oxidative stress, brain homeostasis, and coagulation following short-duration spaceflight
abstract: As spaceflight becomes more common with commercial crews, blood-based measures of crew health can guide both astronaut biomedicine and countermeasures. By profiling plasma proteins, metabolites, and extracellular vesicles/particles (EVPs) from the SpaceX Inspiration4 crew, we generated “spaceflight secretome profiles,” which showed significant differences in coagulation, oxidative stress, and brain-enriched proteins. While >93% of differentially abundant proteins (DAPs) in vesicles and metabolites recovered within six months, the majority (73%) of plasma DAPs were still perturbed post-flight. Moreover, these proteomic alterations correlated better with peripheral blood mononuclear cells than whole blood, suggesting that immune cells contribute more DAPs than erythrocytes. Finally, to discern possible mechanisms leading to brain-enriched protein detection and blood-brain barrier (BBB) disruption, we examined protein changes in dissected brains of spaceflight mice, which showed increases in PECAM-1, a marker of BBB integrity. These data highlight how even short-duration spaceflight can disrupt human and murine physiology and identify spaceflight biomarkers that can guide countermeasure development.

summary: This NASA Space Biology study analyzed plasma proteins, metabolites, and extracellular vesicles/particles (EVPs) from the SpaceX Inspiration4 crew to generate "spaceflight secretome profiles." It revealed significant acute changes in coagulation, oxidative stress, and brain-enriched proteins following short-duration spaceflight. While most changes in vesicles and metabolites recovered within six months, a majority of plasma protein alterations (73%) persisted. The research suggested that immune cells contribute more to these changes than erythrocytes, and mouse models showed increases in PECAM-1 in brain tissue, indicating potential blood-brain barrier disruption. The study concludes that even short-duration spaceflight disrupts human and murine physiology and identifies key biomarkers.
impact: The findings are crucial for guiding astronaut biomedicine and developing countermeasures for spaceflight, especially with the rise of commercial space travel. By identifying specific blood-based biomarkers related to oxidative stress, brain homeostasis, and coagulation, this research provides valuable tools for monitoring crew health and designing targeted interventions to mitigate the physiological impacts of spaceflight.

title: Astronaut omics and the impact of space on the human body at scale
abstract: Future multi-year crewed planetary missions will motivate advances in aerospace nutrition and telehealth. On Earth, the Human Cell Atlas project aims to spatially map all cell types in the human body. Here, we propose that a parallel Human Cell Space Atlas could serve as an openly available, global resource for space life science research. As humanity becomes increasingly spacefaring, high-resolution omics on orbit could permit an advent of precision spaceflight healthcare. Alongside the scientific potential, we consider the complex ethical, cultural, and legal challenges intrinsic to the human space omics discipline, and how philosophical frameworks may benefit from international perspectives.
headings: Dangers of restrictive policies: scientific potential unused
Dangers of permissible policies: exposure to ethical harms
summary: This publication proposes the creation of a 'Human Cell Space Atlas' as an open, global resource for space life science research. This initiative, leveraging high-resolution omics data collected on orbit, aims to enable precision spaceflight healthcare for future multi-year crewed planetary missions. The authors also address critical ethical, cultural, and legal challenges inherent in human space omics, advocating for international perspectives and philosophical frameworks.
impact: The proposed 'Human Cell Space Atlas' and the advent of precision spaceflight healthcare would significantly advance aerospace nutrition and telehealth, providing a foundational resource for understanding the impact of space on the human body at a cellular and molecular level. It could lead to tailored medical interventions and nutritional strategies for astronauts, while also prompting crucial discussions on the ethical and policy implications of such data collection.
theme: Space omics, human health in space, precision spaceflight healthcare, ethical and policy considerations for space biology, molecular and cellular responses to space environments.
original_title: Astronaut omics and the impact of space on the human body at scale

title: Transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations underpinning spaceflight dermatology.
abstract:
Background

Spaceflight poses a unique set of challenges to humans and the hostile spaceflight environment can induce a wide range of increased health risks, including dermatological issues. The biology driving the frequency of skin issues in astronauts is currently not well understood.

Methods

To address this issue, we used a systems biology approach utilizing NASA’s Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) on space flown murine transcriptomic datasets focused on the skin, biochemical profiles of 50 NASA astronauts and human transcriptomic datasets generated from blood and hair samples of JAXA astronauts, as well as blood samples obtained from the NASA Twins Study, and skin and blood samples from the first civilian commercial mission, Inspiration4.

Results

Key biological changes related to skin health, DNA damage & repair, and mitochondrial dysregulation are identified as potential drivers for skin health risks during spaceflight. Additionally, a machine learning model is utilized to determine gene pairings associated with spaceflight response in the skin. While we identified spaceflight-induced dysregulation, such as alterations in genes associated with skin barrier function and collagen formation, our results also highlight the remarkable ability for organisms to re-adapt back to Earth via post-flight re-tuning of gene expression.

Conclusion

Our findings can guide future research on developing countermeasures for mitigating spaceflight-associated skin damage.

summary: This study used a systems biology approach, integrating murine and human transcriptomic datasets (from NASA's OSDR, JAXA, NASA Twins Study, and Inspiration4 mission) along with astronaut biochemical profiles, to understand the molecular basis of dermatological issues in spaceflight. Key findings indicate that spaceflight induces alterations in genes related to skin health, DNA damage and repair, and mitochondrial function. The research identified dysregulation in skin barrier function and collagen formation, while also highlighting the remarkable ability of organisms to re-adapt post-flight through gene expression re-tuning. A machine learning model was used to identify gene pairings associated with skin response to spaceflight.
impact: The findings provide crucial insights into the molecular mechanisms driving spaceflight-associated skin damage, which can guide future research and the development of countermeasures to mitigate these health risks for astronauts.

title: Cosmic kidney disease: an integrated pan-omic, physiological and morphological study into spaceflight-induced renal dysfunction
authors: Terry Chin Choy Lim Kam Sian
abstract: Missions into Deep Space are planned this decade. Yet the health consequences of exposure to microgravity and galactic cosmic radiation (GCR) over years-long missions on indispensable visceral organs such as the kidney are largely unexplored. We performed biomolecular (epigenomic, transcriptomic, proteomic, epiproteomic, metabolomic, metagenomic), clinical chemistry (electrolytes, endocrinology, biochemistry) and morphometry (histology, 3D imaging, miRNA-ISH, tissue weights) analyses using samples and datasets available from 11 spaceflight-exposed mouse and 5 human, 1 simulated microgravity rat and 4 simulated GCR-exposed mouse missions. We found that spaceflight induces: 1) renal transporter dephosphorylation which may indicate astronauts’ increased risk of nephrolithiasis is in part a primary renal phenomenon rather than solely a secondary consequence of bone loss; 2) remodelling of the nephron that results in expansion of distal convoluted tubule size but loss of overall tubule density; 3) renal damage and dysfunction when exposed to a Mars roundtrip dose-equivalent of simulated GCR.
headings: Primary changes in kidney function increase the risk of spaceflight-induced nephrolithiasis
Structural remodelling of the nephron occurs within a month of spaceflight exposure
Multi-omic analyses reveal convergent disease pathways induced by spaceflight
A GCR exposure with a dose-equivalent to a Mars roundtrip induces renal damage and dysfunction
summary: This study investigates the largely unexplored health consequences of microgravity and galactic cosmic radiation (GCR) on renal function during deep space missions. Utilizing a comprehensive pan-omic (epigenomic, transcriptomic, proteomic, epiproteomic, metabolomic, metagenomic), clinical chemistry, and morphometric approach on samples from spaceflight-exposed mice, humans, simulated microgravity rats, and simulated GCR-exposed mice, the researchers identified several key findings. Spaceflight was found to induce renal transporter dephosphorylation, suggesting that the increased risk of nephrolithiasis in astronauts is partly a primary renal phenomenon, not solely a secondary consequence of bone loss. Furthermore, the study revealed structural remodelling of the nephron, characterized by an expansion of distal convoluted tubule size but an overall loss of tubule density. Critically, exposure to a Mars roundtrip dose-equivalent of simulated GCR was shown to induce significant renal damage and dysfunction.
impact: The findings provide crucial insights into the physiological effects of deep spaceflight on the kidney, identifying specific mechanisms of renal dysfunction that could impact astronaut health. By demonstrating a primary renal component to nephrolithiasis risk and uncovering nephron remodelling and GCR-induced damage, this research challenges existing assumptions and highlights the need for targeted countermeasures. This work is indispensable for mitigating health risks and ensuring the long-term well-being of astronauts on future years-long deep space missions.
theme: Spaceflight-induced renal dysfunction and damage due to microgravity and galactic cosmic radiation, explored through integrated multi-omic, physiological, and morphological analyses.
original_title: Cosmic kidney disease: an integrated pan-omic, physiological and morphological study into spaceflight-induced renal dysfunction

title: Spaceflight induces changes in gene expression profiles linked to insulin and estrogen
abstract: Organismal adaptations to spaceflight have been characterized at the molecular level in model organisms, including Drosophila and C. elegans. Here, we extend molecular work to energy metabolism and sex hormone signaling in mice and humans. We found spaceflight induced changes in insulin and estrogen signaling in rodents and humans. Murine changes were most prominent in the liver, where we observed inhibition of insulin and estrogen receptor signaling with concomitant hepatic insulin resistance and steatosis. Based on the metabolic demand, metabolic pathways mediated by insulin and estrogen vary among muscles, specifically between the soleus and extensor digitorum longus. In humans, spaceflight induced changes in insulin and estrogen related genes and pathways. Pathway analysis demonstrated spaceflight induced changes in insulin resistance, estrogen signaling, stress response, and viral infection. These data strongly suggest the need for further research on the metabolic and reproductive endocrinologic effects of space travel, if we are to become a successful interplanetary species.

summary: This NASA Space Biology publication investigates the impact of spaceflight on energy metabolism and sex hormone signaling in mice and humans. The study found that spaceflight induces significant changes in insulin and estrogen signaling pathways in both species. In mice, these changes were most pronounced in the liver, leading to inhibition of insulin and estrogen receptor signaling, concomitant hepatic insulin resistance, and steatosis. Muscle-specific variations in metabolic pathways mediated by these hormones were also observed. In humans, spaceflight altered insulin and estrogen-related genes and pathways, impacting insulin resistance, estrogen signaling, stress response, and viral infection. The research highlights the global impact of spaceflight on these critical physiological systems.
impact: The findings underscore a critical need for further research into the metabolic and reproductive endocrinologic effects of space travel. Understanding these adaptations is essential for mitigating health risks and ensuring the long-term success and well-being of humans during future interplanetary missions, addressing fundamental challenges for humans to become a successful interplanetary species.
theme: Spaceflight induced physiological adaptations, specifically focusing on the molecular mechanisms of energy metabolism and sex hormone signaling (insulin and estrogen) in response to microgravity, and their implications for human health in space.

title: Protective alleles and precision healthcare in crewed spaceflight
abstract: Common and rare alleles are now being annotated across millions of human genomes, and omics technologies are increasingly being used to develop health and treatment recommendations. However, these alleles have not yet been systematically characterized relative to aerospace medicine. Here, we review published alleles naturally found in human cohorts that have a likely protective effect, which is linked to decreased cancer risk and improved bone, muscular, and cardiovascular health. Although some technical and ethical challenges remain, research into these protective mechanisms could translate into improved nutrition, exercise, and health recommendations for crew members during deep space missions.
headings: Studying omics for improved spaceflight safety
Studying omics for improved spaceflight nutrition
Pharmacogenomics and optimized drug prescribing in space
Technical challenges of studying human space omics
Ethical challenges of studying human space omics
summary: This publication reviews naturally occurring protective alleles in human cohorts, linking them to decreased cancer risk and improved bone, muscular, and cardiovascular health. It highlights the current lack of systematic characterization of these alleles in aerospace medicine, despite the increasing use of omics technologies for health recommendations. The research suggests that understanding these protective mechanisms could translate into enhanced nutrition, exercise, and health recommendations for crew members on deep space missions.
impact: Published in *Nat Commun* and authored by prominent experts, this review significantly advances scientific understanding by synthesizing knowledge on protective alleles within the novel context of aerospace medicine. Practically, it lays the groundwork for developing personalized health recommendations, optimized drug prescribing, and targeted countermeasures for astronauts during spaceflight. Broader implications include advancing precision healthcare on Earth by leveraging genetic insights for disease prevention and treatment, while also outlining critical technical and ethical challenges for future research.
theme: Genetics & Genomics for Spaceflight Health and Precision Medicine
original_title: Protective alleles and precision healthcare in crewed spaceflight

title: Author Correction: To boldly go where no microRNAs have gone before: spaceflight impact on risk for small-for-gestational-age infants
summary: This publication is an author correction to a study that investigated the impact of spaceflight on the risk for small-for-gestational-age (SGA) infants, specifically exploring the role of microRNAs in this process. The original research aimed to understand how the space environment affects reproductive outcomes and fetal development. While the specific nature of the correction is not detailed, the core objective was to assess the implications of space travel on infant health risks.
impact: This correction pertains to a scientifically significant study published in Communications Biology, exploring the complex interplay of spaceflight, microRNAs, and the risk of small-for-gestational-age infants, thus advancing our understanding of molecular mechanisms affected by the space environment. The research holds practical importance for future long-duration space missions and potential space colonization, informing astronaut health protocols and the development of countermeasures to mitigate reproductive risks. Beyond space, understanding these mechanisms could offer insights into environmental factors influencing infant development on Earth.
theme: Genetics & Genomics: Spaceflight Impact on Reproductive Health
original_title: To boldly go where no microRNAs have gone before: Spaceflight impact on risk for small-for-gestational-age infants

title: Bread Wheat in Space Flight: Is There a Difference in Kernel Quality?
abstract: Planning long-term space flights necessarily includes issues of providing food for the crew. One of the areas of research is the development of technologies for independent production of food by the crew. Extensive research on lettuce has confirmed that the “space production” of lettuce is not inferior to that on Earth, even in the absence of gravity, but the same deep understanding of the quality of grain crops has not yet been achieved. Therefore, the goal of our work is to establish whether the conditions for growing wheat in outer space without gravity affect the weight and basic parameters of the grain, and whether this leads to increased asymmetry of the kernel and distortion of the starch composition. The objects of the study were wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) kernels of the Super Dwarf cultivar. Of which, 100 kernels matured in outer space conditions in the Lada growth chamber on the International Space Station (ISS), and 85 kernels of the control wheat grown in a similar growth chamber under terrestrial conditions. It has been established that kernels from ISS have significant differences to a smaller extent in weight, area, length, and width of the kernel. However, the kernels under both conditions were predominantly large (the average weight of a kernel in space is 0.0362 g, and in terrestrial conditions—0.0376 g). The hypothesis that the level of fluctuating asymmetry will increase in outer space was not confirmed; significant differences between the options were not proven. In general, the kernels are fairly even (coefficients of variation for the main parameters of the kernel are within 6–12%) and with a low or very low level of asymmetry. The length of starch granules of type A in filled and puny kernels is significantly greater in kernels from ISS than in the control, and in terms of the width of starch granules B and roundness indices, both experimental variants are the same. It can be assumed that the baking qualities of earthly kernels will be slightly higher, since the ratio of type B starch granules to type A is 5–8% higher than on the ISS. Also, the width of the aleurone layer cells in mature kernels was significantly inferior to the result obtained on Earth. The work proposes a new method for establishing the asymmetry of kernels without a traumatic effect (in early works, it was supposed to study asymmetry in transverse sections of the kernels). Perhaps this will make it possible to further develop a computer scanning program that will determine the level of asymmetry of the wheat fruit.
summary: This study investigated whether growing wheat (Triticum aestivum L., Super Dwarf cultivar) in space on the ISS affects kernel weight, morphology, asymmetry, and starch composition compared to Earth-grown controls. While kernels from ISS showed significant but minor differences in weight, area, length, and width (average weight: 0.0362 g in space vs. 0.0376 g on Earth), the hypothesis of increased fluctuating asymmetry in space was not confirmed. Key findings include significantly greater length of type A starch granules in ISS kernels and a 5–8% higher ratio of type B to type A starch granules in terrestrial kernels, suggesting potentially superior baking qualities for Earth-grown wheat.
impact: Scientifically, this research deepens the understanding of microgravity's impact on grain crop development, particularly starch structure and kernel morphology, crucial for long-duration space missions. The findings that space-grown wheat kernels, while showing some differences, do not exhibit increased asymmetry and still produce substantial kernels are vital for advancing bioregenerative life support systems and food self-sufficiency in space. Methodologically, the proposal of a new, non-traumatic method for assessing kernel asymmetry could improve future plant biological studies both in space and on Earth, potentially leading to automated computer scanning programs for quality assessment.
original_title: Growth chambers on the International Space Station for large plants

title: Microbiological and Nutritional Analysis of Lettuce Crops Grown on the International Space Station
abstract: The ability to grow safe, fresh food to supplement packaged foods of astronauts in space has been an important goal for NASA. Food crops grown in space experience different environmental conditions than plants grown on Earth (e.g., reduced gravity, elevated radiation levels). To study the effects of space conditions, red romaine lettuce, Lactuca sativa cv ‘Outredgeous,’ plants were grown in Veggie plant growth chambers on the International Space Station (ISS) and compared with ground-grown plants. Multiple plantings were grown on ISS and harvested using either a single, final harvest, or sequential harvests in which several mature leaves were removed from the plants at weekly intervals. Ground controls were grown simultaneously with a 24–72 h delay using ISS environmental data. Food safety of the plants was determined by heterotrophic plate counts for bacteria and fungi, as well as isolate identification using samples taken from the leaves and roots. Molecular characterization was conducted using Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) to provide taxonomic composition and phylogenetic structure of the community. Leaves were also analyzed for elemental composition, as well as levels of phenolics, anthocyanins, and Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC). Comparison of flight and ground tissues showed some differences in total counts for bacteria and yeast/molds (2.14 – 4.86 log10 CFU/g), while screening for select human pathogens yielded negative results. Bacterial and fungal isolate identification and community characterization indicated variation in the diversity of genera between leaf and root tissue with diversity being higher in root tissue, and included differences in the dominant genera. The only difference between ground and flight experiments was seen in the third experiment, VEG-03A, with significant differences in the genera from leaf tissue. Flight and ground tissue showed differences in Fe, K, Na, P, S, and Zn content and total phenolic levels, but no differences in anthocyanin and ORAC levels. This study indicated that leafy vegetable crops can produce safe, edible, fresh food to supplement to the astronauts’ diet, and provide baseline data for continual operation of the Veggie plant growth units on ISS.
headings: Microbial DNA Isolation, 16S and ITS PCR, and Sequencing
Microbial Counts on Leaves and Roots
Cultivated Bacterial and Fungal Isolate Identification
Total Phenolics, Anthocyanins and ORAC Analysis
summary: This study investigated the microbiological safety and nutritional content of red romaine lettuce grown on the International Space Station (ISS) compared to Earth controls. While some differences in total bacterial and fungal counts (2.14 – 4.86 log10 CFU/g) and specific elemental (Fe, K, Na, P, S, Zn) and phenolic levels were observed between flight and ground tissues, no human pathogens were detected. The findings indicate that leafy greens can be safely grown in space to supplement astronaut diets, providing critical baseline data for continual operation of the Veggie plant growth units on ISS.
impact: This research significantly advances space biology by demonstrating the feasibility and safety of growing fresh produce on the ISS, directly supporting astronaut nutritional and psychological well-being on long-duration missions. Scientifically, it provides critical baseline data on plant microbiology and nutritional changes in microgravity, utilizing advanced techniques like Next Generation Sequencing. The findings have practical implications for designing sustainable food systems for future space exploration and could inform terrestrial controlled environment agriculture.
theme: Microgravity Effects on Plant Biology for Food Production
original_title: Microbiological and nutritional analysis of lettuce crops grown on the International Space Station

title: Natural variation in the expression of ORGANIC CATION TRANSPORTER 1 affects root length responses to cadaverine in Arabidopsis.
abstract: Polyamines, including cadaverine, are organic cations that affect numerous biological processes including transcription, translation, cell signalling, and ion channel activity. They often function in biotic and abiotic stress responses in plants. Because little is known about how plants respond to cadaverine, a quantitative natural variation approach was used to identify genetic factors that contribute to this response. Here it is shown that Arabidopsis thaliana accessions have varying root length responses to exogenous cadaverine: Cape Verde Islands (Cvi) was one of the most resistant accessions tested, whereas Landsberg erecta (Ler) was one of the most sensitive. Recombinant inbred lines, near isogenic lines, and a microarray were used to show that variation in ORGANIC CATION TRANSPORTER 1 (OCT1) is at least partially responsible for this difference. OCT1 expression was higher in Cvi than in Ler, and oct1 mutants were more sensitive to cadaverine than wild-type plants. In oct1 mutants transformed with an ectopic copy of OCT1 originating from either Cvi or Ler, the expression level of the transgene, not its accession, correlated with the cadaverine response. These results suggest that decreased OCT1 expression confers cadaverine sensitivity in some accessions.
summary: This study investigated the genetic factors influencing Arabidopsis thaliana's root length responses to exogenous cadaverine. Researchers found significant natural variation among accessions, with Cape Verde Islands (Cvi) being resistant and Landsberg erecta (Ler) sensitive. Variation in ORGANIC CATION TRANSPORTER 1 (OCT1) expression was identified as a key factor, with higher OCT1 expression in Cvi correlating with cadaverine resistance, suggesting decreased OCT1 expression confers sensitivity.
impact: This research significantly advances understanding of plant polyamine responses by identifying OCT1 as a crucial genetic determinant of cadaverine sensitivity, utilizing robust natural variation and genetic approaches. While not directly applicable to space missions, this fundamental plant biology study contributes to knowledge of plant stress responses, which could inform future efforts in developing stress-resilient plants for diverse environments, including potential controlled ecological life support systems. The publication in J Exp Bot. and authorship by Patrick H Masson suggest high scientific rigor and expertise.
original_title: Natural variation in the expression of ORGANIC CATION TRANSPORTER 1 affects root length responses to cadaverine in Arabidopsis.

title: Turbidity matters: differential effect of a 2,4-D formulation on the structure of microbial communities from clear and turbid freshwater systems
abstract: We evaluated the effect of AsiMax 50®, a commercial formulation of 2,4-D (2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid), on the structure of both micro + nano phytoplankton (>2 μm; species composition and abundance) and cytometric populations (photosynthetic picoplankton (PPP, 0.2–2 μm), which included prokaryotic phycocyanin-rich picocyanobacteria (PC-Pcy), phycoerythrin-rich picocyanobacteria (PE-Pcy) and eukaryotic phototrophs (PEuk); and bacterioplankton (HB), heterotrophic bacteria), using a microcosms-based approach and a single 7-day exposure. Assays were performed on two different microbial assemblages sampled from freshwater bodies of two contrasting turbidity status: clear (chlorophyll a = 7.6 μgL-1, turbidity = 1 NTU) and organic turbid systems (chlorophyll a = 25.0 μgL-1, turbidity = 9 NTU). For each system, the herbicide was applied to 500 mL-Erlenmeyer flasks, at seven concentration levels of the active ingredient (a.i.): 0 (control = no addition), 0.02, 0.2, 2, 20, 200 and 2,000 mg a.i.L−1. The impact of AsiMax 50® seemed to be greater in the turbid system. In this system, total abundance of living (live) micro + nano phytoplankton showed a significant increase at lower concentrations and data were fitted to a humped-shaped curve. For both clear and organic turbid systems, micro + nano phytoplankton decreased in species richness and abundance at higher herbicide concentrations. These results suggest that 2,4-D may mimic hormonal function. Some species, such as Ochromonas sp. and Chlamydomonas sp., showed different responses to herbicide exposure between water systems. In the turbid system, the increase in abundance of the PPP fraction observed at 7-d exposure was probably due to either an increase in PE-Pcy (thus suggesting the existence of auxin pathways) or a reduction in competitive pressure by micro + nano plankton. Our results provide some evidence of the importance of using community-scale approaches in ecotoxicological studies to predict changes in freshwater ecosystems exposed to a 2,4-D-based formulation. However, caution must be taken when extrapolating these effects to real scenarios, as assays were based on a laboratory microcosm experiment.
summary: This study evaluated the 7-day effect of the 2,4-D formulation AsiMax 50® on microbial communities from clear (chlorophyll a = 7.6 μgL-1, turbidity = 1 NTU) and turbid (chlorophyll a = 25.0 μgL-1, turbidity = 9 NTU) freshwater systems using microcosms. The herbicide's impact was greater in the turbid system, where lower concentrations caused a significant increase in total living micro + nano phytoplankton following a humped-shaped curve, while higher concentrations decreased richness and abundance in both systems. Results highlight the importance of community-scale ecotoxicological studies for freshwater ecosystems, though caution is advised for real-world extrapolation from laboratory microcosm findings.
impact: Scientifically, this study advances ecotoxicological understanding by demonstrating the differential effects of a 2,4-D formulation on freshwater microbial communities based on turbidity, suggesting hormonal mimicry and the necessity of community-level assessments. While not directly space-related, the principles of assessing chemical impacts on complex microbial ecosystems could inform the design and maintenance of closed-loop life support systems or bioregenerative systems for space missions. Broadly, this research provides crucial insights for environmental risk assessment and regulation of 2,4-D herbicides in terrestrial freshwater environments, emphasizing that turbidity must be considered to accurately predict ecological impacts and guide future field validation studies.
original_title: Auxin: Shape matters.

title: Mechanosensing antagonizes ethylene signaling to promote root gravitropism in rice
abstract: Root gravitropism relies on gravity perception by the root cap and requires tightly regulated phytohormone signaling. Here, we isolate a rice mutant that displays root coiling in hydroponics but normal gravitropic growth in soil. We identify COILING ROOT IN WATER 1 (CRW1) encoding an ETHYLENE-INSENSITIVE3 (EIN3)-BINDING F-BOX PROTEIN (OsEBF1) as the causative gene for the mutant phenotype. We show that the OsCRW1-EIN3 LIKE 1 and 2 (OsEIL1/2)-ETHYLENE RESPONSE FACTOR 82 (OsERF82) module controls the production of reactive oxygen species in the root tip, subsequently impacting root cap stability, polar localization of PIN-FORMED 2 (OsPIN2), symmetric distribution of auxin, and ultimately gravitropic growth of roots. The OsEIL1/2-OsERF82 ethylene signaling module is effectively impeded by applying gentle mechanical resistance to root tips, including growing in water-saturated paddy soil. We further show that mechanosensing-induced calcium signaling is required and sufficient for antagonizing the ethylene signaling pathway. This study has revealed previously unanticipated interplay among ethylene, auxin, and mechanosensing in the control of plant gravitropism.
summary: This study investigated the regulation of root gravitropism in rice, identifying COILING ROOT IN WATER 1 (CRW1), encoding an ETHYLENE-INSENSITIVE3 (EIN3)-BINDING F-BOX PROTEIN (OsEBF1), as the causative gene for a mutant displaying root coiling in hydroponics but normal gravitropism in soil. The research revealed that an OsCRW1-EIN3 LIKE 1 and 2 (OsEIL1/2)-ETHYLENE RESPONSE FACTOR 82 (OsERF82) ethylene signaling module is effectively impeded by mechanosensing-induced calcium signaling. This work elucidated a previously unanticipated interplay among ethylene, auxin, and mechanosensing in the control of plant gravitropism.
impact: This publication significantly advances the understanding of plant gravitropism by elucidating novel molecular mechanisms and a complex interplay among ethylene, auxin, and mechanosensing, including the role of calcium signaling. For space biology, this research provides critical foundational knowledge for optimizing plant growth and stability in microgravity or altered gravity environments, directly supporting the development of sustainable food systems for long-duration space missions. Beyond space applications, these findings have broader implications for improving crop establishment and resilience in diverse terrestrial agricultural settings.
original_title: Gravity signaling in flowering plant roots

title: Cadaverine regulates biotin synthesis to modulate primary root growth in Arabidopsis
abstract: Cadaverine, a polyamine, has been linked to modification of root growth architecture and response to environmental stresses in plants. However, the molecular mechanisms that govern the regulation of root growth by cadaverine are largely unexplored. Here we conducted a forward genetic screen and isolated a mutation, cadaverine hypersensitive 3 (cdh3), which resulted in increased root‐growth sensitivity to cadaverine, but not other polyamines. This mutation affects the BIO3‐BIO1 biotin biosynthesis gene. Exogenous supply of biotin and a pathway intermediate downstream of BIO1, 7,8‐diaminopelargonic acid, suppressed this cadaverine sensitivity phenotype. An in vitro enzyme assay showed cadaverine inhibits the BIO3‐BIO1 activity. Furthermore, cadaverine‐treated seedlings displayed reduced biotinylation of Biotin Carboxyl Carrier Protein 1 of the acetyl‐coenzyme A carboxylase complex involved in de novo fatty acid biosynthesis, resulting in decreased accumulation of triacylglycerides. Taken together, these results revealed an unexpected role of cadaverine in the regulation of biotin biosynthesis, which leads to modulation of primary root growth of plants.
summary: This study investigated the molecular mechanisms by which cadaverine, a polyamine, regulates primary root growth in *Arabidopsis thaliana*. Researchers identified a mutation, *cadaverine hypersensitive 3 (cdh3)*, affecting the *BIO3-BIO1* biotin biosynthesis gene, which led to increased root-growth sensitivity to cadaverine. The findings revealed that cadaverine inhibits *BIO3-BIO1* activity and reduces biotinylation of Biotin Carboxyl Carrier Protein 1, thereby modulating biotin synthesis and primary root growth.
impact: Scientifically, this research significantly advances our understanding of plant growth regulation by elucidating a novel pathway where cadaverine directly inhibits biotin synthesis, an unexpected role. For space missions, this fundamental knowledge of plant metabolism and root development is critical for optimizing controlled environment agriculture and crop resilience in extraterrestrial environments. Broadly, these insights could inform strategies for enhancing plant development and stress tolerance in terrestrial agriculture.
original_title: Cadaverine regulates biotin synthesis to modulate primary root growth in Arabidopsis

title: Low-Speed Clinorotation of Brachypodium distachyon and Arabidopsis thaliana Seedlings Triggers Root Tip Curvatures That Are Reminiscent of Gravitropism
abstract: Clinostats are instruments that continuously rotate biological specimens along an axis, thereby averaging their orientation relative to gravity over time. Our previous experiments indicated that low-speed clinorotation may itself trigger directional root tip curvature. In this project, we have investigated the root curvature response to low-speed clinorotation using Arabidopsis thaliana and Brachypodium distachyon seedlings as models. We show that low-speed clinorotation triggers root tip curvature in which direction is dictated by gravitropism during the first half-turn of clinorotation. We also show that the angle of root tip curvature is modulated by the speed of clinorotation. Arabidopsis mutations affecting gravity susception (pgm) or gravity signal transduction (arg1, toc132) are shown to affect the root tip curvature response to low-speed clinorotation. Furthermore, low-speed vertical clinorotation triggers relocalization of the PIN3 auxin efflux facilitator to the lateral membrane of Arabidopsis root cap statocytes, and creates a lateral gradient of auxin across the root tip. Together, these observations support a role for gravitropism in modulating root curvature responses to clinorotation. Interestingly, distinct Brachypodium distachyon accessions display different abilities to develop root tip curvature responses to low-speed vertical clinorotation, suggesting the possibility of using genome-wide association studies to further investigate this process.
summary: This study investigated how low-speed clinorotation, a common microgravity simulation technique, triggers root tip curvatures in *Arabidopsis thaliana* and *Brachypodium distachyon* seedlings. It found that gravitropism dictates the curvature direction and clinorotation speed modulates its angle, with specific genetic mutations (pgm, arg1, toc132) and *Brachypodium* accessions affecting the response. The research, showing PIN3 auxin relocalization and lateral auxin gradients, supports a crucial role for gravitropism in modulating plant root responses to clinorotation.
impact: This publication significantly advances the scientific understanding of plant gravisensing and response under simulated microgravity by detailing molecular (PIN3, auxin gradients) and genetic mechanisms in *Arabidopsis* and identifying genetic variability in *Brachypodium*. Practically, it refines the interpretation of ground-based clinostat experiments for future space missions, improving methodologies for assessing plant growth and development in altered gravity environments. Broadly, it opens avenues for genome-wide association studies in *Brachypodium* to identify novel genes involved in gravitropism and mechanical sensing.
original_title: Low-speed clinorotation of Brachypodium distachyon and Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings triggers root tip curvatures that are reminiscent of gravitropism.

title: New Device for High-Throughput Viability Screening of Flow Biofilms
abstract: Control of biofilms requires rapid methods to identify compounds effective against them and to isolate resistance-compromised mutants for identifying genes involved in enhanced biofilm resistance. While rapid screening methods for microtiter plate well (“static”) biofilms are available, there are no methods for such screening of continuous flow biofilms (“flow biofilms”). Since the latter biofilms more closely approximate natural biofilms, development of a high-throughput (HTP) method for screening them is desirable. We describe here a new method using a device comprised of microfluidic channels and a distributed pneumatic pump (BioFlux) that provides fluid flow to 96 individual biofilms. This device allows fine control of continuous or intermittent fluid flow over a broad range of flow rates, and the use of a standard well plate format provides compatibility with plate readers. We show that use of green fluorescent protein (GFP)-expressing bacteria, staining with propidium iodide, and measurement of fluorescence with a plate reader permit rapid and accurate determination of biofilm viability. The biofilm viability measured with the plate reader agreed with that determined using plate counts, as well as with the results of fluorescence microscope image analysis. Using BioFlux and the plate reader, we were able to rapidly screen the effects of several antimicrobials on the viability of Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 flow biofilms.
summary: This study developed a new high-throughput (HTP) method for screening continuous flow biofilms, which more accurately mimic natural biofilms than static versions. The researchers describe a novel microfluidic device, BioFlux, which provides controlled fluid flow to 96 individual biofilms. They demonstrated that using GFP-expressing bacteria, propidium iodide staining, and a plate reader allowed for rapid and accurate determination of biofilm viability, correlating with traditional plate counts and fluorescence microscopy, thereby enabling swift screening of antimicrobial effects on *Pseudomonas aeruginosa* PAO1 flow biofilms.
impact: Scientifically, this work significantly advances biofilm research methodology by introducing the first HTP screening method for continuous flow biofilms, addressing a critical gap in studying these ecologically relevant structures. Practically, this technology has direct applications for NASA's space missions, facilitating the rapid identification of effective compounds to control biofilm growth on spacecraft and within life support systems, thereby safeguarding astronaut health and equipment integrity. Broader implications include accelerating antimicrobial discovery, understanding biofilm resistance mechanisms, and improving control strategies in medical, industrial, and environmental settings.
original_title: New device for high-throughput viability screening of flow biofilms

title: Sigma S-Dependent Antioxidant Defense Protects Stationary-Phase Escherichia coli against the Bactericidal Antibiotic Gentamicin
abstract: Stationary-phase bacteria are important in disease. The σs-regulated general stress response helps them become resistant to disinfectants, but the role of σs in bacterial antibiotic resistance has not been elucidated. Loss of σs rendered stationary-phase Escherichia coli more sensitive to the bactericidal antibiotic gentamicin (Gm), and proteomic analysis suggested involvement of a weakened antioxidant defense. Use of the psfiA genetic reporter, 3′-(p-hydroxyphenyl) fluorescein (HPF) dye, and Amplex Red showed that Gm generated more reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the mutant. HPF measurements can be distorted by cell elongation, but Gm did not affect stationary-phase cell dimensions. Coadministration of the antioxidant N-acetyl cysteine (NAC) decreased drug lethality particularly in the mutant, as did Gm treatment under anaerobic conditions that prevent ROS formation. Greater oxidative stress, due to insufficient quenching of endogenous ROS and/or respiration-linked electron leakage, therefore contributed to the greater sensitivity of the mutant; infection by a uropathogenic strain in mice showed this to be the case also in vivo. Disruption of antioxidant defense by eliminating the quencher proteins, SodA/SodB and KatE/SodA, or the pentose phosphate pathway proteins, Zwf/Gnd and TalA, which provide NADPH for ROS decomposition, also generated greater oxidative stress and killing by Gm. Thus, besides its established mode of action, Gm also kills stationary-phase bacteria by generating oxidative stress, and targeting the antioxidant defense of E. coli can enhance its efficacy. Relevant aspects of the current controversy on the role of ROS in killing by bactericidal drugs of exponential-phase bacteria, which represent a different physiological state, are discussed.
summary: This study investigated the role of the σs-regulated general stress response in bacterial antibiotic resistance, specifically how loss of σs made stationary-phase Escherichia coli more sensitive to the bactericidal antibiotic gentamicin (Gm). Key findings revealed that σs-deficient mutants exhibited a weakened antioxidant defense, leading to increased generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and greater susceptibility to Gm, a mechanism confirmed in vivo using a uropathogenic strain in mice. The research concludes that Gm kills stationary-phase bacteria by generating oxidative stress, suggesting that targeting the antioxidant defense of E. coli can enhance its efficacy.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of antibiotic resistance mechanisms by elucidating the crucial role of σs-dependent antioxidant defense and oxidative stress in the killing of stationary-phase bacteria by gentamicin. Practically, these findings offer a novel strategy for combating antibiotic-resistant infections, which is highly relevant for astronaut health during long-duration space missions where immune function may be altered. Broader implications include the development of adjuvant therapies that target bacterial antioxidant systems to improve the efficacy of existing antibiotics in both space and terrestrial healthcare settings, addressing a critical public health challenge.
original_title: Sigma S-dependent antioxidant defense protects stationary-phase Escherichia coli against the bactericidal antibiotic gentamicin

title: Plasma membrane disruption (PMD) formation and repair in mechanosensitive tissues
abstract: Mammalian cells employ an array of biological mechanisms to detect and respond to mechanical loading in their environment. One such mechanism is the formation of plasma membrane disruptions (PMD), which foster a molecular flux across cell membranes that promotes tissue adaptation. Repair of PMD through an orchestrated activity of molecular machinery is critical for cell survival, and the rate of PMD repair can affect downstream cellular signaling. PMD have been observed to influence the mechanical behavior of skin, alveolar, and gut epithelial cells, aortic endothelial cells, corneal keratocytes and epithelial cells, cardiac and skeletal muscle myocytes, neurons, and most recently, bone cells including osteoblasts, periodontal ligament cells, and osteocytes. PMD are therefore positioned to affect the physiological behavior of a wide range of vertebrate organ systems including skeletal and cardiac muscle, skin, eyes, the gastrointestinal tract, the vasculature, the respiratory system, and the skeleton. The purpose of this review is to describe the processes of PMD formation and repair across these mechanosensitive tissues, with a particular emphasis on comparing and contrasting repair mechanisms and downstream signaling to better understand the role of PMD in skeletal mechanobiology. The implications of PMD-related mechanisms for disease and potential therapeutic applications are also explored.
headings: 3. Cell specific PMD repair and signaling pathways
summary: This review investigates plasma membrane disruptions (PMD) as a key cellular mechanism for detecting and responding to mechanical loading, which promotes tissue adaptation. It details the processes of PMD formation and repair across various mechanosensitive tissues, including skin, muscle, neurons, and critically, bone cells like osteoblasts and osteocytes. The publication aims to compare repair mechanisms and downstream signaling to better understand PMD's role in skeletal mechanobiology, exploring their implications for disease and potential therapeutic applications.
impact: Scientifically, this publication significantly advances the understanding of plasma membrane disruptions (PMD) as a fundamental and widespread mechanism of mechanosensation and cellular response to mechanical stimuli. For space biology, this research is crucial for astronaut health, as understanding PMD's role in bone and muscle mechanobiology can inform strategies to mitigate degradation caused by microgravity. Broader implications include potential terrestrial therapeutic applications for diseases affecting mechanosensitive tissues, leveraging insights into cellular repair and signaling pathways.
original_title: Plasma membrane disruption (PMD) formation and repair in mechanosensitive tissues

title: Effects of Spaceflight on the Mouse Submandibular Gland
abstract:
Objective:
This study was conducted to determine if the morphology and biochemistry of the mouse submandibular gland is affected by microgravity and the spaceflight environment.
Design:
Tissues from female mice flown on the US space shuttle missions Space Transportation System (STS)-131 and STS-135 for 15 and 13 d, respectively, and from male mice flown on the 30 d Russian Bion-M1 biosatellite, were examined using transmission electron microscopy and light and electron microscopic immunohistochemistry.
Results:
In contrast to the parotid gland, morphologic changes were not apparent in the submandibular gland. No significant changes in protein expression, as assessed by quantitative immunogold labeling, occurred in female mice flown for 13-15 d. In male mice, however, increased labeling for salivary androgen binding protein alpha (in acinar cell secretory granules), and epidermal growth factor and nerve growth factor (in granular convoluted duct cell granules) was seen after 30 d in space.
Conclusion:
These results indicate that spaceflight alters secretory protein expression in the submandibular gland and suggest that the sex of the animals and the length of the flight may affect the response. These findings also show that individual salivary glands respond differently to spaceflight. Saliva contains proteins secreted from salivary glands and is easily collected, therefore is a useful biofluid for general medical analyses and in particular for monitoring the physiology and health of astronauts.
summary: This study investigated the effects of spaceflight on the morphology and biochemistry of the mouse submandibular gland, utilizing tissues from female mice flown for 13-15 days and male mice for 30 days on US Space Shuttle and Russian Bion-M1 missions, respectively. While no morphological changes or significant protein expression alterations were observed in female mice, male mice exhibited increased expression of salivary androgen binding protein alpha, epidermal growth factor, and nerve growth factor after 30 days in space. These findings indicate that spaceflight alters submandibular gland secretory protein expression, suggesting that animal sex and flight duration influence the response, and highlight saliva's potential as a biofluid for astronaut health monitoring.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of how specific biological systems, like salivary glands, respond heterogeneously to the space environment, emphasizing the importance of factors like animal sex and flight duration in observed physiological changes. From a practical standpoint, the identification of saliva as an accessible biofluid for monitoring astronaut health offers a non-invasive diagnostic tool crucial for long-duration space missions. The study also underscores the need for personalized medical approaches in space, considering varied individual responses to microgravity and the unique challenges of the spaceflight environment.
original_title: Microgravity alters the expression of salivary proteins
