original_title: Molecular muscle experiment: Hardware and operational lessons for future astrobiology space experiments

title: Tart Cherry Increases Lifespan in Caenorhabditis elegans by Altering Metabolic Signaling Pathways
abstract: Aging and healthspan are determined by both environmental and genetic factors. The insulin/insulin-like growth factor-1(IGF-1) pathway is a key mediator of aging in Caenorhabditis elegans and mammals. Specifically, DAF-2 signaling, an ortholog of human IGF, controls DAF-16/FOXO transcription factor, a master regulator of metabolism and longevity. Moreover, mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress are both linked to aging. We propose that daily supplementation of tart cherry extract (TCE), rich in anthocyanins with antioxidant properties may exert dual benefits for mitochondrial function and oxidative stress, resulting in beneficial effects on aging in C. elegans. We found that TCE supplementation at 6 μg or 12 μg/mL, increased (p < 0.05) the mean lifespan of wild type N2 worms, respectively, when compared to untreated control worms. Consistent with these findings, TCE upregulated (p < 0.05) expression of longevity-related genes such as daf-16 and aak-2 (but not daf-2 or akt-1 genes) and genes related to oxidative stress such as sod-2. Further, we showed that TCE supplementation increased spare respiration in N2 worms. However, TCE did not change the mean lifespan of daf-16 and aak-2 mutant worms. In conclusion, our findings indicate that TCE confers healthspan benefits in C. elegans through enhanced mitochondrial function and reduced oxidative stress, mainly via the DAF-16 pathway.
summary: This study investigated if tart cherry extract (TCE), rich in anthocyanins, could extend lifespan and improve healthspan in *C. elegans* by altering metabolic signaling and reducing oxidative stress. Researchers found that TCE supplementation at 6 μg or 12 μg/mL significantly increased (p < 0.05) the mean lifespan of wild type N2 worms and upregulated longevity-related genes such as *daf-16* and *aak-2*, along with the oxidative stress gene *sod-2*. These benefits, which also included increased spare respiration, were primarily mediated through the DAF-16 pathway, as TCE did not impact the lifespan of *daf-16* and *aak-2* mutant worms.
impact: Scientifically, this research advances our understanding of how natural compounds like tart cherry can influence key aging pathways, specifically the DAF-16 pathway, and cellular processes like mitochondrial function and oxidative stress. For space missions and astronaut health, these findings are highly significant as they identify a potential dietary countermeasure to mitigate age-related decline and oxidative stress, which could be exacerbated by the space environment. Broader implications suggest tart cherry extract as a promising nutraceutical for human healthspan extension on Earth, warranting further research in mammalian models and clinical trials to confirm these anti-aging effects.
theme: Countermeasures for Longevity and Oxidative Stress
original_title: Tart Cherry Increases Lifespan in Caenorhabditis elegans by Altering Metabolic Signaling Pathways

title: A Region of UNC-89 (obscurin) Lying Between Two Protein Kinase Domains is a Highly Elastic Spring Required for Proper Sarcomere Organization
abstract: In C. elegans, unc-89 encodes a set of giant multi-domain proteins (up 8,081 residues) localized to the M-lines of muscle sarcomeres and required for normal sarcomere organization and whole-animal locomotion. Multiple UNC-89 isoforms contain two protein kinase domains. There is conservation in arrangement of domains between UNC-89 and its two mammalian homologs, obscurin and SPEG: kinase, a non-domain region of 647–742 residues, Ig domain, Fn3 domain and a second kinase domain. In all three proteins, this non-domain “interkinase region” has low sequence complexity, high proline content and lacks predicted secondary structure. We report that a major portion of this interkinase (571 residues out of 647 residues) when examined by single molecule force spectroscopy in vitro displays the properties of a random coil and acts as an entropic spring. We used CRISPR/Cas9 to create nematodes carrying an in-frame deletion of the same 571-residue portion of the interkinase. These animals display severe disorganization of all portions of the sarcomere in body wall muscle. Super-resolution microscopy reveals extra, short-A-bands lying close to the outer muscle cell membrane and between normally spaced A-bands. Nematodes with this in-frame deletion show defective locomotion and muscle force generation. We designed our CRISPR-generated in-frame deletion to contain an HA tag at the N-terminus of the large UNC-89 isoforms. This HA tag results in normal organization of body wall muscle, but approximately half the normal levels of the giant UNC-89 isoforms, dis-organization of pharyngeal muscle, small body size, and reduced muscle force, likely due to poor nutritional uptake.
summary: This study identified a 571-residue portion of the interkinase region in *C. elegans* UNC-89 (obscurin) as a highly elastic entropic spring crucial for muscle function. Deleting this region via CRISPR/Cas9 led to severe sarcomere disorganization, characterized by extra, short-A-bands, and resulted in defective locomotion and muscle force generation in nematodes. While an HA tag initially caused normal body wall muscle organization, it halved the giant UNC-89 isoforms and led to other muscle and growth defects.
impact: This research significantly advances the fundamental understanding of muscle protein mechanics and sarcomere organization by characterizing the role of an elastic spring within the giant obscurin protein. The findings on muscle disorganization and reduced force generation have direct relevance to space biology, informing challenges such as muscle atrophy in microgravity and the development of countermeasures for astronaut health. Broadly, this work contributes to understanding muscle diseases on Earth and could inspire future therapeutic strategies for maintaining muscle function.
original_title: A region of UNC-89 (obscurin) lying between two protein kinase domains is a highly elastic spring required for proper sarcomere organization

title: NemaLife chip: a micropillar-based microfluidic culture device optimized for aging studies in crawling C. elegans
abstract: In this study, we report a microfluidic device for the whole-life culture of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans that allows the scoring of animal survival and health measures. This device referred to as the NemaLife chip features: (1) an optimized micropillar arena in which animals can crawl, (2) sieve channels that separate progeny and prevent the loss of adults from the arena during culture maintenance, and (3) ports that allow rapid accessibility for feeding the adult-only population and introducing reagents as needed. The pillar arena geometry was optimized to accommodate the growing body size during culture and emulate the body gait and locomotion of animals reared on agar. Likewise, feeding protocols were optimized to recapitulate longevity outcomes typical of standard plate growth. Key benefits of the NemaLife Chip include eliminating the need to perform repeated manual transfers of adults during survival assays, negating the need for progeny-blocking chemical interventions, and avoiding the swim-induced stress across lifespan in animals reared in liquid. We also show that the culture of animals in pillar-less microfluidic chambers reduces lifespan and introduces physiological stress by increasing the occurrence of age-related vulval integrity disorder. We validated our pillar-based device with longevity analyses of classical aging mutants (daf-2, age-1, eat-2, and daf-16) and animals subjected to RNAi knockdown of age-related genes (age-1 and daf-16). We also showed that healthspan measures such as pharyngeal pumping and tap-induced stimulated reversals can be scored across the lifespan in the NemaLife chip. Overall, the capacity to generate reliable lifespan and physiological data underscores the potential of the NemaLife chip to accelerate healthspan and lifespan investigations in C. elegans.
headings: Optimization of the NemaLife chip design
Selection of the optimal micropillar geometry based on locomotion and lifespan outcomes
Effect of population density on animal lifespan in the micropillar chamber
Whole-life C. elegans studies in pillar-less microfluidic chambers
Comparison of C. elegans lifespan in device and on agar
Lifespan studies using mutants and RNAi interventions
Scoring healthspan measures in C. elegans
summary: This study reports the development and optimization of the NemaLife chip, a micropillar-based microfluidic device designed for whole-life culture and aging studies of *C. elegans*. The device features an optimized micropillar arena for crawling, sieve channels for progeny separation, and ports for feeding, eliminating the need for manual transfers, progeny-blocking chemicals, and swim-induced stress. Validated with classical aging mutants (daf-2, age-1, eat-2, daf-16) and RNAi interventions, the NemaLife chip also allows scoring of healthspan measures like pharyngeal pumping, thereby accelerating reliable lifespan and healthspan investigations.
impact: This technology significantly advances *C. elegans* aging research by providing a high-throughput, standardized microfluidic platform for whole-life studies, reducing experimental variability and manual labor, and demonstrating that pillar-less chambers reduce lifespan and introduce physiological stress. For space biology, this development offers a robust tool for investigating genetic and environmental factors on aging and healthspan in a model organism, which could be adapted for long-duration space missions to study stress responses or test countermeasures relevant to astronaut health. Its broader implications include accelerating drug discovery for age-related conditions on Earth and improving the consistency of lifespan studies globally.
theme: Technology Development for C. elegans Aging Studies
original_title: NemaLife chip: a micropillar-based microfluidic culture device optimized for aging studies in crawling C. elegans

title: Spaceflight affects neuronal morphology and alters transcellular degradation of neuronal debris in adult Caenorhabditis elegans
abstract: Extended space travel is a goal of government space agencies and private companies. However, spaceflight poses risks to human health, and the effects on the nervous system have to be better characterized. Here, we exploited the unique experimental advantages of the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans to explore how spaceflight affects adult neurons in vivo. We found that animals that lived 5 days of adulthood on the International Space Station exhibited hyperbranching in PVD and touch receptor neurons. We also found that, in the presence of a neuronal proteotoxic stress, spaceflight promotes a remarkable accumulation of neuronal-derived waste in the surrounding tissues, suggesting an impaired transcellular degradation of debris released from neurons. Our data reveal that spaceflight can significantly affect adult neuronal morphology and clearance of neuronal trash, highlighting the need to carefully assess the risks of long-duration spaceflight on the nervous system and to develop adequate countermeasures for safe space exploration.
summary: This study investigated how 5 days of spaceflight on the International Space Station affects adult neurons in *Caenorhabditis elegans* in vivo, aiming to characterize risks to the nervous system during extended space travel. Researchers found that spaceflight led to hyperbranching in PVD and touch receptor neurons and, under neuronal proteotoxic stress, caused a remarkable accumulation of neuronal waste due to impaired transcellular degradation. These findings highlight that spaceflight significantly impacts adult neuronal morphology and debris clearance, emphasizing the need to assess and mitigate risks to the nervous system for safe, long-duration space exploration.
impact: This research significantly advances our scientific understanding of microgravity's impact on neuronal health by revealing specific morphological changes and impaired waste clearance, thus contributing critically to space biology and neuroscience. Practically, these findings highlight potential risks to astronaut nervous systems during extended space missions, which can inform the development of health monitoring strategies and essential countermeasures. Broader implications include insights into fundamental neurobiological processes like neurodegeneration and cellular waste management, potentially leveraging *C. elegans* as a model for studying neuroprotection in extreme environments.
original_title: Spaceflight affects neuronal morphology and alters transcellular degradation of neuronal debris in adult Caenorhabditis elegans

title: Microfluidics-integrated spaceflight hardware for measuring muscle strength of Caenorhabditis elegans on the International Space Station
abstract: Caenorhabditis elegans is a low-cost genetic model that has been flown to the International Space Station to investigate the influence of microgravity on changes in the expression of genes involved in muscle maintenance. These studies showed that genes that encode muscle attachment complexes have decreased expression under microgravity. However, it remains to be answered whether the decreased expression leads to concomitant changes in animal muscle strength, specifically across multiple generations. We recently reported the NemaFlex microfluidic device for the measurement of muscle strength of C. elegans (Rahman et al., Lab Chip, 2018). In this study, we redesign our original NemaFlex device and integrate it with flow control hardware for spaceflight investigations considering mixed animal culture, constraints on astronaut time, crew safety, and on-orbit operations. The technical advances we have made include (i) a microfluidic device design that allows animals of a given size to be sorted from unsynchronized cultures and housed in individual chambers, (ii) a fluid handling protocol for injecting the suspension of animals into the microfluidic device that prevents channel clogging, introduction of bubbles, and crowding of animals in the chambers, and (iii) a custom-built worm-loading apparatus interfaced with the microfluidic device that allows easy manipulation of the worm suspension and prevents fluid leakage into the surrounding environment. Collectively, these technical advances enabled the development of new microfluidics-integrated hardware for spaceflight studies in C. elegans. Finally, we report Earth-based validation studies to test this new hardware, which has led to it being flown to the International Space Station.
headings: C. elegans culture for multigenerational spaceflight studies
Design of the NemaFlex-S microfluidic device
Long-term storage of NemaFlex-S device in WLA
summary: This study developed and validated microfluidics-integrated hardware, named NemaFlex-S, for measuring *Caenorhabditis elegans* muscle strength on the International Space Station, addressing the question of whether microgravity-induced gene expression changes impact muscle strength across generations. Technical advances include a microfluidic device design for sorting and individually housing animals from unsynchronized cultures, an optimized fluid handling protocol preventing channel clogging and animal crowding, and a custom worm-loading apparatus for easy and leak-free manipulation. Earth-based validation of these technical advances confirmed the hardware's readiness, leading to its deployment to the ISS for future experiments.
impact: This publication significantly advances space biology methodology by providing a robust, flight-ready system to precisely measure *C. elegans* muscle strength in microgravity over multiple generations, bridging a critical gap between gene expression and functional changes in muscle. The hardware's design explicitly addresses ISS operational constraints like astronaut time and safety, directly supporting future space missions aimed at understanding and mitigating muscle atrophy in astronauts. Beyond space applications, insights gained from studying fundamental mechanisms of muscle maintenance in microgravity using this technology could inform terrestrial research into muscle wasting diseases, offering broader implications for human health.
theme: Technology Development for Muscle Health in Microgravity
original_title: Microfluidics-integrated spaceflight hardware for measuring muscle strength of Caenorhabditis elegans on the International Space Station.

title: A Compact Imaging Platform for Conducting C. elegans Phenotypic Assays on Earth and in Spaceflight
abstract: The model organism Caenorhabditis elegans is used in a variety of applications ranging from fundamental biological studies, to drug screening, to disease modeling, and to space-biology investigations. These applications rely on conducting whole-organism phenotypic assays involving animal behavior and locomotion. In this study, we report a 3D printed compact imaging platform (CIP) that is integrated with a smart-device camera for the whole-organism phenotyping of C. elegans. The CIP has no external optical elements and does not require mechanical focusing, simplifying the optical configuration. The small footprint of the system powered with a standard USB provides capabilities ranging from plug-and-play, to parallel operation, and to housing it in incubators for temperature control. We demonstrate on Earth the compatibility of the CIP with different C. elegans substrates, including agar plates, liquid droplets on glass slides and microfluidic chips. We validate the system with behavioral and thrashing assays and show that the phenotypic readouts are in good agreement with the literature data. We conduct a pilot study with mutants and show that the phenotypic data collected from the CIP distinguishes these mutants. Finally, we discuss how the simplicity and versatility offered by CIP makes it amenable to future C. elegans investigations on the International Space Station, where science experiments are constrained by system size, payload weight and crew time. Overall, the compactness, portability and ease-of-use makes the CIP desirable for research and educational outreach applications on Earth and in space.
headings: 2.1. Description of the Compact Imaging Platform and Its Components
2.2. Compatibility of the CIP with Different C. elegans Substrates
2.3. Controlling CIP Temperature during C. elegans Assays
2.4. Validation of the CIP with Behavioral Assays on Different C. elegans Substrates
2.6. Relevance of CIP for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
summary: This study reports the development of a 3D-printed compact imaging platform (CIP) for C. elegans phenotyping, designed for use on Earth and in spaceflight. The CIP, which integrates a smart-device camera without external optics or mechanical focusing, was validated with behavioral and thrashing assays on various substrates, showing good agreement with literature data and successfully distinguishing mutants. Its compactness, portability, and ease-of-use make it highly amenable for C. elegans investigations on the International Space Station and for terrestrial research and education.
impact: This publication significantly advances the methodology for C. elegans phenotyping by introducing a compact, user-friendly, and versatile imaging platform suitable for both Earth and spaceflight applications. Its design directly addresses critical constraints for space missions, such as system size, payload weight, and crew time, thereby enabling more efficient and accessible biological investigations on the International Space Station. Beyond space biology, the CIP's simplicity and portability have broad implications for fundamental biological studies, drug screening, disease modeling, and educational outreach on Earth, potentially democratizing C. elegans research.
theme: Technology Development for C. elegans Spaceflight Studies
original_title: A Compact Imaging Platform for Conducting C. elegans Phenotypic Assays on Earth and in Spaceflight.

title: Mitochondrial sulfide promotes life span and health span through distinct mechanisms in developing versus adult treated Caenorhabditis elegans
abstract: Living longer without simultaneously extending years spent in good health (“health span”) is an increasing societal burden, demanding new therapeutic strategies. Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) can correct disease-related mitochondrial metabolic deficiencies, and supraphysiological H2S concentrations can pro health span. However, the efficacy and mechanisms of mitochondrion-targeted sulfide delivery molecules (mtH2S) administered across the adult life course are unknown. Using a Caenorhabditis elegans aging model, we compared untargeted H2S (NaGYY4137, 100 µM and 100 nM) and mtH2S (AP39, 100 nM) donor effects on life span, neuromuscular health span, and mitochondrial integrity. H2S donors were administered from birth or in young/middle-aged animals (day 0, 2, or 4 postadulthood). RNAi pharmacogenetic interventions and transcriptomics/network analysis explored molecular events governing mtH2S donor-mediated health span. Developmentally administered mtH2S (100 nM) improved life/health span vs. equivalent untargeted H2S doses. mtH2S preserved aging mitochondrial structure, content (citrate synthase activity) and neuromuscular strength. Knockdown of H2S metabolism enzymes and FoxO/daf-16 prevented the positive health span effects of mtH2S, whereas DCAF11/wdr-23 – Nrf2/skn-1 oxidative stress protection pathways were dispensable. Health span, but not life span, increased with all adult-onset mtH2S treatments. Adult mtH2S treatment also rejuvenated aging transcriptomes by minimizing expression declines of mitochondria and cytoskeletal components, and peroxisome metabolism hub components, under mechanistic control by the elt-6/elt-3 transcription factor circuit. H2S health span extension likely acts at the mitochondrial level, the mechanisms of which dissociate from life span across adult vs. developmental treatment timings. The small mtH2S doses required for health span extension, combined with efficacy in adult animals, suggest mtH2S is a potential healthy aging therapeutic.
summary: This study investigated the efficacy and mechanisms of mitochondrion-targeted sulfide delivery molecules (mtH2S, AP39, 100 nM) versus untargeted H2S (NaGYY4137, 100 µM and 100 nM) on life span, neuromuscular health span, and mitochondrial integrity in *Caenorhabditis elegans*.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of H2S's role in aging, differentiating its effects based on developmental versus adult administration and identifying specific genetic pathways involved. While not directly space-related, the findings on healthy aging therapeutics could have broad implications for maintaining astronaut health and mitigating age-related declines during long-duration space missions, functioning as a potential countermeasure for physiological stresses. The study, published in the prestigious PNAS, provides a foundation for future research into mtH2S as a therapeutic strategy to extend health span in an aging population, both terrestrially and potentially for space exploration.
theme: Genetics & Genomics: Longevity and Health Span
journal: Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A.
original_title: Mitochondrial sulfide promotes life span and health span through distinct mechanisms in developing versus adult treated Caenorhabditis elegans.

title: Bisphosphonates attenuate age‐related muscle decline in Caenorhabditis elegans
abstract:
Background

Age‐related muscle decline (sarcopenia) associates with numerous health risk factors and poor quality of life. Drugs that counter sarcopenia without harmful side effects are lacking, and repurposing existing pharmaceuticals could expedite realistic clinical options. Recent studies suggest bisphosphonates promote muscle health; however, the efficacy of bisphosphonates as an anti‐sarcopenic therapy is currently unclear.

Methods

Using Caenorhabditis elegans as a sarcopenia model, we treated animals with 100 nM, 1, 10, 100 and 500 μM zoledronic acid (ZA) and assessed lifespan and healthspan (movement rates) using a microfluidic chip device. The effects of ZA on sarcopenia were examined using GFP‐tagged myofibres or mitochondria at days 0, 4 and 6 post‐adulthood. Mechanisms of ZA‐mediated healthspan extension were determined using combined ZA and targeted RNAi gene knockdown across the life‐course.

Results

We found 100 nM and 1 μM ZA increased lifespan (P < 0.001) and healthspan [954 ± 53 (100 nM) and 963 ± 48 (1 μM) vs. 834 ± 59% (untreated) population activity AUC, P < 0.05]. 10 μM ZA shortened lifespan (P < 0.0001) but not healthspan (758.9 ± 37 vs. 834 ± 59, P > 0.05), whereas 100 and 500 μM ZA were larval lethal. ZA (1 μM) significantly improved myofibrillar structure on days 4 and 6 post‐adulthood (83 and 71% well‐organized myofibres, respectively, vs. 56 and 34% controls, P < 0.0001) and increased well‐networked mitochondria at day 6 (47 vs. 16% in controls, P < 0.01). Genes required for ZA‐mediated healthspan extension included fdps‐1/FDPS‐1 (278 ± 9 vs. 894 ± 17% population activity AUC in knockdown + 1 μM ZA vs. untreated controls, respectively, P < 0.0001), daf‐16/FOXO (680 ± 16 vs. 894 ± 17%, P < 0.01) and agxt‐2/BAIBA (531 ± 23 vs. 552 ± 8%, P > 0.05). Life/healthspan was extended through knockdown of igdb‐1/FNDC5 (635 ± 10 vs. 523 ± 10% population activity AUC in gene knockdown vs. untreated controls, P < 0.01) and sir‐2.3/SIRT‐4 (586 ± 10 vs. 523 ± 10%, P < 0.05), with no synergistic improvements in ZA co‐treatment vs. knockdown alone [651 ± 12 vs. 635 ± 10% (igdb‐1/FNDC5) and 583 ± 9 vs. 586 ± 10% (sir‐2.3/SIRT‐4), both P > 0.05]. Conversely, let‐756/FGF21 and sir‐2.2/SIRT‐4 were dispensable for ZA‐induced healthspan [630 ± 6 vs. 523 ± 10% population activity AUC in knockdown + 1 μM ZA vs. untreated controls, P < 0.01 (let‐756/FGF21) and 568 ± 9 vs. 523 ± 10%, P < 0.05 (sir‐2.2/SIRT‐4)].

Conclusions

Despite lacking an endoskeleton, ZA delays Caenorhabditis elegans sarcopenia, which translates to improved neuromuscular function across the life course. Bisphosphonates might, therefore, be an immediately exploitable anti‐sarcopenia therapy.
summary: This study investigated the efficacy of bisphosphonates, specifically zoledronic acid (ZA), in attenuating age-related muscle decline (sarcopenia) using Caenorhabditis elegans. Researchers found that low doses of ZA (100 nM and 1 µM) significantly extended both lifespan (P < 0.001) and healthspan, with the 1 µM dose increasing population activity AUC to 963 ± 48% compared to 834 ± 59% in untreated controls (P < 0.05). Furthermore, 1 µM ZA markedly improved myofibrillar structure (83% vs. 56% well-organized myofibres on day 4, P < 0.0001) and mitochondrial networking (47% vs. 16% at day 6, P < 0.01), suggesting bisphosphonates could be an effective anti-sarcopenia therapy.
impact: This research significantly advances the scientific understanding of sarcopenia and potential therapeutic interventions, demonstrating how bisphosphonates can improve muscle health and function through specific molecular pathways. For space missions, where astronauts experience significant muscle atrophy due to microgravity, these findings are highly relevant, indicating that bisphosphonates could be repurposed as an immediate and exploitable countermeasure to preserve astronaut muscle health. More broadly, this work offers promising avenues for developing treatments for age-related sarcopenia in the terrestrial population, addressing a major public health challenge.
original_title: Bisphosphonates attenuate age-related muscle decline in Caenorhabditis elegans.

title: Spaceflight Induces Strength Decline in Caenorhabditis elegans
abstract: Background: Understanding and countering the well-established negative health consequences of spaceflight remains a primary challenge preventing safe deep space exploration. Targeted/personalized therapeutics are at the forefront of space medicine strategies, and cross-species molecular signatures now define the ‘typical’ spaceflight response. However, a lack of direct genotype–phenotype associations currently limits the robustness and, therefore, the therapeutic utility of putative mechanisms underpinning pathological changes in flight. Methods: We employed the worm Caenorhabditis elegans as a validated model of space biology, combined with ‘NemaFlex-S’ microfluidic devices for assessing animal strength production as one of the most reproducible physiological responses to spaceflight. Wild-type and dys-1 (BZ33) strains (a Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) model for comparing predisposed muscle weak animals) were cultured on the International Space Station in chemically defined media before loading second-generation gravid adults into NemaFlex-S devices to assess individual animal strength. These same cultures were then frozen on orbit before returning to Earth for next-generation sequencing transcriptomic analysis. Results: Neuromuscular strength was lower in flight versus ground controls (16.6% decline, p < 0.05), with dys-1 significantly more (23% less strength, p < 0.01) affected than wild types. The transcriptional gene ontology signatures characterizing both strains of weaker animals in flight strongly corroborate previous results across species, enriched for upregulated stress response pathways and downregulated mitochondrial and cytoskeletal processes. Functional gene cluster analysis extended this to implicate decreased neuronal function, including abnormal calcium handling and acetylcholine signaling, in space-induced strength declines under the predicted control of UNC-89 and DAF-19 transcription factors. Finally, gene modules specifically altered in dys-1 animals in flight again cluster to neuronal/neuromuscular pathways, suggesting strength loss in DMD comprises a strong neuronal component that predisposes these animals to exacerbated strength loss in space. Conclusions: Highly reproducible gene signatures are strongly associated with space-induced neuromuscular strength loss across species and neuronal changes in calcium/acetylcholine signaling require further study. These results promote targeted medical efforts towards and provide an in vivo model for safely sending animals and people into deep space in the near future.
summary: This study investigated spaceflight-induced neuromuscular strength decline in *Caenorhabditis elegans* using a microfluidic device on the International Space Station. Findings revealed a 16.6% strength decline in flight versus ground controls, with a Duchenne muscular dystrophy model (*dys-1*) exhibiting an exacerbated 23% strength loss. Transcriptomic analysis strongly corroborated previous findings of upregulated stress response and downregulated mitochondrial/cytoskeletal processes, further implicating decreased neuronal function, including abnormal calcium handling and acetylcholine signaling, under the control of UNC-89 and DAF-19 transcription factors.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of spaceflight's negative health consequences by providing direct genotype-phenotype associations for neuromuscular decline. The identification of specific neuronal pathways and transcription factors offers promising targets for developing personalized therapeutics and countermeasures for astronaut health during deep space exploration. Moreover, the *C. elegans* model with NemaFlex-S devices provides a robust *in vivo* platform for future astropharmacy and space medicine research, with potential broader implications for terrestrial muscle-wasting and neurodegenerative conditions.
theme: Microgravity Effects on Muscle Health and Genetics
original_title: Spaceflight Induces Strength Decline in Caenorhabditis elegans

title: Metabolic model predictions enable targeted microbiome manipulation through precision prebiotics
abstract: While numerous health-beneficial interactions between host and microbiota have been identified, there is still a lack of targeted approaches for modulating these interactions. Thus, we here identify precision prebiotics that specifically modulate the abundance of a microbiome member species of interest. In the first step, we show that defining precision prebiotics by compounds that are only taken up by the target species but no other species in a community is usually not possible due to overlapping metabolic niches. Subsequently, we use metabolic modeling to identify precision prebiotics for a two-member Caenorhabditis elegans microbiome community comprising the immune-protective target species Pseudomonas lurida MYb11 and the persistent colonizer Ochrobactrum vermis MYb71. We experimentally confirm four of the predicted precision prebiotics, L-serine, L-threonine, D-mannitol, and γ-aminobutyric acid, to specifically increase the abundance of MYb11. L-serine was further assessed in vivo, leading to an increase in MYb11 abundance also in the worm host. Overall, our findings demonstrate that metabolic modeling is an effective tool for the design of precision prebiotics as an important cornerstone for future microbiome-targeted therapies.
summary: This study aimed to identify precision prebiotics capable of specifically modulating the abundance of a target microbiome species. Using metabolic modeling, the researchers identified and experimentally confirmed four precision prebiotics (L-serine, L-threonine, D-mannitol, and γ-aminobutyric acid) that specifically increased the abundance of the immune-protective *Pseudomonas lurida MYb11* in a two-member *C. elegans* microbiome. The findings demonstrate that metabolic modeling is an effective tool for designing precision prebiotics, establishing a cornerstone for future microbiome-targeted therapies.
impact: This research significantly advances the field of microbiome modulation by presenting metabolic modeling as a powerful tool for designing targeted precision prebiotics, addressing a critical gap in current approaches. Its potential application extends to developing novel microbiome-targeted therapies for various host conditions, including supporting astronaut health by precisely adjusting beneficial microbial populations in challenging environments. This work lays crucial groundwork for personalized dietary interventions and microbiome engineering, with profound implications for both space and terrestrial medicine.
original_title: Metabolic model predictions enable targeted microbiome manipulation through precision prebiotics.

title: Transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations underpinning spaceflight dermatology
abstract:
Background
Spaceflight poses a unique set of challenges to humans and the hostile spaceflight environment can induce a wide range of increased health risks, including dermatological issues. The biology driving the frequency of skin issues in astronauts is currently not well understood.
Methods
To address this issue, we used a systems biology approach utilizing NASA’s Open Science Data Repository (OSDR) on space flown murine transcriptomic datasets focused on the skin, biochemical profiles of 50 NASA astronauts and human transcriptomic datasets generated from blood and hair samples of JAXA astronauts, as well as blood samples obtained from the NASA Twins Study, and skin and blood samples from the first civilian commercial mission, Inspiration4.
Results
Key biological changes related to skin health, DNA damage & repair, and mitochondrial dysregulation are identified as potential drivers for skin health risks during spaceflight. Additionally, a machine learning model is utilized to determine gene pairings associated with spaceflight response in the skin. While we identified spaceflight-induced dysregulation, such as alterations in genes associated with skin barrier function and collagen formation, our results also highlight the remarkable ability for organisms to re-adapt back to Earth via post-flight re-tuning of gene expression.
Conclusion
Our findings can guide future research on developing countermeasures for mitigating spaceflight-associated skin damage.
summary: This study addressed the poorly understood biology of spaceflight-induced dermatological issues by employing a systems biology approach, analyzing diverse transcriptomic datasets from murine, human, and commercial space missions. It identified key biological alterations in skin health, DNA damage & repair, and mitochondrial dysregulation as potential drivers for skin risks during spaceflight. The research also highlighted the remarkable ability of organisms to re-adapt to Earth conditions through post-flight re-tuning of gene expression.
impact: This publication significantly advances the understanding of spaceflight dermatology by identifying specific molecular alterations and potential drivers of skin health risks using a comprehensive systems biology approach. The findings provide a robust foundation for developing targeted countermeasures to mitigate spaceflight-associated skin damage, directly enhancing astronaut health and safety for future missions. This research will guide future investigations into stress-induced dermatological conditions, potentially yielding broader insights applicable to terrestrial skin health.
original_title: Transcriptomics analysis reveals molecular alterations underpinning spaceflight dermatology.

title: Identification and characterization of a skin microbiome on Caenorhabditis elegans suggests environmental microbes confer cuticle protection
abstract: In the wild, C. elegans are emersed in environments teeming with a veritable menagerie of microorganisms. The C. elegans cuticular surface serves as a barrier and first point of contact with their microbial environments. In this study, we identify microbes from C. elegans natural habitats that associate with its cuticle, constituting a simple “skin microbiome.” We rear our animals on a modified CeMbio, mCeMbio, a consortium of ecologically relevant microbes. We first combine standard microbiological methods with an adapted micro skin-swabbing tool to describe the skin-resident bacteria on the C. elegans surface. Furthermore, we conduct 16S rRNA gene sequencing studies to identify relative shifts in the proportion of mCeMbio bacteria upon surface-sterilization, implying distinct skin- and gut-microbiomes. We find that some strains of bacteria, including Enterobacter sp. JUb101, are primarily found on the nematode skin, while others like Stenotrophomonas indicatrix JUb19 and Ochrobactrum vermis MYb71 are predominantly found in the animal’s gut. Finally, we show that this skin microbiome promotes host cuticle integrity in harsh environments. Together, we identify a skin microbiome for the well-studied nematode model and propose its value in conferring host fitness advantages in naturalized contexts.
summary: This study aimed to identify and characterize a skin microbiome on *Caenorhabditis elegans* from its natural habitats, investigating its composition and functional significance. Utilizing micro skin-swabbing and 16S rRNA gene sequencing, researchers identified distinct skin- and gut-associated microbial communities, with specific strains like *Enterobacter sp. JUb101* primarily found on the skin. A key finding was that this newly identified skin microbiome promotes host cuticle integrity in harsh environments, suggesting its crucial role in conferring host fitness advantages in natural settings.
impact: This research significantly advances fundamental understanding of host-microbe interactions by identifying a novel skin microbiome on *C. elegans* and demonstrating its role in cuticle protection, establishing a new model for such studies. While not directly focused on space, understanding how external microbial communities confer protection against harsh environments is highly relevant for maintaining organismal health, including astronauts, in extreme conditions like space, suggesting potential for developing future countermeasures. This study also has broader terrestrial implications for human health, agriculture, and understanding resilience in diverse ecological contexts by illuminating a previously unappreciated aspect of nematode biology.
original_title: Identification and characterization of a skin microbiome on Caenorhabditis elegans suggests environmental microbes confer cuticle protection

title: Protein kinase 2 of the giant sarcomeric protein UNC-89 regulates mitochondrial morphology and function
abstract: UNC-89 is a giant sarcomeric M-line protein required for sarcomere organization and optimal muscle function. UNC-89 contains two protein kinase domains, PK1 and PK2, separated by an elastic region. Here we show that PK2 is a canonical kinase expected to be catalytically active. C. elegans expressing UNC-89 with a lysine to alanine (KtoA) mutation to inactivate PK2 have normally organized sarcomeres and SR, and normal muscle function. PK2 KtoA mutants have fragmented mitochondria, correlated with more mitochondrially-associated DRP-1. PK2 KtoA mutants have increased ATP levels, increased glycolysis and altered levels of electron transport chain complexes. Muscle mitochondria show increased complex I and decreased complex II basal respiration, each of which cannot be uncoupled. This suggests that mutant mitochondria are already uncoupled, possibly resulting from an increased level of the uncoupling protein, UCP-4. Our results suggest signaling from sarcomeres to mitochondria, to help match energy requirements with energy production.
summary: This study investigated the role of the PK2 kinase domain of the giant sarcomeric protein UNC-89, finding that while PK2 is a canonical and active kinase, its inactivation (KtoA mutation) does not affect sarcomere organization or muscle function. However, PK2 KtoA mutants exhibit fragmented mitochondria, increased DRP-1, elevated ATP levels, increased glycolysis, and altered levels of electron transport chain complexes, with muscle mitochondria showing increased complex I and decreased complex II basal respiration, both uncoupled. These findings highlight a novel signaling pathway from sarcomeres to mitochondria, crucial for matching cellular energy requirements with production.
impact: This research advances our understanding of muscle energy metabolism and sarcomere-mitochondrial crosstalk, revealing a novel role for the PK2 kinase domain of UNC-89 in regulating mitochondrial function independent of sarcomere structure. As a NASA Space Biology publication, this fundamental research on muscle energetics and mitochondrial health is highly relevant to understanding and mitigating muscle dysfunction, such as atrophy and metabolic shifts, experienced by astronauts during long-duration space missions, potentially informing future countermeasures. Additionally, these findings contribute to a better understanding of terrestrial diseases involving muscle and mitochondrial dysfunction, including muscular dystrophies and metabolic disorders.
original_title: Protein kinase 2 of the giant sarcomeric protein UNC-89 regulates mitochondrial morphology and function

title: New perspectives on viable microbial communities in low-biomass cleanroom environments
abstract: The advent of phylogenetic DNA microarrays and high-throughput pyrosequencing technologies has dramatically increased the resolution and accuracy of detection of distinct microbial lineages in mixed microbial assemblages. Despite an expanding array of approaches for detecting microbes in a given sample, rapid and robust means of assessing the differential viability of these cells, as a function of phylogenetic lineage, remain elusive. In this study, pre-PCR propidium monoazide (PMA) treatment was coupled with downstream pyrosequencing and PhyloChip DNA microarray analyses to better understand the frequency, diversity and distribution of viable bacteria in spacecraft assembly cleanrooms. Sample fractions not treated with PMA, which were indicative of the presence of both live and dead cells, yielded a great abundance of highly diverse bacterial pyrosequences. In contrast, only 1% to 10% of all of the pyrosequencing reads, arising from a few robust bacterial lineages, originated from sample fractions that had been pre-treated with PMA. The results of PhyloChip analyses of PMA-treated and -untreated sample fractions were in agreement with those of pyrosequencing. The viable bacterial population detected in cleanrooms devoid of spacecraft hardware was far more diverse than that observed in cleanrooms that housed mission-critical spacecraft hardware. The latter was dominated by hardy, robust organisms previously reported to survive in oligotrophic cleanroom environments. Presented here are the findings of the first ever comprehensive effort to assess the viability of cells in low-biomass environmental samples, and correlate differential viability with phylogenetic affiliation.
summary: This study aimed to assess the frequency, diversity, and distribution of viable bacteria in spacecraft assembly cleanrooms by coupling pre-PCR propidium monoazide (PMA) treatment with pyrosequencing and PhyloChip DNA microarray analyses. While untreated samples showed high bacterial diversity and abundance, only 1% to 10% of reads from PMA-treated (viable) samples belonged to a few robust bacterial lineages. The research revealed that cleanrooms without spacecraft hardware harbored a more diverse viable population compared to those with mission-critical hardware, which were dominated by hardy organisms.
impact: This publication significantly advances the understanding of viable microbial communities in low-biomass controlled environments by introducing a robust methodology for assessing phylogenetic lineage-specific viability, a previously elusive capability. The findings are crucial for NASA's planetary protection efforts, informing strategies to prevent microbial contamination of spacecraft and ensuring the integrity of future space missions and astronaut health. This approach also has broader implications for microbial control and sterility maintenance in sensitive terrestrial industries.
original_title: New perspectives on viable microbial communities in low-biomass cleanroom environments

title: Wild mouse gut microbiota limits initial tuberculosis infection in BALB/c mice
abstract: Mouse models are critical tools in tuberculosis (TB) research. Recent studies have demonstrated that the wild mouse gut microbiota promotes host fitness and improves disease resistance. Here we examine whether the wild mouse gut microbiota alters the immunopathology of TB in BALB/c mice. Conventional BALB/c mice (LabC) and mice born to germ-free BALB/c mothers reconstituted with the wild mouse gut microbiota (WildR) were used in our studies. WildR mice controlled initial TB infection better than LabC mice. The microbial gut communities of LabC mice and WildR mice had similar richness but significantly different composition prior to infection. TB reduced the gut community richness in both cohorts while differences in community composition remained indicating a general TB-induced dysbiosis. The wild mouse gut microbiota did not alter the typical lung histopathology of TB in the BALB/c model that includes unstructured immune cell infiltrates with infected foamy macrophages invading alveolar spaces. Animals of both cohorts mounted robust T cell responses in lungs and spleen with lower absolute counts of CD4 and CD8 T cells in lungs of WildR mice during acute infection, corresponding with observed differences in pathogen load. In summary, LabC mice and WildR mice showed largely overlapping TB immunopathology and pathogen kinetics, with WildR mice controlling early acute infection better than LabC mice.
summary: This study investigated whether the wild mouse gut microbiota alters tuberculosis (TB) immunopathology in BALB/c mice. Researchers found that mice reconstituted with wild mouse gut microbiota (WildR) controlled initial TB infection better than conventional laboratory mice (LabC), despite similar richness but different composition of their gut communities prior to infection. While TB reduced gut community richness in both groups and did not alter typical lung histopathology, WildR mice exhibited lower absolute counts of CD4 and CD8 T cells in the lungs during acute infection, correlating with better pathogen control.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of the gut microbiota's role in modulating host immunity and resistance to infectious diseases like tuberculosis. For space biology, this work is crucial as astronauts experience immune dysregulation and gut dysbiosis, which could increase their susceptibility to infections; insights into beneficial microbiomes could inform the development of countermeasures to maintain astronaut health during long-duration missions. Broadly, these findings pave the way for future research into microbiome-based strategies to enhance disease resistance in both space and terrestrial environments, potentially offering new therapeutic avenues for combating infectious diseases.
original_title: Microbial existence in controlled habitats and their resistance to space conditions

title: Microbiomes of the dust particles collected from the International Space Station and Spacecraft Assembly Facilities
abstract:
Background
The International Space Station (ISS) is a unique built environment due to the effects of microgravity, space radiation, elevated carbon dioxide levels, and especially continuous human habitation. Understanding the composition of the ISS microbial community will facilitate further development of safety and maintenance practices. The primary goal of this study was to characterize the viable microbiome of the ISS-built environment. A second objective was to determine if the built environments of Earth-based cleanrooms associated with space exploration are an appropriate model of the ISS environment.
Results
Samples collected from the ISS and two cleanrooms at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL, Pasadena, CA) were analyzed by traditional cultivation, adenosine triphosphate (ATP), and propidium monoazide–quantitative polymerase chain reaction (PMA-qPCR) assays to estimate viable microbial populations. The 16S rRNA gene Illumina iTag sequencing was used to elucidate microbial diversity and explore differences between ISS and cleanroom microbiomes. Statistical analyses showed that members of the phyla Actinobacteria, Firmicutes, and Proteobacteria were dominant in the samples examined but varied in abundance. Actinobacteria were predominant in the ISS samples whereas Proteobacteria, least abundant in the ISS, dominated in the cleanroom samples. The viable bacterial populations seen by PMA treatment were greatly decreased. However, the treatment did not appear to have an effect on the bacterial composition (diversity) associated with each sampling site.
Conclusions
The results of this study provide strong evidence that specific human skin-associated microorganisms make a substantial contribution to the ISS microbiome, which is not the case in Earth-based cleanrooms. For example, Corynebacterium and Propionibacterium (Actinobacteria) but not Staphylococcus (Firmicutes) species are dominant on the ISS in terms of viable and total bacterial community composition. The results obtained will facilitate future studies to determine how stable the ISS environment is over time. The present results also demonstrate the value of measuring viable cell diversity and population size at any sampling site. This information can be used to identify sites that can be targeted for more stringent cleaning. Finally, the results will allow comparisons with other built sites and facilitate future improvements on the ISS that will ensure astronaut health.
summary: This study aimed to characterize the viable microbiome of the International Space Station (ISS) and compare it to Earth-based cleanrooms to develop safety and maintenance practices. Utilizing traditional cultivation, ATP, PMA-qPCR, and 16S rRNA gene Illumina iTag sequencing, researchers found Actinobacteria, particularly Corynebacterium and Propionibacterium species, were predominant in viable ISS samples, while Proteobacteria dominated cleanroom environments. This finding provides strong evidence that specific human skin-associated microorganisms make a substantial contribution to the ISS microbiome, which is distinct from Earth-based cleanrooms, critical for understanding astronaut health.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of microbial ecology within unique built space environments, highlighting the distinct influence of human-associated microorganisms on the ISS microbiome. The methodology, incorporating PMA treatment for viable cell diversity and population size, offers a valuable tool for environmental monitoring and identifying areas for stringent cleaning. These findings are crucial for developing effective countermeasures, ensuring astronaut health, and improving long-term habitability and safety protocols for future space missions.
original_title: Microbiomes of the dust particles collected from the International Space Station and Spacecraft assembly facilities

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Two Aspergillus fumigatus Strains, Isolated from the International Space Station
abstract: Draft genome sequences of Aspergillus fumigatus strains (ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4), opportunistic pathogens isolated from the International Space Station (ISS), were assembled to facilitate investigations of the nature of the virulence characteristics of the ISS strains to other clinical strains isolated on Earth.
summary: Draft genome sequences were assembled for two strains of *Aspergillus fumigatus* (ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4), an opportunistic pathogen isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). This foundational work was conducted to facilitate future investigations into the specific virulence characteristics of these ISS-derived strains, comparing them to clinical strains isolated on Earth.
impact: This genome announcement provides valuable genetic data for ISS-isolated opportunistic pathogens, which is scientifically significant for understanding microbial adaptation and potential pathogenicity in extraterrestrial environments. The data will enable crucial research into the virulence of these fungi, directly contributing to astronaut health and the development of countermeasures for long-duration space missions. Furthermore, it advances the broader field of environmental microbiology and fungal pathogen research.
theme: Genetics & Genomics of Space Station Pathogens
original_title: Draft genome sequences of two Aspergillus fumigatus strains, isolated from the International Space Station

title: Proteomic characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolated from air and surfaces of the International Space Station
abstract: The on-going Microbial Observatory Experiments on the International Space Station (ISS) revealed the presence of various microorganisms that may be affected by the distinct environment of the ISS. The low-nutrient environment combined with enhanced irradiation and microgravity may trigger changes in the molecular suite of microorganisms leading to increased virulence and resistance of microbes. Proteomic characterization of two Aspergillus fumigatus strains, ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4, isolated from HEPA filter debris and cupola surface of the ISS, respectively, is presented, along with a comparison to experimentally established clinical isolates Af293 and CEA10. In-depth analysis highlights variations in the proteome of both ISS-isolated strains when compared to the clinical strains. Proteins that showed increased abundance in ISS isolates were overall involved in stress responses, and carbohydrate and secondary metabolism. Among the most abundant proteins were Pst2 and ArtA involved in oxidative stress response, PdcA and AcuE responsible for ethanol fermentation and glyoxylate cycle, respectively, TpcA, TpcF, and TpcK that are part of trypacidin biosynthetic pathway, and a toxin Asp-hemolysin. This report provides insight into possible molecular adaptation of filamentous fungi to the unique ISS environment.
summary: This study conducted proteomic characterization of two Aspergillus fumigatus strains, ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4, isolated from the International Space Station, comparing them to experimentally established clinical isolates Af293 and CEA10 to understand molecular adaptation. In-depth analysis revealed variations in the proteome of ISS isolates, with increased abundance of proteins involved in stress responses, carbohydrate, and secondary metabolism, including Pst2, ArtA, PdcA, AcuE, TpcA, TpcF, TpcK, and Asp-hemolysin. This provides insight into the possible molecular adaptation of filamentous fungi to the unique ISS environment, where factors like low nutrients, enhanced irradiation, and microgravity may trigger changes in microbial molecular suites.
impact: This research significantly advances the understanding of how microorganisms adapt at a molecular level to the unique conditions of the International Space Station, employing robust proteomic methods. The findings are crucial for ensuring astronaut health and mission success by identifying potential changes in microbial virulence and resistance in space, which could inform the development of countermeasures and health monitoring strategies. Beyond space applications, this work contributes to broader fungal biology, pathogenesis, and stress response research, potentially informing terrestrial applications.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Biosafety Level 2 Opportunistic Pathogens Isolated from the Environmental Surfaces of the International Space Station
abstract: The draft genome sequences of 20 biosafety level 2 (BSL-2) opportunistic pathogens isolated from the environmental surfaces of the International Space Station (ISS) were presented. These genomic sequences will help in understanding the influence of microgravity on the pathogenicity and virulence of these strains when compared with Earth strains.
summary: This publication presents the draft genome sequences for 20 biosafety level 2 (BSL-2) opportunistic pathogens that were isolated from the environmental surfaces of the International Space Station (ISS). The primary objective is to utilize these genomic sequences to understand how microgravity influences the pathogenicity and virulence of these space-isolated strains when compared to their Earth counterparts. This foundational genomic data is critical for future comparative studies.
impact: Scientifically, this work provides crucial genomic data for space-adapted pathogens, advancing the field of space microbiology and enabling future research into microbial adaptation and virulence in microgravity. Practically, these sequences are invaluable for informing astronaut health monitoring protocols, developing countermeasures, and mitigating infection risks during long-duration space missions. Broader implications include contributing to our understanding of microbial stress responses in extreme environments and opportunistic infections both in space and potentially on Earth.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Several Fungal Strains Selected for Exposure to Microgravity at the International Space Station
abstract: The whole-genome sequences of eight fungal strains that were selected for exposure to microgravity at the International Space Station are presented here. These baseline sequences will help to understand the observed production of novel bioactive compounds.
summary: This publication presents the whole-genome sequences of eight fungal strains specifically chosen for exposure to microgravity on the International Space Station. These baseline genomic data are crucial for understanding the observed production of novel bioactive compounds by these fungi in the space environment. The primary objective is to establish a genomic foundation to elucidate the molecular mechanisms behind these unique metabolic alterations.
impact: Scientifically, this work provides fundamental genomic resources, advancing our understanding of microbial adaptation and metabolic changes in microgravity. Practically, this baseline genomic information could aid in identifying novel bioactive compounds with potential pharmaceutical applications, and contribute to future space mission planning by understanding microbial behavior and potential bioproduction in space. It also sets the stage for future research into microbial drug discovery and astrobiology.

title: Human presence impacts fungal diversity of inflated lunar/Mars analog habitat
abstract:
Background An inflatable lunar/Mars analog habitat (ILMAH), simulated closed system isolated by HEPA filtration, mimics International Space Station (ISS) conditions and future human habitation on other planets except for the exchange of air between outdoor and indoor environments. The ILMAH was primarily commissioned to measure physiological, psychological, and immunological characteristics of human inhabiting in isolation, but it was also available for other studies such as examining its microbiological aspects. Characterizing and understanding possible changes and succession of fungal species is of high importance since fungi are not only hazardous to inhabitants but also deteriorate the habitats. Observing the mycobiome changes in the presence of human will enable developing appropriate countermeasures with reference to crew health in a future closed habitat.
Results Succession of fungi was characterized utilizing both traditional and state-of-the-art molecular techniques during the 30-day human occupation of the ILMAH. Surface samples were collected at various time points and locations to observe both the total and viable fungal populations of common environmental and opportunistic pathogenic species. To estimate the cultivable fungal population, potato dextrose agar plate counts method was utilized. The internal transcribed spacer region-based iTag Illumina sequencing was employed to measure the community structure and fluctuation of the mycobiome over time in various locations. Treatment of samples with propidium monoazide (PMA; a DNA intercalating dye for selective detection of viable microbial populations) had a significant effect on the microbial diversity compared to non-PMA-treated samples. Statistical analysis confirmed that viable fungal community structure changed (increase in diversity and decrease in fungal burden) over the occupation time. Samples collected at day 20 showed distinct fungal profiles from samples collected at any other time point (before or after). Viable fungal families like Davidiellaceae, Teratosphaeriaceae, Pleosporales, and Pleosporaceae were shown to increase during the occupation time.
Conclusions The results of this study revealed that the overall fungal diversity in the closed habitat changed during human presence; therefore, it is crucial to properly maintain a closed habitat to preserve it from deteriorating and keep it safe for its inhabitants. Differences in community profiles were observed when statistically treated, especially of the mycobiome of samples collected at day 20. On a genus level Epiccocum, Alternaria, Pleosporales, Davidiella, and Cryptococcus showed increased abundance over the occupation time.
summary: This study investigated fungal diversity changes in an inflatable lunar/Mars analog habitat (ILMAH) during a 30-day human occupation, simulating closed-system conditions for future space missions. Findings revealed that human presence significantly altered viable fungal community structure, leading to an increase in diversity and a decrease in fungal burden over time, with distinct profiles observed at day 20. Specific fungal families and genera, including Davidiellaceae, Epiccocum, and Alternaria, showed increased abundance, underscoring the necessity of diligent habitat maintenance to ensure crew safety and preserve structural integrity.
impact: This research significantly advances the scientific understanding of microbial ecology in closed space environments, demonstrating that human presence directly influences fungal community dynamics. The use of propidium monoazide (PMA) for distinguishing viable populations also represents a methodological contribution. Practically, these findings are crucial for developing effective countermeasures to mitigate health risks to astronauts and prevent habitat deterioration in future lunar/Mars missions, with broader implications for maintaining microbial control in other terrestrial closed systems.
original_title: Human presence impacts fungal diversity of inflated lunar/Mars analog habitat.

title: Erratum to: Whole metagenome profiles of particulates collected from the International Space Station
abstract: Following publication of the original article [1], the authors reported that the X-axis label was missing from Fig. 4. The new Fig. 4 is attached.

title: Longitudinal characterization of multispecies microbial populations recovered from spaceflight potable water
abstract: While sequencing technologies have revolutionized our knowledge of microbial diversity, little is known about the dynamic emergent phenotypes that arise within the context of mixed-species populations, which are not fully predicted using sequencing technologies alone. The International Space Station (ISS) is an isolated, closed human habitat that can be harnessed for cross-sectional and longitudinal functional microbiome studies. Using NASA-archived microbial isolates collected from the ISS potable water system over several years, we profiled five phenotypes: antibiotic resistance, metabolism, hemolysis, and biofilm structure/composition of individual or multispecies communities, which represent characteristics that could negatively impact astronaut health and life-support systems. Data revealed a temporal dependence on interactive behaviors, suggesting possible microbial adaptation over time within the ecosystem. This study represents one of the most extensive phenotypic characterization of ISS potable water microbiota with implications for microbial risk assessments of water systems in built environments in space and on Earth.
summary: This study characterized five emergent phenotypes (antibiotic resistance, metabolism, hemolysis, biofilm structure/composition) of individual and multispecies microbial communities from NASA-archived isolates of the International Space Station (ISS) potable water system over several years. The research revealed a temporal dependence on interactive microbial behaviors, suggesting adaptation over time within this isolated ecosystem. This extensive phenotypic characterization has significant implications for microbial risk assessments of water systems in both space and terrestrial built environments.
impact: Scientifically, this study advances the understanding of dynamic emergent phenotypes in mixed-species microbial populations within closed habitats, highlighting the limitations of relying solely on sequencing for risk assessment. Practically, its findings are crucial for safeguarding astronaut health and ensuring the integrity of life-support systems on the ISS, directly informing microbial risk assessments for future space missions. Broader implications extend to improving water system management and risk assessment in built environments on Earth, making it a valuable contribution to applied microbiology and public health.

title: Draft Genome Sequences from a Novel Clade of Bacillus cereus Sensu Lato Strains, Isolated from the International Space Station
abstract: The draft genome sequences of six Bacillus strains, isolated from the International Space Station and belonging to the Bacillus anthracis-B. cereus-B. thuringiensis group, are presented here. These strains were isolated from the Japanese Experiment Module (one strain), U.S. Harmony Node 2 (three strains), and Russian Segment Zvezda Module (two strains).
summary: This publication presents the draft genome sequences for six novel *Bacillus cereus sensu lato* strains, belonging to the *Bacillus anthracis-B. cereus-B. thuringiensis* group, which were isolated from the International Space Station. The strains originated from the Japanese Experiment Module (one), U.S. Harmony Node 2 (three), and the Russian Segment Zvezda Module (two), providing genomic insights into the microbial inhabitants of the ISS.
impact: This research significantly advances the scientific understanding of microbial diversity and adaptation within human-occupied spacecraft environments through genomic sequencing. The characterization of these ISS-isolated *Bacillus* strains has practical applications for astronaut health monitoring, spacecraft environmental control, and the development of targeted countermeasures. This foundational genomic data also contributes to broader space biology efforts, including planetary protection and astrobiology research.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Acinetobacter and Bacillus Strains Isolated from Spacecraft-Associated Surfaces
abstract: We report here the draft genome sequences of four strains isolated from spacecraft-associated surfaces exhibiting increased resistance to stressors such as UV radiation and exposure to H2O2. The draft genomes of strains 1P01SCT, FO-92T, 50v1, and 2P01AA had sizes of 5,500,894 bp, 4,699,376 bp, 3,174,402 bp, and 4,328,804 bp, respectively.
summary: This study reports the draft genome sequences of four bacterial strains (1P01SCT, FO-92T, 50v1, and 2P01AA) belonging to the Acinetobacter and Bacillus genera, isolated from spacecraft-associated surfaces. These strains exhibit increased resistance to stressors like UV radiation and hydrogen peroxide. The genome sizes ranged from 3,174,402 bp to 5,500,894 bp, providing foundational genetic data to understand microbial survival and stress adaptation in extreme environments.
impact: Scientifically, this work provides crucial genomic data, advancing our understanding of the genetic basis for microbial stress resistance on spacecraft, which is vital for astrobiology and extremophile research. Practically, characterizing these resilient microorganisms is essential for assessing potential risks to astronaut health and for developing effective decontamination strategies and countermeasures for future space missions. This foundational data could also inform broader applications in controlling microbial contamination in other controlled or extreme environments.
original_title: Draft Genome Sequences of Acinetobacter and Bacillus Strains Isolated from Spacecraft-Associated Surfaces

title: KatharoSeq Enables High-Throughput Microbiome Analysis from Low-Biomass Samples
abstract: Microbiome analyses of low-biomass samples are challenging because of contamination and inefficiencies, leading many investigators to employ low-throughput methods with minimal controls. We developed a new automated protocol, KatharoSeq (from the Greek katharos [clean]), that outperforms single-tube extractions while processing at least five times as fast. KatharoSeq incorporates positive and negative controls to reveal the whole bacterial community from inputs of as few as 50 cells and correctly identifies 90.6% (standard error, 0.013%) of the reads from 500 cells. To demonstrate the broad utility of KatharoSeq, we performed 16S rRNA amplicon and shotgun metagenome analyses of the Jet Propulsion Laboratory spacecraft assembly facility (SAF; n = 192, 96), 52 rooms of a neonatal intensive care unit (NICU; n = 388, 337), and an endangered-abalone-rearing facility (n = 192, 123), obtaining spatially resolved, unique microbiomes reproducible across hundreds of samples. The SAF, our primary focus, contains 32 sOTUs (sub-OTUs, defined as exact sequence matches) and their inferred variants identified by the deblur algorithm, with four (Acinetobacter lwoffii, Paracoccus marcusii, Mycobacterium sp., and Novosphingobium) being present in >75% of the samples. According to microbial spatial topography, the most abundant cleanroom contaminant, A. lwoffii, is related to human foot traffic exposure. In the NICU, we have been able to discriminate environmental exposure related to patient infectious disease, and in the abalone facility, we show that microbial communities reflect the marine environment rather than human input. Consequently, we demonstrate the feasibility and utility of large-scale, low-biomass metagenomic analyses using the KatharoSeq protocol.
summary: This study developed KatharoSeq, a new automated and high-throughput protocol for microbiome analysis from low-biomass samples, outperforming single-tube extractions and processing at least five times faster. KatharoSeq can reveal whole bacterial communities from as few as 50 cells and correctly identifies 90.6% (standard error, 0.013%) of reads from 500 cells. The protocol was successfully applied to diverse environments, including the Jet Propulsion Laboratory spacecraft assembly facility (SAF), a neonatal intensive care unit (NICU), and an abalone-rearing facility, demonstrating its utility for large-scale, spatially resolved metagenomic analyses.
impact: Scientifically, KatharoSeq represents a significant methodological advance, addressing critical challenges of contamination and inefficiency in low-biomass microbiome analyses, enabling robust and reproducible results across hundreds of samples. Its application in the Jet Propulsion Laboratory spacecraft assembly facility has direct practical implications for space missions, planetary protection, and understanding microbial contamination in spacecraft environments. Broadly, the protocol's utility extends to terrestrial applications such as identifying environmental exposures related to infectious disease in NICUs and ecological monitoring in other built and natural environments, opening new avenues for large-scale metagenomic studies.
original_title: KatharoSeq enables high-throughput microbiome analysis from low-biomass samples

title: Draft Genome Sequence of a Clinical Isolate of Fusarium fujikuroi Isolated from a Male Patient with Acute Myeloid Leukemia
abstract: Here, we present the draft whole-genome sequence of a clinical isolate of Fusarium fujikuroi cultured from a patient undergoing chemotherapy for refractory acute myeloid leukemia.

The primary objective is to make this genomic data publicly available, thereby establishing a fundamental resource for subsequent research into this opportunistic fungal pathogen and its role in immunocompromised individuals.

While directly related to terrestrial clinical health, this genomic resource can also contribute to space biology by informing strategies to monitor and mitigate fungal risks to astronaut health, particularly in enclosed spacecraft environments where opportunistic pathogens can thrive.

title: Draft Genome Sequence of Solibacillus kalamii, Isolated from an Air Filter Aboard the International Space Station
abstract: We report here the draft genome of Solibacillus kalamii ISSFR-015, isolated from a high-energy particulate arrestance filter aboard the International Space Station. The draft genome sequence of this strain contains 3,809,180 bp with an estimated G+C content of 38.61%.

The sequenced genome spans 3,809,180 bp and exhibits an estimated G+C content of 38.61%. This announcement provides critical foundational genomic data for understanding microbial inhabitants of the ISS environment.
