title: Microbial Tracking-2, a metagenomics analysis of bacteria and fungi onboard the International Space Station
abstract:
Background

The International Space Station (ISS) is a unique and complex built environment with the ISS surface microbiome originating from crew and cargo or from life support recirculation in an almost entirely closed system. The Microbial Tracking 1 (MT-1) project was the first ISS environmental surface study to report on the metagenome profiles without using whole-genome amplification. The study surveyed the microbial communities from eight surfaces over a 14-month period. The Microbial Tracking 2 (MT-2) project aimed to continue the work of MT-1, sampling an additional four flights from the same locations, over another 14 months.

Methods

Eight surfaces across the ISS were sampled with sterile wipes and processed upon return to Earth. DNA extracted from the processed samples (and controls) were treated with propidium monoazide (PMA) to detect intact/viable cells or left untreated and to detect the total DNA population (free DNA/compromised cells/intact cells/viable cells). DNA extracted from PMA-treated and untreated samples were analyzed using shotgun metagenomics. Samples were cultured for bacteria and fungi to supplement the above results.

Results

Staphylococcus sp. and Malassezia sp. were the most represented bacterial and fungal species, respectively, on the ISS. Overall, the ISS surface microbiome was dominated by organisms associated with the human skin. Multi-dimensional scaling and differential abundance analysis showed significant temporal changes in the microbial population but no spatial differences. The ISS antimicrobial resistance gene profiles were however more stable over time, with no differences over the 5-year span of the MT-1 and MT-2 studies. Twenty-nine antimicrobial resistance genes were detected across all samples, with macrolide/lincosamide/streptogramin resistance being the most widespread. Metagenomic assembled genomes were reconstructed from the dataset, resulting in 82 MAGs. Functional assessment of the collective MAGs showed a propensity for amino acid utilization over carbohydrate metabolism. Co-occurrence analyses showed strong associations between bacterial and fungal genera. Culture analysis showed the microbial load to be on average 3.0 × 105 cfu/m2

Conclusions

Utilizing various metagenomics analyses and culture methods, we provided a comprehensive analysis of the ISS surface microbiome, showing microbial burden, bacterial and fungal species prevalence, changes in the microbiome, and resistome over time and space, as well as the functional capabilities and microbial interactions of this unique built microbiome. Data from this study may help to inform policies for future space missions to ensure an ISS surface microbiome that promotes astronaut health and spacecraft integrity.
summary: This study comprehensively analyzed the International Space Station (ISS) surface microbiome over 14 months, identifying *Staphylococcus sp.* and *Malassezia sp.* as the most represented bacterial and fungal species, with an average microbial load of 3.0 × 10⁵ cfu/m². It revealed significant temporal changes in microbial populations but stable antimicrobial resistance gene profiles over a 5-year span (detecting 29 such genes), and a functional propensity for amino acid utilization. This data is crucial for informing future space mission policies, ensuring astronaut health and spacecraft integrity.
impact: This publication significantly advances scientific understanding of the ISS built environment microbiome, its temporal dynamics, functional characteristics (via 82 reconstructed MAGs), and resistome, utilizing robust shotgun metagenomics and culture-based methods. Practically, the findings directly inform future space mission policies, which is crucial for maintaining astronaut health and spacecraft integrity by providing a baseline for monitoring and guiding countermeasures against microbial threats and antimicrobial resistance. It also offers valuable methodologies and insights applicable to terrestrial closed-environment microbiomes and long-duration human spaceflight.
original_title: Detection of antimicrobial resistance genes associated with the International Space Station environmental surfaces

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Two Fusarium oxysporum Isolates Cultured from Infected Zinnia hybrida Plants Grown on the International Space Station
abstract: Here, we present the whole-genome sequences of two Fusarium oxysporum isolates cultured from infected Zinnia hybrida plants that were grown onboard the International Space Station (ISS).
summary: This publication presents the whole-genome sequences of two *Fusarium oxysporum* isolates. These isolates were cultured from *Zinnia hybrida* plants grown onboard the International Space Station (ISS), providing foundational genetic data for understanding fungal pathogens in space environments.
impact: This genome announcement provides scientifically significant data by presenting the first whole-genome sequences of *Fusarium oxysporum* isolated directly from ISS-grown plants, expanding our understanding of microbial dynamics in closed-loop space habitats. Practically, this information is vital for developing countermeasures against plant pathogens to ensure successful long-duration space missions and maintain astronaut health. Broader implications include insights into fungal adaptation in unique environments, which could also inform terrestrial plant pathology.
original_title: Draft genome sequences of two Fusarium oxysporum isolates cultured from infected Zinnia hybrida plants grown on the International Space Station.

title: Metabolomic Analysis of Aspergillus niger Isolated From the International Space Station Reveals Enhanced Production Levels of the Antioxidant Pyranonigrin A
abstract: Secondary metabolite (SM) production in Aspergillus niger JSC-093350089, isolated from the International Space Station (ISS), is reported, along with a comparison to the experimentally established strain ATCC 1015. The analysis revealed enhanced production levels of naphtho-γ-pyrones and therapeutically relevant SMs, including bicoumanigrin A, aurasperones A and B, and the antioxidant pyranonigrin A. Genetic variants that may be responsible for increased SM production levels in JSC-093350089 were identified. These findings include INDELs within the predicted promoter region of flbA, which encodes a developmental regulator that modulates pyranonigrin A production via regulation of Fum21. The pyranonigrin A biosynthetic gene cluster was confirmed in A. niger, which revealed the involvement of a previously undescribed gene, pyrE, in its biosynthesis. UVC sensitivity assays enabled characterization of pyranonigrin A as a UV resistance agent in the ISS isolate.
summary: This study analyzed secondary metabolite production in *Aspergillus niger* isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) (JSC-093350089) compared to a terrestrial strain, revealing enhanced production of naphtho-γ-pyrones and therapeutically relevant secondary metabolites, including the antioxidant pyranonigrin A, in the ISS isolate. Researchers identified genetic variants, specifically INDELs within the *flbA* promoter, potentially responsible for increased production, confirmed the pyranonigrin A biosynthetic gene cluster, and found a previously undescribed gene, *pyrE*, involved in its biosynthesis. Additionally, pyranonigrin A was characterized as a UV resistance agent in the ISS isolate through UVC sensitivity assays.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of microbial adaptation and secondary metabolite biosynthesis in the unique space environment, pinpointing novel genetic mechanisms and a new gene (*pyrE*) linked to the production of beneficial compounds like the antioxidant and UV-resistant pyranonigrin A. Practically, these findings could lead to the discovery of new therapeutic agents or bioproduction strategies utilizing space-adapted microbes, while also informing risk assessments and countermeasure development for microbial presence on space missions. Broader implications include enhancing terrestrial drug discovery efforts and deepening insights into microbial evolution under environmental stress.
original_title: Characterization of Aspergillus niger Isolated from the International Space Station

title: Multi-drug resistant Enterobacter bugandensis species isolated from the International Space Station and comparative genomic analyses with human pathogenic strains
abstract:
Background

The antimicrobial resistance (AMR) phenotypic properties, multiple drug resistance (MDR) gene profiles, and genes related to potential virulence and pathogenic properties of five Enterobacter bugandensis strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) were carried out and compared with genomes of three clinical strains. Whole genome sequences of ISS strains were characterized using the hybrid de novo assembly of Nanopore and Illumina reads. In addition to traditional microbial taxonomic approaches, multilocus sequence typing (MLST) analysis was performed to classify the phylogenetic lineage. Agar diffusion discs assay was performed to test antibiotics susceptibility. The draft genomes after assembly and scaffolding were annotated with the Rapid Annotations using Subsystems Technology and RNAmmer servers for downstream analysis.

Results

Molecular phylogeny and whole genome analysis of the ISS strains with all publicly available Enterobacter genomes revealed that ISS strains were E. bugandensis and similar to the type strain EB-247T and two clinical isolates (153_ECLO and MBRL 1077). Comparative genomic analyses of all eight E. bungandensis strains showed, a total of 4733 genes were associated with carbohydrate metabolism (635 genes), amino acid and derivatives (496 genes), protein metabolism (291 genes), cofactors, vitamins, prosthetic groups, pigments (275 genes), membrane transport (247 genes), and RNA metabolism (239 genes). In addition, 112 genes identified in the ISS strains were involved in virulence, disease, and defense. Genes associated with resistance to antibiotics and toxic compounds, including the MDR tripartite system were also identified in the ISS strains. A multiple antibiotic resistance (MAR) locus or MAR operon encoding MarA, MarB, MarC, and MarR, which regulate more than 60 genes, including upregulation of drug efflux systems that have been reported in Escherichia coli K12, was also observed in the ISS strains.

Conclusion

Given the MDR results for these ISS Enterobacter genomes and increased chance of pathogenicity (PathogenFinder algorithm with > 79% probability), these species pose important health considerations for future missions. Thorough genomic characterization of the strains isolated from ISS can help to understand the pathogenic potential, and inform future missions, but analyzing them in in-vivo systems is required to discern the influence of microgravity on their pathogenicity.
summary: This study characterized five multi-drug resistant (MDR) *Enterobacter bugandensis* strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) through comparative genomic analyses with human pathogenic strains. Key findings included the identification of 112 genes involved in virulence, disease, and defense, along with genes associated with antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and a multiple antibiotic resistance (MAR) locus in the ISS strains. The PathogenFinder algorithm indicated a >79% probability of pathogenicity, highlighting significant health considerations for future space missions.
impact: This research significantly advances our understanding of microbial adaptation and potential pathogenicity in closed space environments, particularly concerning antibiotic resistance, through advanced genomic methodologies. The findings have direct practical implications for astronaut health monitoring and future space mission planning, underscoring the necessity of mitigating risks from potentially pathogenic, multi-drug resistant microbes. Furthermore, the study suggests the importance of future in-vivo research to fully elucidate the influence of microgravity on microbial pathogenicity.
original_title: Multi-drug resistant Enterobacter bugandensis species isolated from the International Space Station and comparative genomic analyses with human pathogenic strains

title: Correction to: Succession and persistence of microbial communities and antimicrobial resistance genes associated with International Space Station environmental surfaces
abstract:
Following publication of the original article [1], the authors reported a typographic error in scientific notation in the number of reads, the text should read as:

“Approximately 7.3 × 108 reads associated with microorganisms were generated after high quality trimming from PMA (21 samples) and non-PMA treated (21 samples) samples. All metagenomics reads were normalized across all samples, which yielded 3.1 × 108 in total, and 7.4 × 106 assigned to each sample, without affecting the taxonomic diversity.”

The authors regret these errors and the inconvenience caused.
summary: This publication is a correction notice for an original article on microbial communities and antimicrobial resistance on the International Space Station (ISS). It rectifies a typographic error in the scientific notation of metagenomics read counts. The corrected numbers specify approximately 7.3 × 10^8 raw reads, 3.1 × 10^8 total normalized reads, and 7.4 × 10^6 reads assigned per sample, with the important clarification that these corrections did not affect the taxonomic diversity findings of the original study.
impact: The scientific impact of this correction is primarily to uphold the integrity and accuracy of published research by ensuring data fidelity, specifically regarding metagenomics read counts for ISS microbial communities. While not directly advancing new knowledge, it reinforces the reliability of the original study's conclusions that taxonomic diversity remained unaffected. This accuracy is crucial for future research leveraging the dataset, supporting advancements in understanding astronaut health and potential countermeasures against antimicrobial resistance in space environments.
original_title: Succession and persistence of microbial communities and antimicrobial resistance genes associated with International Space Station environmental surfaces

title: International Space Station conditions alter genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics in Aspergillus nidulans.
abstract: The first global genomic, proteomic, and secondary metabolomic characterization of the filamentous fungus Aspergillus nidulans following growth onboard the International Space Station (ISS) is reported. The investigation included the A. nidulans wild-type and 3 mutant strains, two of which were genetically engineered to enhance secondary metabolite production. Whole genome sequencing revealed that ISS conditions altered the A. nidulans genome in specific regions. In strain CW12001, which features overexpression of the secondary metabolite global regulator laeA, ISS conditions induced the loss of the laeA stop codon. Differential expression of proteins involved in stress response, carbohydrate metabolic processes, and secondary metabolite biosynthesis was also observed. ISS conditions significantly decreased prenyl xanthone production in the wild-type strain and increased asperthecin production in LO1362 and CW12001, which are deficient in a major DNA repair mechanism. These data provide valuable insights into the adaptation mechanism of A. nidulans to spacecraft environments.
summary: This study conducted the first global multi-omics characterization, encompassing genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics, of the filamentous fungus *Aspergillus nidulans* grown onboard the International Space Station (ISS) using wild-type and genetically engineered mutant strains. Key findings revealed that ISS conditions induced specific genomic alterations, such as the loss of the *laeA* stop codon in strain CW12001, alongside differential protein expression related to stress response, carbohydrate metabolism, and secondary metabolite biosynthesis. Metabolomic analysis showed significantly decreased prenyl xanthone production in the wild-type strain but increased asperthecin production in DNA repair-deficient mutants LO1362 and CW12001, providing valuable insights into the adaptation mechanisms of *A. nidulans* to spacecraft environments.
impact: This research significantly advances our scientific understanding of how complex microbial life, specifically filamentous fungi, adapts at a multi-omics level to the unique conditions of the space environment. The findings have important practical implications for long-duration space missions, informing strategies for astronaut health by understanding potential microbial contaminants or beneficial roles, and guiding the development of countermeasures or resource utilization strategies. As a NASA Space Biology publication in a reputable journal, this work establishes a crucial foundation for future investigations into microbial resilience and metabolic engineering in extraterrestrial environments, with potential broader applications for stress biology on Earth.
theme: Genetics & Genomics of Fungal Adaptation to Space Conditions
original_title: International Space Station conditions alter genomics, proteomics, and metabolomics in Aspergillus nidulans.

title: Proteomic characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolated from air and surfaces of the International Space Station
abstract: The on-going Microbial Observatory Experiments on the International Space Station (ISS) revealed the presence of various microorganisms that may be affected by the distinct environment of the ISS. The low-nutrient environment combined with enhanced irradiation and microgravity may trigger changes in the molecular suite of microorganisms leading to increased virulence and resistance of microbes. Proteomic characterization of two Aspergillus fumigatus strains, ISSFT-021 and IF1SW-F4, isolated from HEPA filter debris and cupola surface of the ISS, respectively, is presented, along with a comparison to experimentally established clinical isolates Af293 and CEA10. In-depth analysis highlights variations in the proteome of both ISS-isolated strains when compared to the clinical strains. Proteins that showed increased abundance in ISS isolates were overall involved in stress responses, and carbohydrate and secondary metabolism. Among the most abundant proteins were Pst2 and ArtA involved in oxidative stress response, PdcA and AcuE responsible for ethanol fermentation and glyoxylate cycle, respectively, TpcA, TpcF, and TpcK that are part of trypacidin biosynthetic pathway, and a toxin Asp-hemolysin. This report provides insight into possible molecular adaptation of filamentous fungi to the unique ISS environment.
summary: This study proteomically characterized two *Aspergillus fumigatus* strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) and compared them to experimentally established clinical isolates. Key findings revealed variations in the proteome of the ISS-isolated strains, with proteins involved in stress responses, carbohydrate, and secondary metabolism showing increased abundance, including Pst2, ArtA, PdcA, AcuE, TpcA, TpcF, TpcK, and Asp-hemolysin. This research provides insight into the possible molecular adaptation of filamentous fungi to the unique ISS environment.
impact: This study significantly advances scientific understanding of microbial adaptation to the combined environmental stressors (low-nutrient, enhanced irradiation, microgravity) of space, utilizing proteomic analysis to identify molecular changes in *Aspergillus fumigatus*. The findings have critical practical applications for astronaut health and space mission safety, informing strategies for microbial control and countermeasure development against potentially altered fungal virulence or resistance. Broader implications include enhancing terrestrial understanding of microbial stress responses and guiding future research into the *in vivo* consequences of these molecular adaptations in space.
theme: Cell Biology: Microbial Proteomic Adaptation to the ISS
original_title: Proteomic characterization of Aspergillus fumigatus isolated from air and surfaces of the International Space Station.

title: Genomic Characterization and Virulence Potential of Two Fusarium oxysporum Isolates Cultured from the International Space Station
abstract: Two isolates of Fusarium oxysporum, ISS-F3 and ISS-F4, were cultured from the dining table on the International Space Station (ISS). Genomic analyses using EF-1α sequences, presence/absence of effector proteins, k-mer comparisons, and single nucleotide polymorphisms indicate that these two strains are genomically different from 65 known sequenced strains. Functional analysis revealed that ISS-F3/F4 had higher relative abundances of polyketide synthase domains than a non-plant-pathogenic soil isolate, used for biocontrol properties (Fo47), and a clinical isolate (FOSC-3a). Putative secondary metabolite analysis indicates that ISS-F3/F4 may produce yet-unreported polyketides and nonribosomal peptides. While genomic analysis showed that these ISS strains are unlikely to be plant pathogens, a virulence assay using an immunocompromised Caenorhabditis elegans model of fusariosis revealed that they were virulent and may represent opportunistic pathogens in animals, including humans. However, its effects on the health of immunocompromised humans warrant further study.
summary: This study genomically characterized two *Fusarium oxysporum* isolates, ISS-F3 and ISS-F4, from the International Space Station dining table. Genomic analyses, including EF-1α sequences, effector proteins, k-mer comparisons, and SNPs, revealed these strains are genomically distinct from 65 known sequenced strains and have higher relative abundances of polyketide synthase domains. While unlikely to be plant pathogens, a virulence assay using an immunocompromised *Caenorhabditis elegans* model demonstrated they were virulent, indicating potential as opportunistic pathogens in animals, including humans, which warrants further study.
impact: This publication significantly advances understanding of microbial ecology and potential health risks in enclosed space environments by identifying unique and potentially pathogenic fungal strains on the ISS. The detailed genomic characterization and virulence assessment provide critical insights for astronaut health monitoring and the development of countermeasures during long-duration space missions. Beyond space applications, this research contributes to the broader understanding of *Fusarium* species and their diverse pathogenic potential, including the discovery of novel secondary metabolites.
original_title: Genomic Characterization and Virulence Potential of Two Fusarium oxysporum Isolates Cultured from the International Space Station

title: Characterization of the total and viable bacterial and fungal communities associated with the International Space Station surfaces
abstract: Background The International Space Station (ISS) is a closed system inhabited by microorganisms originating from life support systems, cargo, and crew that are exposed to unique selective pressures such as microgravity. To date, mandatory microbial monitoring and observational studies of spacecraft and space stations have been conducted by traditional culture methods, although it is known that many microbes cannot be cultured with standard techniques. To fully appreciate the true number and diversity of microbes that survive in the ISS, molecular and culture-based methods were used to assess microbial communities on ISS surfaces. Samples were taken at eight pre-defined locations during three flight missions spanning 14 months and analyzed upon return to Earth. Results The cultivable bacterial and fungal population ranged from 104 to 109 CFU/m2 depending on location and consisted of various bacterial (Actinobacteria, Firmicutes, and Proteobacteria) and fungal (Ascomycota and Basidiomycota) phyla. Amplicon sequencing detected more bacterial phyla when compared to the culture-based analyses, but both methods identified similar numbers of fungal phyla. Changes in bacterial and fungal load (by culture and qPCR) were observed over time but not across locations. Bacterial community composition changed over time, but not across locations, while fungal community remained the same between samplings and locations. There were no significant differences in community composition and richness after propidium monoazide sample treatment, suggesting that the analyzed DNA was extracted from intact/viable organisms. Moreover, approximately 46% of intact/viable bacteria and 40% of intact/viable fungi could be cultured. Conclusions The results reveal a diverse population of bacteria and fungi on ISS environmental surfaces that changed over time but remained similar between locations. The dominant organisms are associated with the human microbiome and may include opportunistic pathogens. This study provides the first comprehensive catalog of both total and intact/viable bacteria and fungi found on surfaces in closed space systems and can be used to help develop safety measures that meet NASA requirements for deep space human habitation. The results of this study can have significant impact on our understanding of other confined built environments on the Earth such as clean rooms used in the pharmaceutical and medical industries.
summary: This study comprehensively characterized total and viable bacterial and fungal communities on International Space Station (ISS) surfaces using molecular and culture-based methods across eight locations over 14 months. Key findings revealed cultivable populations ranging from 10^4 to 10^9 CFU/m^2, with amplicon sequencing detecting more bacterial phyla than culture. Bacterial community composition changed over time but not across locations, while fungal communities remained stable; approximately 46% of intact/viable bacteria and 40% of intact/viable fungi were culturable. The research provides the first comprehensive catalog of ISS surface microbes, dominated by human microbiome-associated organisms, including potential opportunistic pathogens.
impact: Scientifically, this study significantly advances our understanding of microbial survival and dynamics in closed space systems by providing the first comprehensive catalog of both total and intact/viable bacteria and fungi, bridging traditional culture methods with advanced molecular techniques. Practically, these findings are critical for developing robust safety measures that meet NASA requirements for deep space human habitation, directly informing astronaut health and environmental control strategies. Beyond space, the results have broader implications for understanding and managing microbial communities in other confined built environments on Earth, such as clean rooms in pharmaceutical and medical industries.
original_title: Characterization of the total and viable bacterial and fungal communities associated with the International Space Station surfaces.

title: Proteomic and Metabolomic Characteristics of Extremophilic Fungi Under Simulated Mars Conditions
abstract: Filamentous fungi have been associated with extreme habitats, including nuclear power plant accident sites and the International Space Station (ISS). Due to their immense adaptation and phenotypic plasticity capacities, fungi may thrive in what seems like uninhabitable niches. This study is the first report of fungal survival after exposure of monolayers of conidia to simulated Mars conditions (SMC). Conidia of several Chernobyl nuclear accident-associated and ISS-isolated strains were tested for UV-C and SMC sensitivity, which resulted in strain-dependent survival. Strains surviving exposure to SMC for 30 min, ISSFT-021-30 and IMV 00236-30, were further characterized for proteomic, and metabolomic changes. Differential expression of proteins involved in ribosome biogenesis, translation, and carbohydrate metabolic processes was observed. No significant metabolome alterations were revealed. Lastly, ISSFT-021-30 conidia re-exposed to UV-C exhibited enhanced UV-C resistance when compared to the conidia of unexposed ISSFT-021.
summary: This study investigated the survival and proteomic/metabolomic characteristics of extremophilic fungi, including Chernobyl nuclear accident-associated and ISS-isolated strains, under simulated Mars conditions (SMC). It revealed strain-dependent fungal survival after 30 minutes of SMC exposure, with strains ISSFT-021-30 and IMV 00236-30 showing differential expression of proteins related to ribosome biogenesis, translation, and carbohydrate metabolism, but no significant metabolome alterations. Critically, re-exposure to UV-C enhanced resistance in ISSFT-021-30 conidia, demonstrating adaptation to extreme environments.
impact: This research provides the first evidence of fungal survival under simulated Mars conditions, significantly advancing our understanding of extremophile adaptation and astrobiology. The detailed proteomic analysis sheds light on the cellular mechanisms of resilience, offering valuable insights for planetary protection protocols and the search for extraterrestrial life. Furthermore, these findings have practical implications for astronaut health by informing strategies to mitigate microbial risks and develop countermeasures during future long-duration space missions.
theme: Cell Biology: Extremophilic Fungal Adaptation to Simulated Mars Conditions
original_title: Proteomic and Metabolomic Characteristics of Extremophilic Fungi Under Simulated Mars Conditions.

title: MetaMiner: A Scalable Peptidogenomics Approach for Discovery of Ribosomal Peptide Natural Products with Blind Modifications from Microbial Communities
abstract: Ribosomally synthesized and post-translationally modified peptides (RiPPs) are an important class of natural products that contain antibiotics and a variety of other bioactive compounds. The existing methods for discovery of RiPPs by combining genome mining and computational mass spectrometry are limited to discovering specific classes of RiPPs from small datasets, and they fail to handle unknown post-translational modifications. We present MetaMiner, a software tool for addressing these challenges that is compatible with large-scale screening platforms for natural product discovery. After searching millions of spectra in the Global Natural Products Social (GNPS) molecular networking infrastructure against just eight genomic and metagenomic datasets, MetaMiner discovered 31 known and seven unknown RiPPs from diverse microbial communities including human microbiome, lichen microbiome, and micro-organisms isolated from the International Space Station.
summary: MetaMiner, a new scalable peptidogenomics software, was developed to overcome limitations in discovering Ribosomally synthesized and post-translationally modified peptides (RiPPs) with unknown modifications from microbial communities using computational mass spectrometry. By analyzing millions of spectra against eight genomic/metagenomic datasets, the tool successfully discovered 31 known and 7 previously unknown RiPPs. These RiPPs were sourced from diverse microbial communities, including those isolated from the International Space Station, showcasing its utility for large-scale natural product discovery platforms.
impact: This publication significantly advances the field of natural product discovery by introducing MetaMiner, a novel and scalable computational tool capable of identifying RiPPs with blind post-translational modifications from vast metagenomic datasets. Its successful application to microorganisms from the International Space Station directly contributes to NASA's Space Biology efforts, offering a new method for discovering bioactive compounds potentially relevant to astronaut health, countermeasures, or environmental monitoring. Beyond space applications, this methodology has broad implications for drug discovery and a deeper understanding of microbial biochemistry in diverse terrestrial environments, such as the human microbiome.
keywords: Ribosomally synthesized and post-translationally modified peptides
original_title: MetaMiner: A Scalable Peptidogenomics Approach for Discovery of Ribosomal Peptide Natural Products with Blind Modifications from Microbial Communities

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Sphingomonas Species Associated with the International Space Station
abstract: The draft genome sequences of three Sphingomonas strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) were assembled. These genomic sequences will help in understanding the influence of microgravity conditions on their potential bioactive compound production and other important characteristics compared to their Earth counterparts.
summary: The study assembled the draft genome sequences for three *Sphingomonas* strains isolated from the International Space Station (ISS). This foundational genomic data will enable future research to understand how microgravity influences the production of potential bioactive compounds and other characteristics of these bacteria compared to their Earth-based counterparts.
impact: Scientifically, this publication provides crucial genomic data, advancing understanding of microbial adaptation and potential functionality in the space environment. Practically, this information could be vital for assessing microbial roles in astronaut health or developing in-situ biotechnological applications during long-duration space missions. The data serves as a stepping stone for future research into space microbiology and astrobiology, potentially leading to new insights into microbial resilience and metabolic capabilities.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Tremellomycetes Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
abstract: The draft genome sequences of six eukaryotic microbial strains belonging to the class Tremellomycetes isolated from the International Space Station were assembled. Further characterization of these sequences will aid in the understanding of the influence of microgravity conditions on these organisms’ potential pathogenicity.
summary: Draft genome sequences of six eukaryotic microbial strains belonging to the class Tremellomycetes, isolated from the International Space Station, were successfully assembled. This foundational genomic data will aid in further characterization to understand how microgravity conditions influence these organisms’ potential pathogenicity. The research aims to provide insights into microbial adaptation in space environments.
impact: This publication significantly advances scientific knowledge by providing essential genomic data for ISS-isolated microbes, which is critical for understanding microbial responses to microgravity and their evolutionary potential. Practically, this information is vital for monitoring astronaut health, assessing bioburden risks, and developing countermeasures for long-duration space missions. The involvement of NASA and prominent researchers like Christopher E Mason highlights the study's relevance to space biology and its potential to inform future astrobiological research and spacecraft design.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Rhodotorula mucilaginosa Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
abstract: The whole-genome sequences (WGS) of 28 isolates from the International Space Station were generated and identified as Rhodotorula mucilaginosa, a pigmented yeast that has been classified as an emerging human pathogen in recent times. These WGS enable the identification of genes responsible for synthesizing compounds with biological implications.
summary: This study aimed to generate whole-genome sequences (WGS) for 28 *Rhodotorula mucilaginosa* isolates obtained from the International Space Station (ISS). The researchers successfully identified these isolates as *Rhodotorula mucilaginosa*, a pigmented yeast recently classified as an emerging human pathogen. These comprehensive WGS data are crucial for identifying genes involved in synthesizing compounds with significant biological implications.
impact: This publication represents a significant scientific advancement by providing genomic insights into an emerging human pathogen specifically adapted to the unique environment of the ISS. Practically, this research is vital for improving microbial monitoring strategies, assessing astronaut health risks, and potentially developing countermeasures against microbial threats in long-duration space missions. Broader implications include enhancing our understanding of microbial adaptation and pathogenicity in closed, extreme environments, which can also inform terrestrial studies of environmental pathogens.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Enterobacteriales Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
abstract: The whole-genome sequences of 26 strains isolated from the International Space Station were generated, and the strains were identified as being members of the order Enterobacteriales. Characterization of these whole-genome sequences might enable the identification of potential pathogenic bacteria that have been adapting to the space environment.
summary: This study generated the whole-genome sequences for 26 Enterobacteriales bacterial strains isolated from the International Space Station. The primary objective is to characterize these sequences to identify potential pathogenic bacteria that may be adapting to the unique space environment. This genomic data is crucial for understanding microbial behavior and assessing potential risks to astronaut health during long-duration space missions.
impact: This publication makes a significant scientific contribution by providing foundational genomic data, advancing the understanding of microbial adaptation within the ISS's closed environment. Practically, this information is vital for identifying potential pathogens and developing countermeasures, directly enhancing astronaut health and mission safety. Broader implications include insights into microbial evolution in extreme conditions, which can inform both space exploration strategies and terrestrial microbiology research.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Lactobacillales Isolated from the International Space Station
abstract: Nineteen strains from the order Lactobacillales were isolated from the International Space Station and commercial resupply vehicle, and whole-genome sequences (WGS) were generated. WGS would permit the characterization of these potentially pathogenic bacteria that have been adapting to the extreme conditions of the space environment.
summary: This publication announces the isolation of nineteen bacterial strains from the order Lactobacillales, recovered from the International Space Station (ISS) and commercial resupply vehicles. Whole-genome sequences (WGS) were generated for these strains to enable the characterization of these potentially pathogenic bacteria. This data will facilitate research into their adaptation to the extreme conditions encountered in the space environment.
impact: Scientifically, this work provides valuable foundational genomic data for understanding microbial adaptation and evolution within the unique space environment, advancing the field of space microbiology. Practically, the characterization of these potentially pathogenic strains is crucial for assessing risks to astronaut health, developing countermeasures, and ensuring the safety and success of future space missions. This resource also contributes to a broader understanding of microbial survival in extreme, closed ecosystems.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Klebsiella Species Isolated from the International Space Station
abstract: Isolated across four locations aboard the International Space Station (ISS), 10 bacterial strains were compared using whole-genome sequencing analysis and were phylogenetically identified as Klebsiella. The whole-genome sequences will aid in comparative genomic studies of ISS Klebsiella strains with Earth counterparts to gain insight into their adaptation to space conditions.
summary: This publication describes the whole-genome sequencing analysis of 10 bacterial strains, isolated from four locations on the International Space Station, which were phylogenetically identified as Klebsiella species. The objective was to provide these sequences for comparative genomic studies, aiming to understand the adaptation of ISS Klebsiella strains to space conditions by comparing them with Earth counterparts. This resource will facilitate future research into microbial adaptation in extraterrestrial environments.
impact: This publication significantly advances space microbiology by providing crucial genomic data for 10 Klebsiella strains isolated from the ISS, enabling comparative genomic studies to understand microbial adaptation to space conditions. Practically, this knowledge can inform strategies for astronaut health and environmental monitoring on long-duration missions by identifying potential pathogenic adaptations. Broader implications include insights into microbial evolution in extreme environments and potential applications for terrestrial pathogen research.

title: Draft Genome Sequences of Bacillaceae Strains Isolated from the International Space Station
abstract: The draft genome sequences of 29 bacterial isolates belonging to the family Bacillaceae were collected from the International Space Station, assembled, and identified. Further analysis of these sequences will enable us to understand their roles for space and biotechnological applications.
summary: This publication reports the draft genome sequencing, assembly, and identification of 29 bacterial isolates from the Bacillaceae family, collected from the International Space Station. impact: This resource announcement provides crucial foundational genomic data for 29 ISS-isolated bacterial strains, significantly advancing the understanding of microbial ecology and adaptation in space environments. title: Assessing the Risk of Transfer of Microorganisms at the International Space Station Due to Cargo Delivery by Commercial Resupply Vehicles
abstract:
Background

With increasing numbers of interplanetary missions, there is a need to establish robust protocols to ensure the protection of extraterrestrial planets being visited from contamination by terrestrial life forms. The current study is the first report comparing the commercial resupply vehicle (CRV) microbiome with the International Space Station (ISS) microbiome to understand the risks of contamination, thus serving as a model system for future planetary missions.

Results

Samples obtained from the internal surfaces and ground support equipment of three CRV missions were subjected to various molecular techniques for microbial diversity analysis. In total, 25 samples were collected with eight defined locations from each CRV mission prior to launch. In general, the internal surfaces of vehicles were clean, with an order of magnitude fewer microbes compared to ground support equipment. The first CRV mission had a larger microbial population than subsequent CRV missions, which were clean as compared to the initial CRV locations sampled. Cultivation assays showed the presence of Actinobacteria, Proteobacteria, Firmicutes, and Bacteroidetes and members of Ascomycota and Basidiomycota. As expected, shotgun metagenome analyses revealed the presence of more microbial taxa compared to cultivation-based assays. The internal locations of the CRV microbiome reportedly showed the presence of microorganisms capable of tolerating ultraviolet radiation (e.g., Bacillus firmus) and clustered separately from the ISS microbiome.

Conclusions

The metagenome sequence comparison of the CRV microbiome with the ISS microbiome revealed significant differences showing that CRV microbiomes were a negligible part of the ISS environmental microbiome. These findings suggest that the maintenance protocols in cleaning CRV surfaces are highly effective in controlling the contaminating microbial population during cargo transfer to the ISS via the CRV route.
summary: This study compared the microbiome of Commercial Resupply Vehicles (CRVs) with that of the International Space Station (ISS) to assess the risk of microbial contamination, serving as a model for future planetary protection. Samples from internal surfaces and ground support equipment of three CRV missions revealed that internal vehicle surfaces were generally clean, with an order of magnitude fewer microbes compared to ground support equipment. Metagenome sequence comparison showed CRV microbiomes were a negligible part of the ISS environmental microbiome, indicating that CRV maintenance protocols are highly effective in controlling microbial populations during cargo transfer.
impact: This research significantly advances scientific knowledge by providing the first direct comparison of CRV and ISS microbiomes, establishing a crucial model for future planetary protection protocols. Practically, its findings validate the effectiveness of current CRV cleaning procedures, minimizing microbial transfer risks to the ISS and informing robust protocols essential for safeguarding extraterrestrial environments during interplanetary missions. The insights gained are critical for astronaut health and broader space mission planning, potentially guiding the development of enhanced contamination countermeasures for various space vehicles and destinations.
original_title: Assessing the risk of transfer of microorganisms at the International Space Station due to cargo delivery by commercial resupply vehicles

title: Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov., Isolated From the International Space Station
abstract: Four strains belonging to the family of Methylobacteriaceae were isolated from different locations on the International Space Station (ISS) across two consecutive flights. Of these, three were identified as Gram-negative, rod-shaped, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, motile bacteria, designated as IF7SW-B2T, IIF1SW-B5, and IIF4SW-B5, whereas the fourth was identified as Methylorubrum rhodesianum. The sequence similarity of these three ISS strains, designated as IF7SW-B2T, IIF1SW-B5, and IIF4SW-B5, was <99.4% for 16S rRNA genes and <97.3% for gyrB gene, with the closest being Methylobacterium indicum SE2.11T. Furthermore, the multi-locus sequence analysis placed these three ISS strains in the same clade of M. indicum. The average nucleotide identity (ANI) values of these three ISS strains were <93% and digital DNA-DNA hybridization (dDDH) values were <46.4% with any described Methylobacterium species. Based on the ANI and dDDH analyses, these three ISS strains were considered as novel species belonging to the genus Methylobacterium. The three ISS strains showed 100% ANI similarity and dDDH values with each other, indicating that these three ISS strains, isolated during various flights and from different locations, belong to the same species. These three ISS strains were found to grow optimally at temperatures from 25 to 30°C, pH 6.0 to 8.0, and NaCl 0 to 1%. Phenotypically, these three ISS strains resemble M. aquaticum and M. terrae since they assimilate similar sugars as sole carbon substrate when compared to other Methylobacterium species. Fatty acid analysis showed that the major fatty acid produced by the ISS strains are C18:1−ω7c and C18:1−ω6c. The predominant quinone was ubiquinone 10, and the major polar lipids were diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol, and an unidentified lipid. Therefore, based on genomic, phylogenetic, biochemical, and fatty acid analyses, strains IF7SW-B2T, IIF1SW-B5, and IIF4SW-B5, are assigned to a novel species within the genus Methylobacterium, and the name Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov. is proposed. The type strain is IF7SW-B2T (NRRL B-65601T and LMG 32165T).
headings: Description of Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov.
summary: This study aimed to identify novel bacterial species isolated from the International Space Station (ISS) across two consecutive flights. Researchers identified four strains of Methylobacteriaceae, with three determined to be a novel species, *Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov.*, based on extensive genomic analyses. These novel strains showed <99.4% 16S rRNA and <97.3% gyrB gene similarity, <93% ANI, and <46.4% dDDH with any described Methylobacterium species, thus expanding our understanding of the ISS microbial environment.
impact: Scientifically, this research significantly advances our understanding of the microbial ecosystem within the International Space Station, emphasizing the robust application of polyphasic taxonomy for novel species identification in extreme environments. Practically, identifying *Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov.* is critical for monitoring astronaut health and maintaining the integrity of life support systems during long-duration space missions. This work contributes to astrobiology and informs strategies for managing microbial communities in confined habitats, both in space and potentially on Earth.
original_title: Methylobacterium ajmalii sp. nov., isolated from the International Space Station
